Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After completing this book for you, O sons, which is the last science in medicine with its complement, and having reached its end in it, by explanations thereof and its declarations, I found it pleasing to me to complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the operation, that is, chirurgery with my hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	For the operation with the hand is laid down in our region and entirely cut off in our time: until perhaps science of it perishes, and its track is cut off: and none of them remained except small descriptions in ancient books, which have changed hands: and an error and doubt occurred to them until their intentions were closed, and the will of its was extended: I found it pleasing to me to revive it with the intention of this treatise in it according to the life of its position, and its declaration, and its abbreviation: and to make it like the forms of the cauteries and other instruments of work: when addition is made from its declaration, and from its operation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	However, the cause why this skilled artisan with his hand did not find good in our time is: because medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to exercise before this in knowledge of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the excitement of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, and nerves, and tendons, and number of them, and their exit, and pulsars, and quiet, and exits of their places:
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for that reason Hippocrates said that the name when it is with the name is much, and when it is with the work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already spoken of that at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is not aware that we are speaking of anatomy, does not understand, and thus falls into the error in which men are killed: just as I have seen many of them, who, being formed by this science, throw it aside without knowledge and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What is that, because I have seen a stupid physician cut an abscess of the gross and it happened that some arteries were cut in the neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed until she died, until she became a dead woman in her hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician who presumed to extract the stone that had passed through the urethra in youth, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he went to him, and extracted it with a small force.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	Indeed I had already called to extract it, and I saw from the size of the stone and the weakness of its position that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who received a bone from a certain duke of our land for medicinal purposes: and it happened to an black eunuch, who was with him, a fracture near the heel: and the physician, with ignorance of his own, hurried up and tied the fracture with a thumb on the palm with strong strings, and did not release the wound's expiration.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released him according to his desire.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Later he released him for some days, and commanded him not to untie the bandage: and he stood thus until the abscess of his leg was cured, and his foot, and then he forced it to death.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him, and I went to loosen the bandage: and immediately peace came, and he was free from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, corruption had already settled in the member: and I could not stop it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, let corruption walk around in the member until it perishes.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous carbuncle: and the wound became after days, until the malice of it grew with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, because when there is a pure cancer from the melancholic humor, it does not need to be treated with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can bear it, so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, O Son, it is necessary for you to know that the operation when done with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation which is associated with safety, and the operation which is dangerous in many positions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already stirred up this book in all its places where the operation comes, in which there is fear and trembling.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, it is necessary for you to guard against this, and let it go: so that fools may not find a way to speak and disgrace themselves.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take the measure with anxiety and protection, and your weakness with ease and firmness, and use the better way of grace from God for salvation and praiseworthy success: and let go of difficulties of life-endangering diseases: and take your souls away from him who makes you afraid, so that he may enter into superstition upon your faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining for your glory, and sublime in this world, and finally for your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You should not heal evil with evil, nor call bad doctors good.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	This book has already been divided into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	First Chapter. Of cauterization with fire and with sharp medicine, a book divided into sections from the head to the feet, and the forms of the instruments and tools of cauterization, and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Second Chapter. Of sectioning and piercing, phlebotomy and venous bleeding, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows and similar objects: and everything in its proper place, divided into forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Third Chapter. Of restoration and dislocation, and treatment of twisting, and similar cases: and everything in its proper place, divided into forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	About the use of cauterization and its effects, and which complexions it suits, and when, and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	However, before that, it is necessary to say the nature of the wounds and the effects of cauterization of its own, and in which complexion it is shown.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say that the speech about the nature of the wound caused by cauterization and its effects is a long and subtle one, knowledge, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Even a multitude of wise men have spoken in it, and they have disputed in it, and for me, it is enough a little from their words, fearing the prolongation.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I declare that cauterization is effective on all wounds, whether with matter or without matter, except for two wounds: the hot wound without matter and the dry wound without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry wound with matter, they have disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that cauterization is harmful in that case.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	However, others have said that cauterization is not suitable for the disease which is caused by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is hotness: and it is unsuitable to heal from a hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	He who says the opposite has said that a wound is made by cauterization in all hot and dry diseases that occur in the bodies of men, because when you compare the body of man and his humors to the fire, you find the body of man to be cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I also say by his words: because I have already found that through experiment this will happen again.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	Nevertheless, it does not belong for him to come upon that, unless he has already proven it and been exercised in the chapter of cauterization, and has known the diversity of human wounds, and the nature and disposition of their diseases, and their causes and accidents, and the time of their occurrence.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	However, do not fear from other wounds: and especially in cold and damp diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have become familiar with those: and they have not disagreed in the wound with cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And you know, son, that from the secret of the physician's care, with cauterization and the goodness of fire, and over the medicine burning with cauterization, is that fire is simple, whose action does not harm except to the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm any other connected member unless it harms slightly.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning surgeons in medicine is indeed detrimental to that which is extended from the limbs: and perhaps it even causes difficulty in the treatment of difficult disease in a member, and perhaps it even kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	However, fire, due to its own subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed, we have not yet learned this from experiment, due to the length of practice and study with the art, and the station on the truth of things: and for that reason I excuse the length of my speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if there were not, because it is not allowed for me to bring this secret and hidden thing about fire to you in this book, and the quality of its operation in bodies, by which it expels diseases that are demonstrated by philosophical speech, which disturbs your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know you, O sons, that you yourselves disagree in the time when it is most convenient to make a cauterization, and they set a better time for my lesson.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is convenient at all times, because the hurt that happens by the time is swallowed up in the wound, which is drawn to the cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And above all, if the cauterization is made for the sake of pains that are necessary and hard, and which do not endure delay: because it is feared that from them a greater malice may happen than the small hurt which is done by being late.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not suppose that this thing will not be in your minds, O sons, unless you are vile and stupid physicians, that is to say, that the diseases which are cured by cauterization are not always a return: and they set it down as a consequence, and things are not as they think: because cauterization is not but in the place of medicine, which alters the complexion, and dries up the humors which are causes of the pains, wherefore the pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Indeed, the cauterization aids the healing process of its own disease, and the strength of its own operation, and the power of its master's dominion: and it is possible that the illness lasts for some time according to the complexion of the weak, and the location of his illness, and the power of his illness: and that it is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superfluities in it: and that it is sustained by it in its acquisition from food, and similar ones from their causes, unless an illness occurs in which the cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A slight illness in a member of few superfluities and moisture, such as the tooth cauterization, for pain, and similar ones, is possible that it does not last in that one pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But my speech is again a matter of delay, that cauterization is the last of medicine: not what they intend in it: for they believe that there is no cure which confirms with the medicine, nor with another after the occasion of the cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the matter is contrary to that, and the intention, that cauterization is the last of medicine, is not, unless when we administer modes of cure in some diseases, and they do not confirm those of medicine: then we administer at the end of the case cauterization, and it confirms: then falls out that cauterization is the last of medicines, not according to the intention which the wise and proud physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients said that cauterization with gold is better than with iron, and they did not say it otherwise than for the equality of gold, and the sublimity of its own substance: and they said that it does not make a pus place in the cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Indeed, it is not absolutely true: for I have already proven this, and found that it does not make it in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization, when used alone, is beneficial, and better than when iron is used, as they have said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Indeed, when you use fire for cauterization on gold, it does not appear to you when it is heated according to the amount you wish, due to the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add above it further heat, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls away from that and is replaced by one who does it better and more easily: and therefore we use cauterization with iron here, which is more suitable for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	Indeed, I have already ordered this chapter on cauterization, according to the previous one: and I have ordered them from the head to the feet: so that those who seek it may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	¶ About the method of cauterization of the head in a circular band.
Caput II.	Head 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is applied to the dominion of moisture and coldness over the head: which are two causes of soda, and the multitude of fluids from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and the multitude of dreams, and pain of the teeth, and pain of the throat: and generally all diseases that happen from coldness, such as paralysis, and soda, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and like these from the diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is, to treat the patient as follows: so that he may vomit in the first place when the head is uncovered and cleansed with a mild medicine three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient and his age, and habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then he commanded him to make a cut across his own head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then place him facing you, so that he places his own hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the base of your thumb on the base of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Therefore, if his middle finger bends, mark that spot with a thin line.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the cauterization of olive oil: whose form is shown here.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it directly on the marked spot with a thin line, using a gradual descent so that you can gently clench your hand around it and roll it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then gently pull back your hand and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see already that the amount of bone in the head is decreased or the amount of flesh, then pull back your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, you will pull back your hand with the same iron, or with another that is frozen: until the bones that I told you about are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from the salt, dissolve it in water, drink it yourself, and place it on the spot, and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the buttermilk drunk on top of it over the spot, and leave it there until the scar burns away with fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with the ointment Tetrapharmacons, until it is cured.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that the more of the finger remains open, the more pus is emitted: therefore it is better and more inflamed.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone: and the cauterization should be held until it becomes somewhat thick with bone.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is cut after that which is hardened from the bone, and then it is cured.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	They say that others, it is necessary that when cauterization permeates to the end, until it imprints in the mouth an impression of lead, so that the head falls down, like the form of a chisel: or the instrument that women put infused with the large alphabet: and they consider that they exhale from this place vapors of the head, and the elbow is released for a long time open.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is treated, until it is consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	However, I do not recognize these two kinds of cauterization at all, except in some men according to the fear of man.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And let it be released, with my health it is better with his own.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head is weakened from the solution of its continuous natural nature: as we have testified in other parts: and especially when the head is weak and feeble, the nature: and indeed the first kind of cauterization is more gentle and better with me, and I use it: therefore operate with it in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	¶ About the method of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there happens chronic pain, and it is prolonged in the weak, and it is used with plasters, and needles, and head purgatives, and oils, and emplastered things.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if the cauterization has already been done with the cauterization we have mentioned, and it does not give anything to it from them: then consider it.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is weak from the nature of creation, and it is not feeble, and it finds coldness: then cauterize with another cauterization less there under.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over all the horn of its own cauterization, do not pierce the skin, and it should not excavate from the quantity of bone that we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And he should cauterize himself with one burning iron on the back of his head, in the place which is called the eye. And this is a place where the wound is located, and you will cut off your bone there, and do not break your skull.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the weak man finds this painful due to that intense pain, and different from the pain of other head burns.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say this cauterization is in its proper place: and it must be a cauterization where the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of his head with a softer cauterization, where the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is the form of him.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	¶ About the method of cauterization in migraines, both when the medicine is burnt, and when it is made of iron.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When the pain and soreness is in a part of the head, or it extends to the eye, and the face becomes wet with the medicine washing the head, and the remainder of the treatment is given as I said in the divisions of the disease, and it does not all fit together: then the cauterization in him is in two ways: either with a hot medicine burning, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But when the cauterization is with a hot medicine burning, it is like this: take one tooth, and cut it out, and cut off the ends of its two sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then divide the painful place at the time when the phlebotomist makes a wide cut, until there is under the skin a place where the tooth can catch.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore insert it into the same place under the skin until it is hidden: then tighten it above it with a gentle constriction, and let it stay for fifteen hours, then dissolve the tooth, and remove the alien, and leave it for two or three days, or four: then put a submerged belly on it, until the place becomes pussy: then care for it with ointment until it is cured.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	If you wish to perform this with some of the medicines that I have mentioned as burning in the twelfth book of my treatise on medicines for the Middle Ages.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization, however, is done in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The form of the cauterization is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	It is called the Clauilis: for its form is like that of the scalp, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle there is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it directly on the spot and hold your hand: and you will rotate the iron slightly with force: and the amount that is burned will be from the thickness of the skin, as in the middle of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand, so that the artery beneath is not burned and the flow of blood is not obstructed.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then drink the ointment in salt water and place it on the spot for three days, then place the ointment with butter, and then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish to cauterize this half-crane with the second extremity of the Cauterization iron.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And take care not to cut the artery in this half-crane, not in the proper sense.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ In the method of cauterization in the old half-crane.
Caput V.	5. Head.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating the half-crane, with what we have said in the preceding treatment and with the division of diseases, and not with the curing: and you see from the disease that it is not enough for him that we have said in the first cauterization with medicine, or with cauterization with fire, then it is necessary to make the Cauterization iron hot until it becomes white after the signs on the spot of pain with the line, whose length is the middle of the digit, or as if this were: and place your hand on it carefully once, and tie it until you incise the artery and press up to the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	Indeed it is necessary for you to prevent the continuation of the jaw, which moves during mastication, from becoming inflamed on the side, or the nerve that moves it, from causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And this is for the care and caution of the artery that has been excised.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	In the excising of it, there is fear, and especially him who does not know what it does, nor is eager, nor experienced: and he lets the operation be done with that first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I also remember when the regulation of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own mode, and in its place in this book, happened.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the patient's illness, that this cauterization is not sufficient for him, and if you see a weak body enduring the cauterization in the middle of the head, as we have mentioned, then care for the elbow until it recovers.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer this cauterization that we said in the chapter of the extraction of the artery with the cauterization having two hammers.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	§ About the method of cauterizing in painful ears.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When there happens pain in the ear from cold, and it is cured with dissolved things, and the remaining cure that we have mentioned in the division, and it does not remove the pain, then with fire cauterization: and this is what is called the point, whose form is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the points with it after its burning around the ear, as it rotates: or around both, if the pain is in both at the same time.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And stretch it with the cauterization at the root of the ear as much as you can after seeing the places with the burning: and the quantity of the cauterization should be ten points in all the ear, and almost that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then attend to the location, until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	In the method of cauterization in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Torture which is practiced with cauterization, is not but from those species which happen from phlegm, according to what we said in the division of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And she also mentioned the species of cauterization which happens from dryness, and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you are treating this species of torture with ear-drops, and purgatives, and gargles, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary for you to cauterize the weak one with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and a second rather lower than usual at the time, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And then place your cauterization on the opposite side of the weak one.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For hardening does not happen, unless in the part which appears to be healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cauterization is, that it cauterizes itself with Cauterization in direct contact with the upper extremity of the ear, sub-cornu of the head, quite: and another at a different time: whose length is according to the length of the finger.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And lay your hand with the cauterization, until the quantity of the denseness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterization, and it is a species from the knife, whose form was mentioned before: verily it is not too fine, as you see: and it is necessary for it to be a knife with a superfluous bulk quite.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then attend to the location, with that which precedes: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	In the method of cauterization in old stroke.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes old, and when you treat it as we said, and your treatment does not agree with it, and it does not have a fever, then cauterize it with four cauterizations over all the horn of its head, and a cauterization in the middle of its head, as we said, and a cauterization in the back of its head, according to what precedes: and the mode of cauterization should be according to what precedes.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Even it is cauterized with cauterization over the stomach's cheek: and it is the lastest of all.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is treated, according to what precedes.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	¶ About the method of cauterization in Obliuition.
Caput IX.	Head Nine.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the first place, powerful ones are given to the big eyelid, and pills that cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shake the head of the weak one all over, and place on top of its occipital bone the plaster described in the treatise on plasters: and place it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For it is the mode of cauterization: and make it according to the same order that I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If then it is cured by this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make three cauterizations in the back of its head, which are going from the top of its head to the lower part of the eye: and place between all the cauterization the size of the finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization according to what precedes.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you want an addition, and it is enduring that one: then make for it a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you want an addition: then cauterize it on two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it, until it is cured: let the cauterization be olive-shaped according to the form that was said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the mode of cauterization in paralysis and mollification.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed with the cleansing of the head with iodine, and as we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then gently rub the weak head: then cauterize it with cauterization in the middle of the head, and cauterization on all parts of the crown, and cauterization on the three following parts of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	However, if you need for the mollification of the body in many of these, and the weak endures it, and the disease is strong: then cauterize it with four cauterizations on the back of the neck, and the last with cauterization, until it burns from the most of its cuticle, and tear off your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then take care of it until it heals: and then apply olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	Epilepsy is not cauterized unless it is of phlegmatic nature.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary to clean the brain of its head with iodine first, and then with the remaining care that we have mentioned in division, when the head is large or endures the reception of drugs.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	However, if the child is who does not tolerate drugs, then a gargle and mouth wash are given to clean the brain before many days with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then gently rub the head of it, then cauterize it with a single cauterization in the middle of the head, according to the method that precedes: and with another cauterization on the back of its head, and over all parts of the crown of his own cauterization.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the weak is strong and endures it, then cauterize it with the cauterizations that we have said in having paralysis and mollification of the body on the back of the neck, and on the back of the neck: and the olive oil cauterization according to the method that precedes.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If then the boy is feeble, place a fine cauterium in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	In the method of cauterization in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupt humors and a thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries we mentioned for paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is superfluous descents into melancholy, and the body is a wet one, then give it power to cleanse its brain according to what precedes in division, and then scrape the wet head, and afterwards make a decent linen bandage like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it on the middle of the head: and the feeble one sitting squarely is held by all parts.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more befitting from ancient honey.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it with gentle fire temperature, according to the size that the finger can tolerate when it is introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of its head in a circle, and let it go until it is saturated.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the feeble one once a week when the remaining good regimen of it is ended, until it is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you will, cauterize it by making small points in it as much as possible, except that you hold your hand with the cauterium: indeed it is pleasant-smelling.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this species of cauterization humidifies the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it the drinked-up butter or goose fat on top.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	¶ In the method of cauterization in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water is declared in the eye by the signs I have mentioned in division, then begin to drink the weak one, with that which cleanses its head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard it from all moistures, and make it sit in the bath for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to shave his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him twice over two intervals, if the descent of water is delayed in both eyes at once: or from the side, if the descent of water is delayed in one eye: and cut away all the eyelids and arteries that are under the cheek, and let the cauteries be long in breadth: and guard against the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	That is, if you see something from it, then cut it away immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will repeat with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and guarding against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized in the scalp, under two bones, with the last two cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ About the method of cauterizing in the ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Head XIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the ancient tears of the eyes are frequent and are above the eyelids and the arteries that are in the manifest cheek outside, it is believed that this is due to excessive cold and phlegmatic humors: then cauterize with the same cauterization that I will describe in the delay of the descent of water, with the cauterization in the middle of the head, and two cauterizations over two intervals, and two cauterizations in the scalp under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need additional help, then cauterize it all around the eye, on the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	The method of cauterization in a putrid nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that, when you have divided it as we said in division, and the medication does not fit: then immediately, and give to a weak man three nights' rest, and then shave the head of that person, and cauterize it with the middle part of an olive.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the cauterization on two sides of the eye, above two eyebrows under the short hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And keep away from the artery, so as not to inflame it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of Clauilis cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	The method of cauterization in the softening of the eyelids.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid is softened by disease or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with a single cauterization, with this cauterization of the moon.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above two eyebrows with two cauterizations in all parts: and they will lengthen by two times: and the length of the cauterization should be according to the length of the eyebrows: and do not finally extend your hand with the cauterization, but according to the amount that becomes third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cauterization according to this method of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	The method of cauterizing the eyelid when the eyebrows become prickly and painful.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either with fire, or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cauterization with fire, order the weak man to go before that, so that he may let go of his hairs, if any of them are covered by them, until they become long and grow again.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they prick him at his own point: then bind his eyes with a thread, so that they may not move, until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and open their eyes, then place the weak head in your side: then make signs on the eyelids of his eyes with a burning iron, according to the figure of the myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a drunken whey on the white part of the eye: or on the silky mucus over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then make a cauterization, whose form is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize on the figure which you have gradually made in many eyes, until the surface of the skin is completely burned, as the figure of the myrtle leaf appears truly.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your healing work is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted, and the hair shaved at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then shave your hand, and release it three days later.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place on it a whey with honey, until the scar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment, until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair remains after the hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cauterization on that place, as you have done at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If the hair is at the bottom: then cauterize it itself, until it grows to its natural place: and let it be as if it does not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	¶ About the method of cauterizing when the fire is burning in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Head 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is as if you were making the patient weak, so that he may let go of the hair, until they grow and appear.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	The shape of the myrtle leaf from a paper sheet.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from soap known, and from a shoe not saturated, one pound of weight, or almost that: then grind it all at once with good contrition, and make it with haste, so that it does not fail.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the dough that you made as the shape of the myrtle leaf, and place it directly on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a dampened wool, in the albumen: and let the weak head be in your groove.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger over the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And move it as often as you feel the weak tingling of the medicine, because its tingling is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While he persisted with this that he found the tingling, then let go of the medicine, and press it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the tingling is at rest, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider if you see the eyelid rising, as it rises with the contraction like fire, or with incision, it is well: and if not, then try again over it from the medicine at that place, where the medicine does not press, and does not deny, until your operation is equal, and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place over it the wool with butter, until the fire-scarred skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of diaphoric unguent, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you at the operation, to keep the last care, lest something from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if the eyelid is softened after a day, and something from the hair clings to the eye, then try the medicine again over that place which you softened with the eyelid properly, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it itself, until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you know that the eyes of humans are diversified in size and proportion.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, your consideration is: and not hidden is the desire for the rightness of that, which is sought in this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	¶ About the method of cauterization in the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Head 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating the tear duct fistula, when as we said in the division of diseases, and your treatment does not agree with it: then, it is necessary for you to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Please advise the patient to place his head in your groove, and hold his head with his own hand in this way, so that it does not move, nor does he move with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place the infused cork in the eye socket, or in the siliceous ointment on the eye of the patient: then heat the cauterization, whose form is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be thick, as the form of a feather of a quill wants, with which the cauterization is made: and if you want it to pass through to the other end, and if you want it to rise thus, try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	Nevertheless, this thickness is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and take out from it healthy matter, and scrape it: and if it is not open, then open it, and take out the pus of it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place on it then the cauterization that is made hot gently.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it with your hand as much as possible near the cauterization between the eye and the nose, so that your hand does not slip, or the weak one is disturbed: and place the cauterization in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If then you are careful at the beginning of Cauterization from the beginning to the mouth, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then do Cauterization once, or twice, if you need that: and let that be three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put on the poultice with honey, and care for it with the dried ointment until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If however more than forty days have passed and it does not heal: then put on top of it sharp medicine for the corrosive ulcer, until the mouth is exposed: and rase it according to what comes in the chapter of it.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another way of Cauterization fistula, which some at first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Understand to the place of the fistula, and find it: then put in the same fissure of the skin with a thin needle, that is, a thin cannula whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour in it the quantity of a drachm of lead melted, and hold your hand with a good retention of the needle, and do not tremble at all so that it does not run, or drip the melted lead to the eye of it.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you put on top of the weak eye a poultice soaked in almond milk or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For the lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it by a miraculous cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with what we said from Cauterization and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to make a nostril opening and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what it wants in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ About the way of Cauterization in the fissures of the Lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter Twenty.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many times, fissures in the lip are called "pilus," and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures, when you consider what we have said about the division of diseases, and the treatment does not heal, then a small cauterization knife, in this shape, should be used.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its cure should be according to the sharpness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the hot knife quickly into the fissures, until the cauterization reaches the deep fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the heat, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	¶ Method of cauterization in the mouth fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter Twenty-One.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs in the root of the gums, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts: afterwards, it becomes suppurated and the pus runs and forms a fistula: then care for it and its treatment does not heal, then it is necessary to use hot cauterization according to the amount that is taken in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the hot knife into the fistula opening and hold your hand, until the heated knife reaches the deep part of it and its end: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it after that, until it heals according to what we have said about the treatment.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If then the pus is cut off and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place and remove the rotten bone according to what does not want to grow in its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	¶ Method of cauterization in the gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Head XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the ginger is softened due to moisture, and the teeth are moved, and it is treated with medicines, and does not fuse: then place the weak head in your side seam.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then make a cauterization of the form which will become soft after this, so that you can place the cannula on the tooth: and quickly insert the heated cauterization into it: and hold your hand for a moment, until the weak tooth feels that the heat has passed to the root.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And scrape your hand: then repeat the cauterization as many times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then fill the weak mouth with salt water, and hold it for an hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened, and the softened ginger is held together, and the moisture is dried out.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	¶ About the method of cauterization in tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Head XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the tooth pain is due to coldness, or there is coldness in the tooth itself, or it is frozen, and the treatment does not heal with medicines: then the cauterization is in the tooth itself in two ways: either with honey, or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	However, the cauterization of it with honey is as follows: take honey in a mortar and mix it with vinegar, and heat it in a lead pot, or in a pan.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a piece of wax, and apply it to the end of the tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in the heated vinegar: and place it quickly on the painful tooth, and hold it for a moment until it strengthens: then repeat it several times until the heat of fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If you wish, immerse a thread or a piece of cloth in cold butter, and place it directly on the tooth that is aching: then place a heated iron on top, until the heat reaches the depth of the tooth's root.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	However, when the heat is applied to it, as you would to a copper or iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And there should be some bulkiness in the body of the tooth, so that the heat of the iron does not penetrate the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then apply the cauterization, whose form is to be avoided: and place it directly on the tooth: and hold your hand there, until the cauterization has hardened.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be relieved, either on the same day or on another.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary for the impression of that cauterization to fill the weak bone of the tooth, and hold it for an hour: then withdraw it.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cauterization.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Apply the cauterization wherever you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	¶ About the method of cauterization in Strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the Strophuli are cold and wet, and are not easily digested by means of drugs, and you wish to digest them quickly, then apply the cauterization with this form:
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that the smoke can pass between the cauterization and the other end: and place the heated cauterization on top of the gum, and then, if necessary, twice, until the heat reaches the depth of the gum.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the gum is small: then place the cauterization according to the size of the gum.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Afterwards, release him for three days, and place a cloth soaked in butter over the wound, until the burned part is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with toothpaste, until the form of the cannula heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ Method of cauterization in rancid oil and congestion of cold.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moisture is removed from the lung tubes, and especially when it is with cold complexion, then it is necessary for the weak to be emptied first with the help of soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.
