Then cauterize it in the throat at the root of the gullet in a depressed groove: and be careful not to cause ulcers with cauterization to the gullet, nor in the skin, unless some of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cauterization at the joint of the neck at its end to the spine of it: and let the cauterization be a clasp according to the way which precedes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which precedes, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	¶ Method of cauterization in lung diseases and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and lung disease are caused by cold moisture, and the weak does not have a fever, nor phthisis, nor old age: then cauterize it with two cauterizations above the girdle in depressed and loose, wet places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And let another cauterization be made in the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and let the cauterization be a cannula according to the way which precedes.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish your cauterization to be piercing with the cauterization called Punctum, which has the form that precedes in the pain of the ear: and let the piercings be from thirty to almost another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then, take care of it yourself with what has gone before, until it heals.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now the cauterization has three branches, according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why is the cauterization supposed to be done at the same time as the one you are doing with your finger, when you do three Cauterias?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	¶ In the method of cauterizing in the elbow, in the case of a dislocated shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the thumb is dislocated due to moisture and does not show in the hour of its return to its place, until it becomes used to the return, then it should be dislocated by a small movement, as we have already mentioned, and then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then, the weak one is raised up on its back or over the sound side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then, raise the skin that is in the inner part of the elbow with the fingers of your left hand and if the dislocation is jointed to the inner part.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then, the cauterization having two vertices is lit.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its form is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then, the cauterization should be applied to the skin until it penetrates it to the other side and the figure of the cauterization with four cauteries becomes smooth.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes a cauterization is made with a cauterization having three vertices, and then the figure of the cauterization becomes six times larger, and they are vertices according to their fineness.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the cauterization having three vertices.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added to this mode, and then there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then, place over the cauterization the contracted thighs with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then, make the weak one calm down so that the member does not tremble at any time until it is strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	If the dislocation is to the upper part, and this happens rarely, then cauterize it directly on the shoulder with a cauterizing iron, or by multiple cauterizations with a cauterizing instrument.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	The joint is strengthened, and moisture is removed: the weak one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the stomach:
Caput XXVIII.	Head 25.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When there occurs in the stomach cold and much moisture, until it is extracted from its case, and many catarri are poured on it, and constant methods of treatment are applied, and it does not confer: then it is necessary for the weak one to be placed on the back of its own shoulder, and its legs to be extended, and its hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, with a cauterizing iron of the size of a single finger's tip under the cochlear pectoris, and two cauteries below on the two sides of the first cauterization, until the figure of the cauterizations becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And stretch them apart between each other, when they form pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be that of two thirds of the skin's thickness.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the figure of the cauterizations should be according to this shape without addition: and if you want to cauterize with a large cauterizing iron in the middle of the stomach according to this shape, then the cauterization should be one according to the figure of a circle according to this shape.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by piercing it with a point that is feared from this cauterization: and it is, that signs on the stomach are made according to the quantity that you want to use when you encaustro: then the stomach is cauterized with the point of the cauterization: then care for it with the care that precedes until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the manner of cauterization of cold iron.
Caput XXIX.	Head XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When a pain occurs in the knee from coldness and moisture, or from gross excrement, until it escapes from its natural complexion, and the weak is treated with what I said, and does not progress in that: then it should be cut off above the cauterization, and three lines of cauterization according to this figure, and the same quantity below the knee, where the urine exudes from the human thigh: and there should be a space between every cauterization according to the size of the finger: and the cauterization should be according to the length of the body: and do not press your hand with the cauterization much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And the quantity that is burned from the thickness of the skin does not add to its median part: and the weak stands upright on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	However, if it is not standing, then it should be lying down, who has already extended his legs and has raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of cauterization.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you to cauterize this cauterization with a sharp and skilled knife, when you have subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take care not to ultimately proceed in cauterization, and the thickness of the skin is burned throughout, because the whole body is burned, and it exudes into the intestine: for the skin is there thin, so you know that.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the manner of cauterization of the Epaplaxis.
Caput XXX.	Head XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an exit occurs, and you want to know if it is an abscess of the flesh of the knee or of its covering: then if it is in the flesh of the knee, it pains the weak with cold and dullness without acuity: and if it is in the covering of the knee, when there is pain, there is sharp heat without dullness: and you see now that the doctors of this patient have exhausted their strength in its cure.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It must then be that the weak one lies down on his own bandage.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then, the figure of the place with wax: then the burnt cauterization that is similar to the edge.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And it cauterizes with that cauterization one until the whole skin burns, and then seeps into the siphon, until all the sweat flows out: then care itself is cured by its own healing.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it should not be used in this way of cauterization unless the student's desire in the art of medicine is prolonged: and for whose hands are present such afflictions with experiment: then should he dare upon such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But at his releasing it, I find better here.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	¶ About the method of cauterization in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Caput XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that the cauterization with the roots of Aristolochia to pleurisy cold was made in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is that you receive from the dry long roots of Aristolochia one longer root, which is found in it, and it is like the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with the cauterization one in it that is between the continuity of the knee with the neck, and two cauterizations parius under the guidezi with little declivities to the part which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauterizations also in it that is between the fifth and sixth ribs to the posterior almost: and one cauterization in the middle of the chest, and one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauterizations from the back: one in it that is between two spoons: and two cauterizations from the two sides of the chest, lower cauterization that is between two spoons.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	It does not become you to hold your hand with the cauteries, rather it should be clear smelling skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	Some ancient ones have said that out of humans who use cauteries made from similar metal rays: and they burn them, and thrust them inside the belly, until it comes to the apostema, and issues forth with pus, as we say in the apostema of Epagathus.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this puncture with the cauteries there is fear, that either a weak one dies immediately, or it happens in the place of the fistula, which is not cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	¶ About the way of cauterizing the Liver Head, XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating the sickness of the liver, when it is not the cure that is causing division among the diseases, then the cauterization is on it in three ways, which are all correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of which one is, that you make three cauterizations, or four, by lineing according to the length of the liver according to the figure of the cauteries of Epagathus, which precedes the figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And it should be between all the cauterization the quantity of the finger size, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And it should be the method of the cauterization that we say in the cauterization of Epagathus equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not hold your hand with the cauteries: and it should be a weak one hanging over the back of its own.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of the cauterization is: that the cauterization having two flames, which we say in the chapter of dislocation of the shoulder: and burn the skin which is in direct to the liver, where the weak side of the thigh falls: and your eleua should be such that the eleuation of the skin according to the length of the body, so that the cauterizations fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two blazing hot wires into the skin from opposite sides until they penetrate to the other side. Then extract the caustic: thus four caustics are formed.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a different caustic, use three wires.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the caustic after you have released it to emit pus over many days: for it more rapidly concurs with the following remedies of the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	¶ The method of cauterization in Hydrocephalus.
Caput XXXIII.	Head XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The caustic does not fall in Hydrocephalus, unless it is properly bitten.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are curing Hydrocephalus with the methods of cure that we mentioned in the division, and it does not concur with the cure, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four caustics around the umbilicus, and one caustic over the stomach, one caustic over the liver, one caustic over the spleen, and two caustics post dorsum between the spines, one in directo pectoris, and another in directo stomachi: and the depth of the caustic should be near to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then release the open caustic so that it emits pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not release the weakness from the cure after the caustic, because it is necessary that two intentions gather to it: and it will hasten to the healing with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the caustic with which the belly is cauterized should be a plug: according to which form precedes it: and its form with which the back is cauterized should be an ointment according to which form precedes it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	¶ The method of cauterization of the feet and limbs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XLII.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they are about to be baptized in the hydriatic and are replenished with blue water: it is necessary to cauterize on the sole of the foot, which is between the auricula and the annulus: and take your hand with the cauterization, and do not twist it at all: then take your hand again: and do not move it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the blue water to remain, and the cauterization should be in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauterizations on the two thighs, and let the cauterization be at the end of the sword of the cauterization: and let the cauterization be according to the length of the thigh, one under the knee, and one below it, about in the middle of the thigh: and over all the stomach make two cauterizations: and release the open cauterization without long care: so that some water remains from it: then care for it with the others that I have mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	¶ About the method of cauterizing in the solution of the belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XLV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the belly is made from cold and moisture, until the virtuous and digestive powers which are in the stomach and intestines are weakened and relaxed: and it is cured according to the methods of curing, and is not healed: and you see the feeble one enduring the exudation of the virtle powers, then cauterize it with a large cauterization on the stomach itself, according as was done in the cauterization of the belly with the circle-shaped cauterization, and four cauterizations around the navel subtle ones, with a subtle closure cauterization: and the cauterization over the scutum above the eyes or two cauterizations.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see the exudations of moisture, and the feeble one enduring it, then cauterize it with a cauterization on the chest, and with a cauterization on all the thighs: and perhaps add two small cauterizations on the stomach near the great one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	This is indeed a progressive treatment, whose ingredient does not deceive.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	¶ Regarding the method of treating hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Caput XXXVI. (Head XXXVI)
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When hemorrhoids, old or new, single or multiple, are found in the anus, and are caused by humors that are cold, dry, or corrupted with moisture, they should be treated with the same division, and the curative method does not agree: in this case, cauterization should be performed with three cauterizations on the lower back of the spine, just above the ribs, and a cauterization under the navel, as if made with two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that the stomach of this person is cold, and his food does not digest, and you see his face about to bleed, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cauterization, according to what precedes: also cauterize on the spleen, and on another part of the liver, with the cauterization closed: then leave the open cauterization for some time, and then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	¶ Regarding the method of cauterizing an abscess after its formation.
Caput XXXVII.	Caput XXXVII. (Head XXXVII)
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you are about to abscess an abscess, then use a hot cauterization that is similar to the radius.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the hot cauterization into the abscess: and your last hand, until the cauterization reaches the opening of the wound, through which the blood runs: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If then the abscesses are many, then cauterize each one according to what we have mentioned.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it with the ointment that agrees with them, until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	If you cauterize him with great fire over tin, it is more final in the operation.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	The method of cauterizing an anal fistula is...
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the feeble does not submit to the section and operation that we have described in its place, and is afraid of it, it may be cured by cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When a fistula occurs in someone and becomes old, pus runs from it, and the corrupted moistures run out.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore, it is more proper that you should try to open it with gentle trials.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the depth of its penetration when you try.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then heat the cauterization iron that is similar to the ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert yourself, heated, into the fistula and the quantity by which you entered is closed.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cauterization on it until all the corrupted bodies burn, once, twice, or three times, according to the quantity necessary for your case.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And protect yourself from the dryness of the nerve, if it is there, or great vagina: or if the fistula goes to the dry body, or to the dry intestine, then protect yourself from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this unless the fistula is in a dry place: and think that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it is cured.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is closed, and the materials are removed from it, and it remains for a long time: then you know that it has been cured completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not remove the material from it, then you know that it is penetrating, or there is a dry opening in its depth, or something like that: whose remembrance will not be in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	The method of cauterization for the Rhine.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When a pain occurs in the Rhine from cold or from large excrement, and weakness is caused by it, then it is necessary to cauterize it on the almentum over the same renes, with cauterization over all the renees with the same cauterization, whose predecessor is rememoration.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we should cauterize it a second time in the same almentum.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Because three lines appear.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, there will be more in the application.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	The method of cauterization for the vesica.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the vesica from cold and moisture, until the urine does not hold firm, then it is necessary to cauterize it on the inferior part of the thigh over the vesica, where the hairs begin to grow woolly, and from the right thigh and another from the left, and its length according to the quantity of the pollicis nail: and cauterize it with cauterization on the back of the inferior thigh or with two cauterizations if you need that, and it should be according to what precedes the remembrance.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	The method of cauterization for the matriculum.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture occur in the matriculum, which prohibits impregnation, and the menstrua are corrupted, and the excitement of them is delayed, and a pain occurs at their approach, then it is necessary to cauterize it with three cauterizations around the umbilicus, as I said in the cauterization of the vesica, and with cauterization on the lower back of the thigh or with two cauterizations: and it should be according to what precedes the remembrance.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	The method of cauterization of Ancham in case of dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When humidities of the mucous membrane are exuded to the point of Anchae, and cause its exit from its place: and this is the sign which is prolonged above another, when they are compared to be inserted: and the location of the dislocation is found to be in it, when it is empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore, it is necessary to cauterize the weak point on Anchae with a similar circle of cauterization: after you have seen the signs when encausted in the circumference of the mucous membrane, as it revolves: and let it fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauterization be of that form which precedes in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cauterization is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauterizations, with a large olive oil cauterization: and let the depth of the cauterization be according to the thickness of the entire skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	The method of cauterization in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When there is pain in the mucous membrane of Anchae, and the cause is cold and humidity: and the weak one is cared for with that which we said in division, and the treatment does not agree with it, and it becomes old: then it is necessary to dissolve the weak one from the thick fluids with pills bitter or artificial, and such.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	The method of cauterization in this is according to two methods: either with the cauterization and medicines that are applied, or with the cauterization and fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cauterization with fire, is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	When one is, it cauterizes on a piece of the ankle of its three triangular cauterizations, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them a good depth, or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be a space that is between all the cauterization of the quantity of the digit: and it should be an olive-shaped one.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	However, when the cauterization is made in the middle over the head of its ankle.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Why are there four cauterizations?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form precedes in the cauterization of the dislocation of the ankle, one: so that the circle contains the whole ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the density of the skin of the whole.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization in Sciatica, when the pain is adhering to the ankle of its own and does not extend up to the thigh and crus.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	However, if it extends up to the thigh and crus, then cauterize it with two cauterizations over the thigh, over the place where the weak one indicates, in which there is pain, and your cauterization over the callous of four fingers to the part that is slightly slier, and it should be a punch.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be according to the density of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the weak one indicates that the pain extends up to the toes, then cauterize it at the place where the weak one indicates with the point of the cauterization, three or four or more, if it is needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if the weak one indicates that the pain is under the knee, then cauterize it at the place where the weak one indicates with the punch of the cauterization, one.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And be careful in all your cauterization that you do not finally with the cauterization to this that burns the nerves, or a large artery, and draws through it on the weak one, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I have indeed seen one and another of them, among those who cauterized above the knee, and finally in the cauterization, and the leg became inflamed until the tumor followed to the foot, and was completely perforated and corrupted throughout, and then the solution of the fluid occurred, and death followed after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If there is pain in two parts at once, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	Indeed, some wise men have said that in the cauterization of anchaea, this is the method of the cauterization.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar one from iron, whose diameter is the breadth of the palm: and it should be at the orifice of its own according to the size of the nail's nucleus, or less perhaps: and within that iron, make another iron.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there should be a space between all the iron according to the quantity of the pollex node: and they should be open from two parts: and their height should be like a node, or two nodes: and make for them manubria from iron appropriate to the irons.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it should be burned in the fire until it turns red and emits sparks, and then it should be placed on a slightly raised anchaea with an infirm side on a healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, it should be cauterized with three round cauterizations in the ice of one.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then release it for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards, ointment with honey-butter: and release the open gauze for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says that in this kind of cauterization of the anchaea, we have not used it much because of the fear of its appearance, and for that reason, because we have found a few who expect on it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Indeed, it is from good cauterizations that he finds a place for him.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	When the cauterization is made with the medicines that are applied, as you will make two pieces of black leather with holes, in which the door of his porte will descend from the air or iron, and the length of the wall: of whose height there will be two knots, or as if they were themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be space between the two quantities of the thickness of the finger, and they should be open below and above: and it should be that which contains them together, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on a very fine thread, the weak one lying on the healthy side of the abdomen.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And compress your hand on the very fine thread much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of hot water, which is heated with fire almost, and hold it by the time of the hour: and the weak one will endure the mordication of his, and its own burning, for he has found the mordication as if it were fire, until the mordication ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then uncover your hand with the instrument, and take away hot water from the whole of it with sweet water: then release this for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put on top of it butter, until the blackness of the burning is removed: and release it for some days, and the pus will come out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For it is the final in the dressing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the house or couch, or cramp: make for him a statue in it that contains water, according to what you made in the high equal.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way of hot water: and I have already written it in the book of the correction of the physicians.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Sum the alkali and unburned lime, and take part of one: tritiate both, and put them in a new crucible, whose lower part has a single small hole, according to the amount that enters the radius: then put another empty crucible under the first one: and dip both with alkali and lime from sweet water, which submerges them with one finger: then with your good hand compression compress the crucible: and let it go until the sharp lower part of the other crucible descends.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather all that water, and pour it over the other lime: and let it run until it runs out.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be strong and astringent power, which is given in many medical operations and in cauterization of other parts of the body.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it produces the effect of fire on its own.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from medicines there are those which, when they are cauterized widely, and even like this, and melted wax, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed. ¶
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed, in telling about one of the old remedies, by which the patient was cured of the pain of anchylosis and sciatica, and magnified its power.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it was not needed for another treatment, and that it was cured by the water alone, until he mentioned that he may have entered the bath and left it already cured. ¶
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is said that it should be taken from the girl's milk: and if it is not found in the milk, then dried and fresh, and cooked with some fat, and put on the anchylosis, where the pain, or crust, or in the thigh, and lie down, and let it be for three hours, or according to how she feels a weak desiccation. ¶
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then insert it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the abdomen of the body becomes flat, insert it into the belly.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain subsides and he is cured.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that it is not necessary for anyone to use cauterization with these medicines unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that the feces of rabbits, when cauterized with it, is beneficial for the sciatica, and it is made as a cauterization according to this method.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	A piece of wool is given, and it is drunk with old oil, and it is placed on a deep place which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the big toe, and it is nearer to the big toe.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry feces of rabbits, and burn it in the fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it on the wool, and let it out until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then do this again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	You will not stop doing this until the sense is felt over the midriff up to the anus, and the pain stops.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called the Vaccinum cauterization.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	¶ About the cauterization of the back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	¶ Caput XLIII.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When the pain occurs in the back from various causes, or from accident, or from percussion, or evacuation of excessive, and like these, from the infusion of a cold and damp matter, and then cauterization indeed falls, unless it is made in this kind alone, which is made from the infusion of a cold and damp matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after the evacuation of the weak with pills fetid and like them, which are made over the back where the pain is, three lines according to the width of the blistered skin itself, after the signs with encaustic in every line five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity that comes from the tolerance of the weak virtue of its, it should be made cauterization with cauteriopuncti.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish, cauterize three times or four, with the cauterization of the sides, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	In the beginning of the Gibbosite, how to cauterize.
Caput XLV.	Head 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This ailment often happens to infants in childbirth.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its onset in children is: that which happens above it, stricture in anguish at the time of evacuation, and motion; and I found in the last vertebra of the back and nodes of his, which has already begun to emerge over the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this, and you want to do this, then cauterize it with the cauterization that is a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And take the cauterization over all parts of the vertebra equally: and if you wish to cauterize in the circumference of the vertebra with the cauterization of a point, two lines, or three: and let the points be near the incoming.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place until it heals with what I said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, do not give the cauterization in the Gibbosite that is made in the spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	In the method of cauterizing in Podagra, and the pain of the joints.
Caput XLVI.	Head 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pain of the joints is from cold humors that are poured on any part of the body, then when the pain occurs in the feet, it is according to the custom of the physicians to call this Podagra properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When Podagra is treated with the cold causes of the treatment and do not move the pain, then the cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is that the cauterization of it after the evacuation in the circumference of the joints of the feet, with many cauterizations, and let the cauterization be Olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is the form of it.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to mark points on the face of the foot, then make marks with the cauter.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If pain goes up to the knees or other joints, and this happens often, then cauterize the whole knee with three or four cauteries from all sides, and close it with the same cauter.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	But if you need more of this cauterization, then cauterize the whole thing.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cauter, but rather it is the thickness of the skin that matters.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If pain goes up to the knees and back, then apply what I said from the cauter section.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If pain is only in the hands, then make marks in the surrounding area of the foci, just like the two lines that rotate.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If pain remains in the fingers, then make marks on all the nodes of the finger and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pain goes up to the elbows or shoulders after a few days, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not let the weakness be cured by poor management or the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen is made, and the phlegm is cured, it will be healed by the help of God with this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	¶ About the method of cauterization in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Head 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groins, and the intestine descends, or the cecum to the testicle, and this is the beginning of the proximate one, then it is necessary to let the weak eat less on the day of the meal.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And use what is gentle, by which the feces come down from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then seat yourself between his hands on his back: and tell him to hold his breath until he goes out, or shows signs of passing out, or reveals an intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce him with your fingers, and signs with the flame under the rupture on the ears of the tendons, with a sign whose extremity is similar to the half of the circle in the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then apply the cauterization, whose form is this, until it turns yellow, and pours out sweat.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or the abdomen to its natural state.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then place his hand on the place so that it does not leave the intestine: and you have already exposed the weak legs, and placed under them a pillow, and placed another under his chest, which holds his hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cauterization over it, with your hand with the cauterization standing straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him, until when you have found the mouth with it: or go with another one if you did not find it in the first place up to the mouth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And observe carefully from the exit of the intestine in the hour of your cauterization, so as not to burn it, and may you find by this on the weak or death, or great malice.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not find with the cauterization the mouth, your operation does not succeed.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterization of children be fine, according to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care with the rest of the ointments until it heals.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let him lie weak on his back for forty days, until the wound is stitched.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you place the food of his length of time of healing, which soothes his belly: so that the intestine does not leave the anus and the excretion.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	When you wish to rise after forty days, then administer the ligature in such a way that it is properly made, and hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And it will be lessened by labor, and by an abundance of food and drink, and loud shouting.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this regimen is used, the healing is accomplished through complete health.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I say that the treatment of ruptures with incision is in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however ruptures occur in the other vent, and they are beginning, and you do not wish them to be added, then cauterize the rupture with a round cauterization according to its quantity: and this that hardens from then shall be as the third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then take care of it, according to what we have said: and it will not be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some have already said that the first: to cauterize the rupture with a triangular cauterization, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is burned with pitch, and a line is put which is along the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another one downward.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cauterization closed.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the cauterization is first easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	¶ About the method of cauterizing in pain because of the wound, or the blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Caput XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in some members by the wound, or the blow: and he has endured the pain for a long time, and does not consent to the cure with the medicines: then it is necessary that he be cauterized with the point cauterization.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the cauterization shall be a cauterization of all members according to its magnitude, and its parity, and its weakness, and its virtue, and its location of torsion, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If then the wound is cured by cauterization first, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat over the cauterization.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For because of the custom of these pains, they are changed from a member to that which is nearest to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary to follow them with cauterization until the weak one is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	¶ About the method of cauterization in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	However, when leprosy is treated with cauterization, it is done with the maximum cauterization.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy that is made due to putridity of the phlegmatic and melancholic, when you consider to cauterize it,
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If then leprosy is causing it, and you have treated it as we said in the division, and it has not gone down, nor seems to be: and you fear for the weak one who comprehends corruption over the whole complexion of it, then cauterize him on the head with five cauterizations: one in the middle of the head, and another below the front, at the end of the hair, and two above the two points, and one below the nail.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And then your hand with cauterization almost, until the small impression is printed in the mouth, and the cortices are dislocated from it: so that the expiration of the gross vapors from it may be driven out, and cauterize also on the spleen, according as it precedes.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	However, if leprosy has already spread over the weak one and appears clearly: then it is necessary to cauterize with the cauterizations we said on the head, and on the end of the nose, and two on the two maxillae, and two on the two spines of the neck, and six on the spine of the back, and one large on the ankles of the great tail and one above it, in the very ankle: and two on the thighs: one on all the thigh, and two on the knees, and two on the elbows, and two on the tendons of the chest of his: and cauterize him over all the joints, from the joints of the fingers of his hands, and feet: and cauterize on all the heel of his foot, and the soles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And so for your heels, which are above the last bone of the foot, that you may not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when the cauterization is made on the cheek with cauterization over the stomach and over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you know that the more you add to the cauterization, the more fuel it is and the more it yields.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the weak do not find pain in cauterization as the healthy do, because the body of this one is already stunned.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it should be that the cauterization is according to its size and weakness according to the limbs and seams: according to what precedes from the kinds of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cauterization with flour of a plant and honey, and the rest of the care until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	¶ In the method of cauterization in stupor.
Caput L.	Head L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a limb is stunned and it is treated with medicines, oils, plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize the stunned limb with cauteries according to the size of the member or its weakness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And your cauterization should be deep into the thickness of the skin, almost.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when it is cauterized to a certain stupor that happens to the hand and foot, and to the spine at the exit of the nerves that move that member: and the stupor is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	Indeed, it should not be presumed on that unless he who is wise in the anatomy of the members, and the exit of the nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	¶ In the method of cauterization in alba.
Caput LI.	Head LXI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras becomes ancient and contains nothing from the arts of medicine: then cauterize over the deep cauterization almost, according to the degree of skin fullness until it becomes white and changes its color.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with flour of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossae, and blood of the dove, and blood of the gnat: each of these is one part: mix them all together and they will stick to the cloth and remain in place until healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	¶ On the method of cauterization in cancer.
Caput LII.	Head LXIIR.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning and you wish to hold it: then cauterize it with a circular cauterization around it, just as it rotates.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	However, the wise have said that it should be cauterized with the last cauterization in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	However, I do not see that: for I fear that it will ulcerate, and I have already seen that several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we have said, or with many cauterizations.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	¶ On the method of cauterization in abscesses.
Caput LIII.	Head LXXIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess and it is slow to mature, or because of the excessive formation of it, or because of the weakness of age, when there are few drops of blood, or because of time, and you wish to hasten the maturation of the abscess: then cauterize around it with many small cauterizations.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then release it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If then you wish to make a puncture with cauterization, then with this cauterization, which is of this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin: and let it be a cauterization from that which follows weakly, so that the course may be clean.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	¶ Method of cauterization in corroding matter.
Caput LIIII.	Head LIV. (Note: This seems to be a reference to the size or weight of the head, but without additional context, it's difficult to provide a precise translation.)
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	Corrosion is not except for the decay in the walking member, and it corrodes itself: just as fire eats dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If then you see the corroding in the place which can tolerate cauterization with fire, then with fire cauterization many, small and large closures, according to what suits that place where the decay is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you erase the total decay, and nothing remains of it deeply.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then release it for three days, and put over the cauterized places ground sulfur with oil, until all eschars are eradicated, and all decay is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then take care of it with the ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If then you see that after three days healthy flesh is generated without decay, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization over that which remains from the places of decay.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the corroding is sometimes treated with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	Indeed, it rises from the place of cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Nevertheless, the cauterization with fire is more favorable to the operation: and I myself have already said that the cauterization of it with sharp medicine in division: take it therefore when you need it here.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	In a manner of cauterization in cases of boils and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This affliction often occurs in the lower parts of the feet: it is a large, filtered wart that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there is indeed a cauterization for these in two ways: one with fire, and the other with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	However, when it is with fire, it is like a pen made of hot coals: it is made from iron, according to the quantity that it contains closed on all sides: and it should have a fine edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the hot iron on the closed part.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then roll the hand with the cauterization around the closed part, until the cauterization penetrates to the depth of the closure: and let it remain for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply the plaster with thinned ointment, made rough with salt: and let it be placed on top of it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with the generated skin ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they do not heal, and many of them occur on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then apply the cauterization with hot water to them: and it is like taking a cannula from air, or iron, or from a hard pen: and place it on the closed part, or a thick one.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then draw out a little of the hot water from the cannula: keep your hand, and roll it with the compression of your hand, so that it impresses the edge of the cannula on the closed part, and it finds warm water to the depth, to the closure: and it will be weak for a short time after the application of hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for the tumor will be removed along with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do it with one after another, until all those that come from them are in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they have been removed, with the ointment that generates flesh from the skin.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	¶ Method of Cauterization in Tremors.
Caput LVI.	Head 66.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to someone that there is a tremor from cold in the nerve, or from the quartan fever, or otherwise: then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries, or five on the back of the spine, and over all the spine, and in the chest of the one who is cauterized, and over the stomach of the one who is cauterized.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	Indeed, the tremor ceases with the olive oil cauterization, and hastens the health of the cold disease.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	¶ Method of Cauterization for Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Head 67.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes, the filthy materials that are corrupted are expelled from the body of Albathir, that is, the pustules which are formed.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.
