If you see that it is being burned and cut, and imprinting on it, then distill from your hour into the eye from the saline made from a pig's bladder, or from red saline, or from crushed salt: and moisten the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat on the same operation until the whole of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is something different for you in the eye, hot apostema: then release it and treat the apostema until it becomes healthy.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then perform the operation again on the same part with its respective reasoning, until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	However, the tear duct of the eye, if it causes harm to the eye in a great manner, should be suspended with a safety pin, and an incision should be made from that part of it: and not ultimately the incision, so as not to cause the flow of tears.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then a small piece of red cotton or made from hazelnut, should be placed in the eye until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	¶ About the Alguardenic incision, and the flesh made in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes a red flesh is made or placed in certain eyes of men, until it covers the pupil, or approaches it, or draws it up over the eyelids, and perhaps turns the eyelids outside: and resembles the rose of balsam.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation is also done, so that the weak head of your own may be placed in your groove.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open the eyes of those, and close that entire flesh with appropriate safety pins to that: and hold it with one hand, or grasp it.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then make an incision in the flesh at first, until the whole of it is finished with the incisor.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And be careful not to hurt the eye with your operation: and let your incision be the one you make, or with sandpaper that we have mentioned in the cutting of the toe: or with needles, according to which form you wish for it after this cluster.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is completed and the entire Alguardenic removed, then fill the eye with ground salt: or distill some red paint, and similar to that from medicines corrosive: and place a piece of cotton over the deformed eye with glass: so that it may be secure from hot apostemates.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If there remains from other wounds something, and the hot blood dominates over you, and you fear the hot apoplexy: then let go of the eye, and care for it with that which soothes the apoplexy.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then you will repeat over it with the operation until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And similarly, make with the flesh added that happens in the eye from this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that all weak eyes from one kind of nature or from another accidental kind be cured by operating with iron: and you do not thrust your hand into any of these operations until you see that this member is enduring that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	¶ Regarding the collection of sebum from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Sebum is red and is woven over the eye, and prevents its own operation: and weakens the eye with the length of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore, it is necessary for you at first to see if the eye in which there is sebum is strong, and there is no sickness in it except for the sebum: then collect the sebum of that eye.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is good to prioritize the weak one, so that its head is placed in your groin.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those eyelids with a single or two hairs according to your prudence: and the hair should be a fine doubling of this form, or be two hairs that are graduated in the body one, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect those eyelids with fine threads, and wipe the blood hour after hour until you see that these eyelids are withdrawn from the eye, and they become: and be careful not to hurt the eye with the extremities of salt water.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And your operation should be in the midday sun, and you should be firm in your operation: so that you do not fall except for those eyelids.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	When you have completed your application, then distill it into the eye of the affected area, or red: so that its sharpness may consume what remains in itself.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If however it is not possible for you to gather the whole of it at that time, then apply a plaster to the eye with it, which soothes the pain of the eye: and leave it on for some days, until the pain of the wound settles down: and protect it from hot applications: and then repeat over it in the same manner, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the thorn.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Regarding the reduction of Arsenius to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The physicians named Arsenius the fistula, which they treat with cauterization, or with burning medicine, according to what is stated in the following narrative.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no wisdom in it: unless you find on the surface of the wound, and outside, all the moisture that is in it and the pus, until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is exposed, and you see corruption or blackness in it, then scrape it off with the instrument whose form is this.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the scrapping of the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron, and let its head be round like an azir, which is punctuated with a fine line of the lancet, or with a fine line of the chisel: and place it on top of the place of the corrupted bones.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll it between your fingers, and press your hand slightly, until you know that the corruption has been scraped off: and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with the dried medicinal ointments.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If then the wound is healed and flesh has been formed, and the discharge of pus ceases: and if, after forty days, it remains unaltered, unopened, without suppuration, and no accident befalling it occurs: then you know that it is cured.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no genius in it, unless the fistula be reduced to the nostril, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is that you remove from the bone either with a hammer or with sharp medicine: and when you have found the bone, then take the wedge according to this form, it should be at the end of the iron, triangular: and the wood of it should be a pyramid diminished to its end, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place this over the bone itself: and it should be near the tear-ditch: and extend your hand a little from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then roll your hand with the wedge, until it penetrates the bone, and feels weak: by this you will find the air to escape from it, when you hold your hand over your own nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore, then restore the place with stupefying ointments, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When then flesh is formed and the wound hardens: then the matter that was poured out to the outside returns to the nose: it is therefore weaker above the weak part.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	¶ On the reduction of the prominence of the Eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye projects with all its bulk, and no harm occurs in use, nor diminution: then it is necessary to loosen the weak part: then make a bloodlet at that place: afterwards put on wet dressings without scalding, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then place over the eye a liniment made from acacia, and aloe, and olibanum, and sarsaparilla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then tie the eye up with the plaster made with many mustard seeds.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the method of mustard seeds is: take many thin linen cloths, and double each one four times over; make many of them according to the size of the eye; then place them one on top of another according to the amount needed for the eye; then tie them together with a strong cloth bandage.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat the waters without scarring with suction.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then take away the waters, and release the tied-up eye both day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	But if the bandage is again softened, then it should be tied up very tightly; then take away the bandage the following day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If you see the eye already dressed with clean linen, that is good; and if not, then repeat the plaster, the mustard seeds, the tied-up eye, and the waters until it is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	¶ About the cutting of the king's linen.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When the linen of the eye is torn, then it should be mended and go out beyond the eyelids like the grain of wheat, and spoil the appearance of man because of this, and it may insert itself: then the operation is done in it as I will tell you: and it is like this: that you thrust an acumen into the root of the linen from the lower part to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then thrust another acumen into it where the thread is doubled from the watery part, and make it pierce: and release the first according to its own position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then let the thread be inserted at the place of the doubled one, and tie it with that part of the linen around the acumen: and tie it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the eye socket and place a piece of infused linen over it on the alveolus of the eye: and release it, until the thread falls with the king.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the eye with it, so that it strengthens it, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the thread is tied around all parts with a circle from linen, until it adds great prominence to the eye.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then let it be washed with fine sand, which reaches the depth of the eye, and moistens the alveolus, and the eye comes down, and enters immediately: then tie it up, until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	¶ About the cure of Alcomnati.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease called Alcomnati is not, except for pus, which is gathered in the eye, similar to descending water, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the mode of operating in it is, as you make the weak sit on a prepared or directed seat.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take the head of it with your hands from two parts, and move it, until you see healthy wounds to heal the lower eyes of yours.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it is shaped and does not go down, and the light is released: and the weak sees as he saw: and if it does not go down below, you know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if it is not prepared for the descent of pus with it, which I said, then make the weak sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take fine sand, and find with it above the thin lining of the cornea at the end of the conjunctiva with the corneal layer, until the pus comes down.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And when it comes out, then pour hot water into the eye in which you mixed honey: or water in which you have already boiled Greek must and honey: then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	On the treatment of water that has descended into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	I have already mentioned the types of water in division, and which are suitable for making a hole in the speech, declare and explain them, then take this same according to its health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then it is necessary that you make the infirm sit with his feet square between your hands, opposite to the light, near the sun: and tie the sound eye of him, and pull it gently: then pull the eyelid of his eye with your right hand, if the eye from which the water comes is the left: or with your left hand, if the eye is on the right side.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take your right hand with a cloth, if the eye is on the left: or with your left hand, if the eye is on the right side.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the edge of the cloth near the corona by the size of the radius in the white eye apparent lachrymal of lesser: then pull the cloth with force: and you will roll your hand with it, until it penetrates into the vitreous humor of the eye: and you will feel that the cloth is already wet to the work.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measurement of the cloth be to the depth, the space which is from the pupil to the end of the black part: and it is the corona of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see it in the same pupil vision of the eye, because of the clarity of the corneal layer.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the cloth up to the place where the water is.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press it down with your finger one after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If then the water comes down immediately, then the infirm will see this above what it opens its own eye at once, and the cloth in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then you will rest for a short time.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If then water descends, then place it secondly, excluding that it goes to the dung.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When then it is made and does not rise: then take out the dung with ease: and you turn your hand slightly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something in water from clear-eyed stone gem: and wash the eye with it when exhausted.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place all the plaster around the eye, or infused wool with rose oil, and clear eye: and tie the healthy eye to it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and they who are of our time, place over him ground almond with rose oil.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	What if it does not submit to you the dung for entry into the eye because of its hardness, since it is from a man whose eye is hard: then it is necessary that you take Alberid soap, which is called, because of this form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore, with it, when you are connected to it alone, and not finally with your hand in the hole: and there is no other than to make a light to the subtle dung place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the dung, according to what we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the end of the work, prepare an infirm sleeping bed, in which he sleeps on his back in the dark house: and forbid all movements and cries: and place the food of him that lenients its nature: and it will not turn its head to the right or left.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the bandage be according to its own arrangement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then dissolve it in that dark house, and try his sight: and make him see that thing.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament up to the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it should not be done at the time of treatment, or immediately after the incision: rather, it should be left to itself, because water rises quickly through a vigorous aspect.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If, however, an inflammation of the eye occurs: then it is necessary to reduce the eye before the seventh day: and then correct that with what soothes the inflammation until it is sated, then remove the same humor from his mouth, and place over his face which is being treated with that humor for those days which are necessary in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then he should gradually leave the house and be cured in his own cases.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And you know that the student is not excused from sighting a few times in salve: for then he dares to oversee the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And already some of them have come to us who are from Al-Layrach, who said that it was made in Al-Layrach with a perforation, through which water is thought to pass.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Indeed I do not know anyone in your land who made this: nor have I read it in any of the ancient books: and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of species as they stand on them, which one who knows them does not know.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of proper air: and their extremities should be with this same fine triangular shape, and an acute angle.
Formae magda.	Species of magda.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	§ About the care of the flesh-born in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When sometimes these flesh-born are born in the nose, there is something in them which resembles the scorpion of many feet: and from this comes cancerous flesh, lard, and white flesh: and from this comes the soft flesh, not white.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In this, therefore, the soft, non-deceptive, and cancer-free part of these flesh, you should have the weak sit down between your hands facing away, open its nostrils, and pull out the hair from these parts: then take them to the outside, and cut what you have grasped with the soft and sharp foam from one side, until you know that the entire flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains of that from which removal is not possible: then rub that with one of the soft tools with facility, until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If, however, blood dominates over you, or a hot blister occurs: then place it opposite as is appropriate: if it is from the bad blisters, then cauterize it immediately, until the blood is removed, and all the flesh is taken away.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then it should be pushed into the nose after cutting, with vinegar and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose opens, and moisture proceeds from it up to the tongue, then you know that it is now healthy.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If, however, the moisture does not penetrate, according to what is appropriate, then you know that there is flesh inside the upper bones of the nose, which does not become wet with the cutting instrument during the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is appropriate to insert a thread of linen, which has some thickening and nodes in it, and place the quantity of the digit on each node, or less: and let the weak one take hold of the extremity of one filament with the thumb, or with what is possible, after making it similar to the one he has made for himself: and draw out the sweet one, until it reaches the caassum, and go up over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	Indeed, many children indeed imitate this dissection in schools: it is an easy matter for him who wishes it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the child's penis, one end that is going over the nose, and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then and apply a tight bandage of flesh with the knots that are in the child's penis.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is already with the knots of the child's penis.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread: and place it in the nose after washing the nostrils with the Egyptian ointment that you have drunk: do this for three days, or more, until the ointment dissolves all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place the end of the thing in the nose a lead tube, for some days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however, he needs care that dries out, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	To make the head purge, with which olives and other medicines are distilled in the nose, make it of silver or air: which is similar to a small lamp, open like a concha: and its mouth similarly.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you want to make a closed tube, like a cane.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the concha instrument for making the head purge should be full, detected: which has a handle in its end, with which you hold it, when you heat in it oil, or what you want from burning wood, and things that flow.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	¶ About the care of Thelul's nose.
Caput XXV.	Caput XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Indeed, a head is born at the end of Thelul's nose, and it grows and increases with the days until a good appearance is made of it.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	It is therefore necessary, for that reason, to appear at the beginning of its appearance and remove everything of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place over the place, or cauterant which is burning the medicine that is in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If then the incision of it is slow to grow until it becomes large, then consider it, if it is made of stone, hard, reddish-brown color, few senses: then you do not touch it with iron: because it is a cancerous ulcer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Indeed you often see that the monstrous ulcer of the hand is caused by it, and it happens from this malice that has been on it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the ulcer is a mild touch, not reddish-brown color, and you see that the incision is possible in the whole of it, then you escape with the weak, and cut it without fear, without trembling: and take care of the place where it extinguishes and constricts, until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Regarding the suture of the nose, and lips, and ears.
Caput XXVI.	Head 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when the solution of the continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, it does not profit much in it operation, unless in some men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore when something happens to someone from it, you should consider if it is a recent wound with its own blood: and then gather the pain of the wounds with the suture: and then take care of it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the solution of the continuity of the lips has already been separated, and every part has been made healthy: then it is necessary to remove all parts from its own appearance, until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then gather the two lips with the suture, and tie it, and make a pustule over the blood of the dragon, and powdered olibanum: and put above the pustules a fragment of plaster diafinicon, and some other plaster consolidated: and release it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then dissolve it, and mix the medicine again: and let it alone until the threads come out by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointment, until it is cured.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	However, the method of the suture is to gather the continuous solution, or with a candle, as we have mentioned in the suture of the lungs: or gather the solution with thread, as I will show you to know.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	¶ On the extraction of false teeth.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Indeed, many people have hard and painful spots in the interior of their teeth, caused by small and large plants. And some of them are smaller and larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, it is necessary to open the lip, and pull a thread all around the tooth, and hang it with a needle, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the place after cutting the thread, until blood comes out.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then wash with vinegar, and heal the place where there is stitching, until the wounds are cured.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	¶ On the cutting of the flesh of the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	The flesh of the gum is often born, which the ancients call abuluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore, it is necessary to hang it with a needle, or hold it with pliers, and cut it at the root of it, and let the healthy blood run, or the blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on top of the place where the thread is cut, or other small stitches, and make them dry.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	That if the flesh returns to it after the treatment, for it often returns, then cut it again and cauterize it: for it does not return after the cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Regarding the Reason of Teeth with Iron.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When the parts of the teeth are aggregated from within and without, and between the gums are sharp, rough, and sometimes become blackened, and then become smooth and yellowish, until the corruption reaches the gum, and then they become unsightly.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	Therefore you should make the patient sit with their hand on your shoulder, and place their head in your lap, and rub their mouth and tooth, in which the bark appears, and something similar to sand, until nothing remains of it, and also do the same for blackness, whiteness, yellowness, and other similar qualities, until they become clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If something is removed from them that was at the beginning of the reason, it is good: and if not, then you should repeat the reason on them on the next day, secondly, and thirdly, until finally your desire comes to an end in what you wish.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And you know that the tooth requires different shapes and many figures of razors, according to which it is prepared for your operation: the one is the razor that cuts the tooth from the lower part, the other is the razor that cuts between the teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these shapes of razors should be ready at hand which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Regarding the Extraction of Tooth Pain.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary to cure the tooth from its pain with all your skill, and then to remove it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For it is not that the tooth supplies itself with a bone when it is removed: for it is a substance that is elevated: until when there is no excuse for the removal of it, then it is necessary when you think to remove it firmly, and to be certain that the painful tooth is removed.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	The infirmity deceives the feeble pain, and thinks that it is in the tooth of the Saha and eliminates it: then the pain does not depart until the weak tooth is eliminated.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We have already seen this from the operation of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When the tooth itself is certified as painful to you, then it is necessary to scarify around the tooth with sandarac wood, in which there is some virtue, until the gum loosens from all parts: then move it with your fingers, or with the tips of the thumbs at first gently, until you agitate it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the large screws well in that place, and the weak head between your knees: which you have held well, so that it does not move: then pull the tooth according to its straightness, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not go out, then take one of their instruments, and introduce it under it from all parts with ease, and stir its movement, as you have done at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded, then it is necessary to fill that hole with a piece of cloth: and tie it with the tip of the fine ends of the threads, so that it does not break in your constriction above it with the thumbscrews.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary to be very careful when scarifying around the gum from all parts, much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And guard your strength, so as not to break it, and there remains a part of it, and the malice that is greater pain for it at first remains above it.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And be careful not to do this that unknowing bloodletters do in their haste and the boldness of their removal, beyond what we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many times they cause great harm to the bodies of men, whose difficulties are such that they break, and all the roots of them remain, or some of them: or such as extract it with some of the bones of the jaw: as we have testified many times to this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is covered after its removal with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If blood flows from certain places (for it often happens), then grind some of the zegi and fill that place: and if not, burn it with your zegi.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forms of the sharp points by which the tooth moves are first long-tailed, short necks, thick, so as not to double when they press upon the tooth: they should be like the thick necks of a hammer, until when you pull them with them, they do not bite into themselves, nor double: short-tailed, and they should be made of iron or of those that are not fit for the ends, and in their ends there should be teeth, some of which go into some, and are held by a proper contraction.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes they become like the end of the jaw of a bird called the crow, and are strong in contraction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	§ On the Removal of Teeth and the Extraction of Bones from the Jaw.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When something remains at the removal of the tooth which has broken off, it is necessary to put on the place a poultice with honey once or twice a day until the place becomes soft: then insert into it a needle or a forceps, whose ends are like the end of the jaw of a bird called the crow.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The form of this is a forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	The ends of these are made like a spoiled thumb: or like an aliskife.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If then you do not submit to the end with these claws, it is necessary to make a cut above the root, and pull out the entire flesh, and insert the small instrument called the Palanca, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	The end should be short, but rather large: and it should not be drunk, lest it be broken.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If however the root goes through this, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to apply with these other instruments whose forms are like these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The form of the first end is a triangle, in which there is some bulkiness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The form of the second end is a triangle, subtle.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It may also be applied with this instrument having two branches, whose form is like this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and tools which preceeded in the ratio of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It may also be applied with this instrument that is similar to a large uncino, whose form is a triangle, twisted, in which there is some bulkiness, so as not to be broken: and it should not be drunk.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And you know that the dental instruments are many: and similarly other instruments are not counted, and a wise craftsman has found by himself the instrument, according to which it operates and cures itself.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For from the diseases are made those to which the ancients did not speak about the instrument, because of the diversity of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If however the bone breaks from the jaw, or from other bones of the face, or putrefies: then examine above it in the place where it was with that which is convenient to it from the instruments and claws which I said in the extraction of the root, and apply with your hand, whose form is like this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Sit in the beginning with a slight increase in size, so that it can be stretched or held together with that bone, and does not fear or wear out, until it exits the bone: and restore the place with suitable medicines for this.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	However, if there is a small pus in the bone, then rub it out of its own pus, and care for it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Regarding the suturing of prominent teeth over others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth do not grow according to their natural course, a monstrous form is produced: and this is especially true when it happens in women and girls, that is, those who are of marriageable age.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore, you should consider this.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if the tooth is born after another tooth, and is not placed, or its suture is possible, nor its own lipping: then remove it: and if it is connected with another tooth, then cut it off with this instrument, which has this form.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is similar to a small face, and it is made from iron with sharp points at both ends.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And your cutting should be the one you make in many days, and for the hardness of the teeth, and so that it does not move another tooth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	However, if it is prominent exposed to its own lipping: then lip it with the same lip that has this form.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It should be all of iron, and the head of its small points should be as small as the lip that makes the needles: with which it is lipped over the tooth gradually in many days with ease, so that it does not move the tooth, and falls off: then gently remove it, at the end, rub it with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If it is a tooth from which a part breaks off and hurts the tongue: then it should be lipped also, until the roughness of that break is removed and made equal: and it will flatten and not hurt the tongue, nor corrupt the speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	In the description of the teeth with golden sons.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When there is a concussion and agitation of the anterior teeth, either by blows or chance: and an weak person cannot hold them together over the part that is chewed so as not to fall: and they are cared for with stimulating medicines, and the treatment is not avoided: then the wisdom is to tie them with gold wire, because silver becomes dull and rots in days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And the thread should be of medium fineness and coarseness according to the amount that is taken between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the shape of the tie is that you take the thread, and insert it twice as long between two healthy teeth: then you should twist with both ends of the wire between the moving teeth, whether one or more, until the swelling with cloth up to the other sound part.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then you should repeat the twisting up to the part from where you began: and hold your hand with fineness and wisdom, until it does not come loose at all, and the tie that you make by pulling up the thread between the roots of the teeth should not fall off.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the loose ends of the thread with a knife: and gather them together and turn them with your hand, and hide them between the sound tooth and the moving tooth so that they do not hurt the tongue, and then let it be tied as tight as possible while it remains.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	But if it is loosened or falls off, tie them with another thread and let it stand firm for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the shape of the teeth, and the figure of the tie of two sound teeth and two moving teeth as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And sometimes it happens that one tooth remains, or two after the accident of the knife and the hammer in their places, and are tied as we have said, and remain: and this is done only by a skilled artisan, wise, and experienced.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	When it comes to setting a bone from the ribs: and it is made like the shape of a tooth, and placed in its place, where the tooth is fastened, as I have said: and it remains, and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	¶ Regarding the incision of the ligament that occurs under the tongue, and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Head 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When the ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, as it is from the time of human birth, or accidental, from the elbow that has already solidified.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation on it is to open the weak mouth of its head in your groove, and split its tongue: then incise this nervous ligament through its breadth, until it is loosened from its own retention.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is any hard knot or node, and it is from the consolidation of the wound: then extract this knot, and find it through its breadth, until you incise the ligament, and the node is loosened.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And be careful not to make a fissure in deep flesh, and incise the artery there, and blood may flow.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then apply to the wound of the incision with hot water, or with vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a bandage of linen, that holds firmly all night, so it does not consolidate secondarily.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if blood flows, then place above the spot a piece of flax.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If not, then cauterize the place with a sharp iron that is suitable for it, and then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	The extraction of Ranula which is made under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When an apostema occurs under the tongue which resembles a small ranula, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function: and perhaps it becomes so swollen that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation is to open the weak mouth before the sun: and consider the apostema.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If then you see it to be of a red or black color, hard, which does not give way to the weak sense: then do not touch it, because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it is inclined to a whitish color, which is moist: then insert the thumb into it, and cut it with a soft salt, and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood does not come out of your mouth during the operation, then place a piece of chewed bread on it until the blood is absorbed: then return to your operation, until you take it out with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then rinse it with vinegar and salt: and care for it with the rest of the treatment suitable for this, until it is cured.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	The cure of two breasts.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When two breasts occur between the throat, that is, glands which resemble linen, which occur in deformity: and they are called two breasts: when you cure them along with what I said earlier in division, and they do not heal, then consider.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If then it is a hard apostema of a red or black color, with few senses: then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is a red color, and the root of it is large: then do not touch it with iron, fearing the flow of blood, even though you let it go, until it is mature.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	Then you will either pierce it yourself: or it will burst on its own.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	If it is white in color, round in shape, and its root is fine: then you must cut it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	If the operation is to be performed on the same spot where the hot pimple has quietly completed its course, or if it is about to diminish: then let the weak one lie down in the sun, and place the head of the patient in your lap: open the mouth of the patient, and take hold of it with your own hands, and press down the tongue of the patient with the instrument which has this form.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver or air, which is as fine as a dagger.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press the tongue with it, and show the pimple to you, and it falls on top of your used one: then take a thread, and tie it in the hollow, and pull it out from outside as much as you can, without taking anything from the cloth with it.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut it with the instrument which has the form that follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It will resemble a sickle: but the ends of them are blunt, so that the opening of each of them is in the direct acute angle of another: therefore take care that it is made of iron, or that it is dipped in blood.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut it with the one which has the following form.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	It should be sharp on one side, and blunt on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you cut the first one, cut the second one in the same way as the first one.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the cutting, gargle the weak one with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If blood flows from it, gargle with water in which the bullae of the bark are cut, or the leaves of myrtle and such like from stitches, until the blood flow stops: then take care of it until it is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	When certain stones are born in the throat, there are two besides the two breasts.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Therefore, these should be cut equally according to what I said about the incision of two breasts.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	Indeed, I have already treated a woman with a stone that had been born between the two breasts, which she had drawn to the neck, and it was nearly closed: the woman was breathing from the narrow opening, and she had forbidden it food and drink, and she had perished if she had remained alive for one day or for two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The stone rose so much that it emitted two branches before they passed through the two openings of the nose.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I therefore hastily fixed the other one in a knot.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	I then drew it out, and a large portion came out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	I then cut it off where I could comprehend it from the opening of the nose.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	I then made this to her that came out of the other opening of the nose.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	I then opened her mouth and pressed her tongue: I then fixed the knot in it: I then cut out a large portion from it, and it did not come out but only a little blood: The woman's throat was therefore released, and she began to drink water immediately, and then she took from food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	I did not therefore stop cutting it for a long time from that stone: and the stone was in the place I was cutting, until it was too long and with this.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I therefore used my ingenuity and cauterized the stone between the two breasts.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It remained still, and then I walked on from that side, and I do not know what God did with it after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Section on making an ulcer incision with a knife.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When catarrh descends to the ulcer and makes it longer, then it is called a perpendicular ulcer. And if it is in the lower part, which is thick, round, then it is also called a vesicle.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When the division is made as we have said, and there is no cure of it, and you see that the hot knife has left it and it is fine, then it is necessary to cut it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And if there is anything gathered on it that is round and does not have length, and it is bloody or of a red or black color and has no sense, then it is necessary to make an incision on it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For there is fear in the weakest part.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore, when you see it according to the manner which I have said of white and its length, then make the weak part sit by the sun: and press the tongue of it with the instrument which follows the narration, and then tie a string in it and draw it downwards: and cut it with one of two instruments which I have said in the incision of two clavicles.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary to cut from it unless that which is added above natural end is without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from it more than necessary, you will harm the lip and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the cutting use that which we have said in the incision of two clavicles: and take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	But if the weak one is afraid of the cutting, then it is necessary to use your skill in cauterization of it without fear and gentleness.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization in it is not, except with sharp water: and it is, as you place the weak head in the socket of your vein.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press the language of its with the instrument that we say.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water that I told you in the chapter of cauterization, and wrap it with a non-extinguished iron scalpel, neither thick nor thin, and fill this connection with this instrument's form, which is this one.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	The connection of its extreme where the medicine is placed should be like the connection of the cochlea's radii.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on the same layer: and let it be weak lying on its side, so that saliva from its mouth is drawn out internally by the medicine, so that nothing of it descends to its throat and harms it.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first of it on the same quantity of the middle hour, until you see it already faded and sated by the medicine's bitterness.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take a pill and place it on the extreme of the radii, and inject the pill with the medicine, and insert the radium with the pill into the cannula below, until the pill adheres above the layer.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times until you find out what you want from cauterization of the skin.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then let it go: for it itself will wane and fall after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	What if you need to take the medicine again? Then take it again: and after cauterization, wipe around the skin with the pill taken in honey, and cleanse yourself with what is around it from the medicine: and wet with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And it is cured externally with an ointment, and swallowed with gargles, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Therefore this species of curing is more salubrious than a long incision and less frightening.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	When the wound is cured, even if it is softer than cauterization and incision, it is cured with suffocation, according to this method.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Combine calamite, hyssop, origanum, rue, sage, chamomile, and burdock, and all similar herbs. Mix them together, or some of them in a pot, and let them soak in vinegar, and boil: and the pot should be washed with cleanliness, and the hole in the middle of the pot should be for the instrument of the concaium according to this method.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make of silver or air: and insert the extremity, in which is the ginger, into the weak tooth, until the vapor rises to the wound through the tube, until the wound becomes very much obscured.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the same spot, until it is scorched.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful not to perform this curing at the beginning with aseptics.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For plasters are added to aseptics, and it is not proper to do this except at the decline of the aseptics, which are hot.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If this instrument is not present to you, then take vinegar and put the end of the bark in it: so that the weak tooth will not burn: for the bark of the bark prevents the vapor from burning the tooth: and this is good for cure with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	¶ About the extraction of thorns and bones from the mouth.
Caput XXXVIII.	Head 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	The tooth adheres very much to the gum, or a thorn of a fish, or another.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, it is necessary to remove what is apparent above that falls on the sun, and declare to you what is in the mouth, after you have placed your tongue with the instrument.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	When it does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary for you to make a human weakness before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the matter attached by vomiting will be released.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the weak one may swallow the sharp end of a nut, or the root of a lettuce, or the tip of a dry bread; or he may take the tip of a dry marine sponge and then swallow it. And tie it up in a thread and then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When he comes to the place where the spine or the bone is, and it is extracted, then he goes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If he does not go out with that which we said: then use the instrument from the second leg according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.
