It should be larger than the radius but smaller than a thumb, and at the end of it there should be a notch that he inserts into his throat with ease, and he himself should have his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him be careful of the touch of his epiglottis so that he does not get a fit of coughing, and pushes with it either the bone or the hand of the physician.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Indeed, when the weak one inserts it, this is better: because of his knowledge of the place where the thing attached is: and he pushes down or pulls up his hand with the instrument upwards, all of it according to the quantity that is prepared for him until it goes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	¶ About the extraction of Sanguisuga.
Caput XXXIX.	¶ Head 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the sanguisuga is treated with that which I said in the division of care with medicines and does not fit, then consider in the weak throat in front of the sun, whether at the sun after he has put his tongue with the instrument that I will tell you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If then your custom falls upon blood-letting, take it out with a small ivory needle, or with a gentle grasp.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If then it is not possible with these: then take a hollow needle, and insert it into the weak throat near the throat: then insert into the hollow of the heated needle with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this often: and let the weak one abstain from water all day long.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take cold water full in his belly, and open his mouth into it: and let him wet his mouth with it, and swallow nothing out of it: and let him drink water an hour after another with his own hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For blood-letting falls down with the sense of blood.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If then he does not follow what we have told him, then suffume the weak one with incense, or with a gentle grasp with the instrument that I have described for suffocation.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this often, for it falls down.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in suffocation is to take a pot wherein are young pearls with fire: and the pot be covered with a covering, in the middle of which is a hole: and the end of the instrument is put into this hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then draw off the suffocation, and let him open his mouth at the end of the hollow, and close his mouth, so that he does not suffocate until you know that the suffocation has made blood fall.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For blood-letting falls down immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If then it does not fall, then do suffocation often.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the weak one will endure thirst, and eat salt, and honey, and will not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he go out with this diet.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	This is the shape of the instrument used to extract blood from the stomach, when it falls on itself.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It resembles a pair of forceps, as you see: unless it is this curvature that is inserted into the stomach.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And the end of it is similar to that of a goose's beak, where there is roughness of the fingers: when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	¶ About the opening of the Apostemate, and its sectioning, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Head 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of Apostemata, of different sizes, according to the rememoration of them, that is, one and one in this book: and they are different in their piercing and sectioning from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is of the kind of Apostemata in itself, and that which grasps from moisture.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is because of the places where it happens to the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For the Apostemata happening in the head is different from that happening in the anus: and the Apostemata happening in a fleshy place is different from that happening in joints: and each of them has its own judgment from their operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from the Apostemata there are those which it is not fitting that they should be pierced unless after the maturation of the sore in them, and the complement of it: and there are those which it is fitting that they should be pierced while they are raw, and do not mature according to the complement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	So Apostemata which are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when the Apostemata happen near the joint, and it extends itself, until it putrefies which is in its circumference, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint are corrupted: therefore it is a cause nearer to the contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	If it is an abscess on the main limb, then it is harmful to either you or the member from which it bursts, or through that member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is near a joint, then the wound is not yet fully healed, and it should not be opened if it is near a joint, otherwise it will decay deeply and extend to the inner parts of the joint, or a fistula will form, or it will not heal at its end.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary to know the hour of the abscess's opening, according to the complement: it is near the sedation of pain, the recession of fever, and the decrease of rubefaction, and the pulsation of the head abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary to make the same opening on the lower part of the abscess, and more deeply: and the wound should be made in the length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of the fingers, and the tendons, and the nerves, and the arteries, and at last in all equal places where there is no reflex:
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those where there is a reflex, close the wound with the member on which the opening was made.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the abscess is in fleshy parts, it is better to leave the wound open until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you open it before that, the course of the wound will be prolonged, and there will be many sore and sore places, and perhaps the lips of it will become hard, and its depth will be increased.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are opened according to the length of the body, at the necessity: or according to the member that is needed.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	It is necessary to make incisions in the small labia and in the large ones, making them wide; or to make many sections in the likeness of the size of the labia.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	These are from the labia where it is necessary to cut through the skin; and the incision is made when the skin is already like a cloth, and is made at the end where the dead part is, as in the case of many, such as in mumps, and tumors.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from these there are those that are cut with a three-angled section.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from these there is one, by which the incision is made like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	So the labia.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from these there are those where a round section and a lunar section are made, and similar ones from the sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	However, if there is no head like the smooth and superficial labia, it is necessary to make the incision through the superficial or flat one.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when the labia is large and has already collected a lot of healthy tissue, and makes an incision in it, so that not too much pus is drawn out at once: indeed, it should be taken from that part itself.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then fill the labia up to another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then take some more pus from it.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this frequently according to the degree until it comes out: especially if the person is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a boy who is young, or an old man who is decrepit: for the animal spirit of the animal is resolved from animal to animal when the pus comes out: and perhaps the weak one will die, and you will not know.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore this chapter requires great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	After making the incision, you should clean the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If the wound is small and flat, then apply a linen bandage, or an old clout.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If the wound is large and there are many incisions, then you should insert linen into all the fissures until they become moist with blood.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have split a part of the skin, or cauterized it around: then you should cover it with an old bandage, or as when the cloth is tied, or the hair of linen is wet without moisture: and tie it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and care for it with ointment until it is cured.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however, blood flows in your operation hour, then apply cold water and vinegar, after which the bandage soaks it up: and place it over the flowing blood site many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If however, the blood flow persists, then you should give a treatment, and care, and pills which I will tell you in many places of this our book, and by division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If however, it is in the winter season, and the wound site is of many nerves: then you should pour pills with wine, and hot oil: and place them over the sites.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	If however, it is in the summer season, and the wound sites are fat: then you should place pills soaked in water and oil, or wine and oil, and all of it cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	When the third day comes, as I said, then you should dissolve the wound, and clean it, and give in its care what is suitable for it, until it is cured.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is what is necessary for the universal understanding of the apostem's care.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the semiotics, I have already said about all apostemates, how it is useful for their care in detail.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	¶ About the section of the apostemates that occur on the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Scalp XLI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small apostemates occur on the scalp and are of the species Nodorum, which are found in the clothes that are made from them, which are like the feathers of a hen.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their species is very many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Among them are fat ones: and among them are those that contain like moisture of the limbs: and among them are those that contain like moisture of flax and plaster: and such as these, and among them are those that are hard like stones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in all sections, and there is no fear of their extraction, while it does not cause any contraction of the artery in their section.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is as I have experienced it with the instrument whose form comes after this, which is called the Intromissive, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then dry it in the section according to the length of the surface section: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the section from line b to line g. And when the moisture is expelled, then scrape out the kistin which contains this moisture, and do not let anything be left inside it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For it often returns, if there remains something inside it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then submerge the gutta in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the vulva with it, and let it remain until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	It itself will be discontented that a part remains from the box.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then follow up on the same belly with Egyptian ointment twice, and thirdly, and if you need it, until you trust that nothing will remain from the box, then care for the other side with ointment, until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the carbuncle contains a red node: then cut it according to this form, which has the shape of a cross: and strip the wool between the two sections, and scrape it off from all parts: and trust in your courage in extracting the wool that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If the artery causes you any contrariness: then do what I will tell you later.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly, in the carbuncle, if it is of stone: then cut it according to the section and treatment that I said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section on the stone carbuncle is easier: because it has fewer blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some of these carbuncles on the head of certain men, in which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I followed the carbuncle on the head of a woman's forehead, and found a carbuncle like a hard and solid stone, sharp, white, which could not be broken: and if it is scraped off with something, it wounds itself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In others, however, there are accidents on the head of the carbuncle, except for these carbuncles that happen in the heads of children, and among the gold roots, the section of all of them is a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or, first, make a perforation from the lower part of them, so that the course of the pus may go to the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it as for that, according to what suits them from the care.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	§ Section on the Strophular muscle in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These wounds often occur in the neck, under the jaw, and in the groin, and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those that occur above them in the neck are fewer and more severe, and are caused by the violence of the wound. And all the Strophlus is within its own shirt, just as it is in the noses and wounds of the heads, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	The appearance of these Strophlus is very varied.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For they are hard and some are moist, and some are malignant and do not obey the treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that which you see as having a good disposition in the wound, whose color is manifestly close to the skin color, and moves over all parts of the body, and is not anchored to the neck muscles, nor to the tendons, nor to the artery, nor is deep: it is necessary to cut this superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body along line b to line g, and extend the two lips of the skin with the razor, or with many razors, if you need that, as we said in the wounds of the head, and then take it out slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is above the caution, so as not to touch the brain, or the nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the scalpel be not sharp and cold, so as not to add to your hand with the incision, or disturb the weak, and you cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein, or an artery, or forbid you from the operation, then place in the thigh ground nuts, or some children who cut the blood, and tie the thigh, and let it go, until the sharpness of the wound is dulled, and the thigh becomes soft: or begins to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	The blood is let then, go to your operation, until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your finger tip the stitches of the Strophulus to others' wombs: then cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If the root of the Strophula is very large: then it is necessary not to cut that Strophula from its root: indeed it is necessary to tie it with a strong thread and to let it go until it falls by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the old gut with the ointment of Egypt that you have already dipped.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole Strophula is cut, then it is necessary to gather the two lips of the wound and to stitch them immediately, after which you will see that there is no excess.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you see that there is excess due to the size of the Strophula, then it is necessary to consider cutting off its root and taking it out, and to apply the suture that I mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And whatever contains humidity from the Strophula, make a superficial perforation in it: so that you may see the place of its readiness for you: and place the perforation below the body, as I mentioned.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the hair after the perforation with ointment, and similar to it, so that what remains of corruption may rot until you see the wound already clean: then take care of it with the ointment of grown flesh, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	¶ About the cutting of the Epiglottis from the aposteme inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients used to cut this section in the Epiglottis, and I have not found anyone in our land who did it, and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In cases where there is a tracheal tube (synanchiam), it is necessary to omit the section on the division of the epiglottis: because if a passage is made through that, all the veins and lungs are weakened.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In cases where there is a hot aphthae in the mouth, or throat, or both round lymph nodes, when there is no inflammation in the trachea, it is necessary to use the section on the division of the epiglottis to avoid destruction that occurs from praecociality.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to omit the division of the epiglottis, it is necessary to separate the epiglottis under three or four circumferences of the epiglottis, or five, by a small section through the width, in the part that is between the two circles by the quantity, which is the section in the sifac, not in the cartilage: and this is an appropriate place for the section, because it is bare flesh, and the blood is far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the throat with a sharp nail.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he will examine the skin until it becomes moist towards the trachea: he will let out blood if he sees anything in it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he will seal the sifac that we have mentioned: and it means above the section of the trachea, when it exits from it, with what is broken, and by abscission of the tongue.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the groin be open at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the hour comes that you fear praecociality, gather together two lips of the skin, and take only the same without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer the medicines that cause flesh to be born, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis said.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this part of the discourse is that if the patient has already lost consciousness due to the apostematum, and the surgeon wants to operate on him after his death, he should cut the epiglottis to allow him to breathe from a different place, and thus save him from death. For this reason, they were instructed to leave the abdomen open for three days, until the malady of the patient has subsided, and it seems that the patient has recovered. Then, they were advised to close the wound and take care of it until he recovers.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw myself, that one woman received a sword, and sent it with her throat, and it occurred when she entered her lung.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to care for him, and I found him crying, just as the cry of the dead is.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Therefore, I removed it from the wound, and found blood that had escaped from the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore, I was surprised that it had not closed the wound, nor guided it: and the air was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore, I acted promptly, and his own wound, and cared for it until it was healed: and nothing happened to the woman except that she had a cough in her throat: and she returned after a few days to a better arrangement of her own.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear in the cutting of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Regarding the sectioning of the guttiernal hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 43.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This apostemata, called the guttiernal hernia, is a large apostemata according to the color of the body: and it is much more common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It is according to two modes: whether it is natural, or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural, there is no genius.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental, however, is according to two modes: one of which is similar to a small feather.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode, it is similar to a spindle which is made from the nodation of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And it is fear itself, and it does not need to be assumed about it with iron, unless in the small one: and you prove it yourself, and investigate it with intromission.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then I find it similar to a small feather, and it is not suspended with any wings: then dry it, as is done with the nods: and extract it with that which contains it from the kist, if it is in the kist: and if not, then examine the whole of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with which it must be treated until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Regarding the section on the species of nods.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of nods, and I have already said all the species of these in division: and it is necessary to point out this difference between the nod and the exit: since there is doubt about it.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when the exit is heat, and fever, and violent pains, until the ebullition of the superfluous one subsides, and putrefaction is completed: then the fever and the heat are quieted.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the nod is not heat, nor fever, nor pain, and it contains them in kistis sifachin, which is their own bag, and is according to the color of the body: and it is a stopper like a chestnut, and it is like a brush, and greater and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	They are of two kinds: either they are fat: or they contain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you are wet in the treatment of Noma, you must try it first, and then look at the instrument called the Intromissive, according to its form in the chapter that follows this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of the probe is for all Noses, that you take this instrument and insert it into a moister place that you find in the probe: and then rotate your fingers with it gradually, until you know that the instrument has already pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then the last hand of yours according to the size of the probe.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then take out the Intromissive and look at that which goes into the wound of it.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If then moisture runs out, whatever its color: then cut it off at the surface according to what I said in the others probes.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if moisture does not run out in the wound of the Intromissive, then you know that it is fat: cut it off at the surface with a cross-shaped section, according to the form I showed you: and suspend it with strings, and scrape the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the kistin if you can over it, so that it takes out the sound Noma.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the kistin is broken at the operation and cannot be taken out, often this happens, then take it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if a little remains of it, or much, the Noma returns according to the most.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And if it does not heal you, and there remains little of it: then fill the wound at the end of your cure with some sharp-pointed children's teeth, and tie it up, and put the hot probe over it, and care for it with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then the knot is large, then its two lips, and care with it that it may be incarnated.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If then the opposite evil is a small one, or not small: then immediately, and fill the wound with three layers of threads, and release the tight knot for two days, or three, until the wound has putrefied, and the ebullition of blood has ceased: then return to heal that which remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	§ Regarding false instruments for cutting and drilling.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are three forms of introducers, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For among them there is a large one, and among them there is a medium one, and among them there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	May they be made from tempered steel quadrilaterals at both ends, so that the introduction may be made quickly into the aperture.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of the introducers, and not, that is, the drills: and one of them is called beris, that is, the piercer: and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For among them there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They come together, so that they may be investigated through those apertures, and exits, and fistulas, and bones from the one that is between them.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, thin, and soft, like the large needles from which the seats are made, of silver certainly, or of air, or of iron, or of gold.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And their better ones are those that are made of silver.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are also introducers of lead black, which come together so that they may be investigated through those fistulas, whose reflections are refractions, so that they may be reflected with the lenity of their reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	The three species are again.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For they are long, they are medium, and they are short, according to the size of the fistula and its stricture.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of the ninth, and they are many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For they are simple, namely those with a single ulceration: and they are three kinds as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are the ninth blind: and they are three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are the ninth with two ulcerations, and they are three kinds: and from them are the ninth with three ulcerations, and they are three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, by which the nails are cut and scratched, and the staples are removed: and they are three kinds: for there is a great, a medium, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities by which the incision is made are sharp, while other extremities are not sharp: and they are not placed thus, except when with them there is an excitement of the nails in the scratching of the nails at the fear of the incision of the vein, or of the nerve: and so it heals through these weak ones, and finds tranquility rather than what it finds at the scratching of the staples.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the Madras, and they are three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of iron, and they are similar to the Rhodes, with which alcohol is made: and at the end of the flat point there is a hidden dot of Spatumilis: and it runs towards the interior and exterior when you wish, just as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of Spatumilis which is hidden between the fingers at the staple incision: and they are not perceived by the weak: and they are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The three kinds of winds that divide the flow of blood are: the great, the medium, and the small ones.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of air or citrino, round, and nearly as long as you see, and they should be of a subtle nature.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of winds be at your disposal, both the great and the small ones: so that you can cut through the blood with ease when there is a necessity, and then when no doctor is present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you will not use them in cutting through all parts of the body, and you will only use them in the locations of the flesh: such as the knees, and hips, and the shoulders, and breasts, and mammary glands, and throats, and groins, and similar parts, from the fleshy parts, which are humid.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they become small instruments of the same kind as those made from fistules, according to their form: which cut through the blood when it flows from the site of phlebotomy, or at the wound, or at the artery: and sometimes they become round in this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Regarding the treatment of human breasts that are similar to those of women's breasts.
Caput XLVII.	Head 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell up when they are near the end of sleep (that is, when they start to be polluted in their sleep) until they are like the breasts of women: and they remain full of poison.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, if he detests this, it is necessary to cut over the breasts with a lunar section, according to this form from the line b to the line g. Then scrape off all the grease.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards, fill the wound with medicated gristle.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then, gather the two lips of the wound with the suture, and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If the nipple leans towards the lower parts and softens due to its size, as often happens in women: then it should be cut into two equal parts on the upper sides, with each part containing the other at their ends, until the larger line contains the smaller one, according to this form from line b to line g. Then, scrape off the skin that is between the two lips and remove the fat, and apply what I have mentioned about the suture and gums, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If the incision does not lie down as it should, due to weakness or because of the flow of blood: then it should be filled with gristle under a dressing of corrosive ointment, and let it remain until the remaining part becomes corroded from the fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then, care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	¶ Regarding the puncture of the staple that happens under the Titillation.
Caput XLVIII.	Head 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These staples that happen under the Titillation are made from hard species of Strophular, which contain kernels, and some of them have wetness in them.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those that have wetness in them should be cut into a lunar shape, according to this form, from line b to line g, when the entire thing that is in the staple comes out of the sore, then fill it with old dressing, and let it remain until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then, remove the dressing, and care for it with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If an apoplexy has occurred in the form of a node of the Strophular group, then cut along it, as we have said in the section on the Strophular group, equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If the finger is extended in this way and allows pus to be discharged, then apply a caustic in that place, according to what we have said in that place which was first mentioned.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	¶ About the section of an apoplexy that occurs due to the artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is torn and the skin above it consolidates, there often occurs from that point an apoplexy, and likewise the vein, so that there occurs in it an apoplexy and inflammation.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an apoplexy and inflammation are due to the artery and vein are: for when an apoplexy is due to the artery, it is long, gathered in the deep part of the body: and when you press the apoplexy of your fingers, you seem to hear as if there were a cracking.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to the vein is round in the apparent body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section above this apoplexy is an error, and especially that which is under the scales, and in the groins, and at the neck, and in many places of the body: and it is a great wonder.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary that this care be neglected with iron, and that it also occurs at the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary that it be neglected.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore over that which is from them due to the inflammation of the artery's opening, find in the cut a longitudinal section.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with the hooks, then the artery: and free it from the coverings, until it is seen.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the scalpel under it, and make it penetrate until it reaches another side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then press the spot where the two ligaments meet with sodium, until blood that is entirely in it comes out, and the apostematic membrane is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply the curing agent that generates pus, until the ligaments fall: then care for it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is apostemata due to the section of the vein, then it is necessary for you to hold your hand with which you can hold the apostemata with your skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the scalpel under the place where you held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and there should be a double thread in it until the other side has taken it out.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the apostemata with the same good bandage: according to what I told you in the good vein bandage, with two parts from two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you think that the thread may be taken out, then insert the scalpel another with another thread under the apostemata completely at the incision of the scalpel: press and tie your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the apostemata in the middle of it, until when it comes out what is in it: then make an incision for the excess skin and let that which is tied be released from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put a little ointment on the one you dipped in wine.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the curing agent that is made with laudanum and ointments until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	¶ About the apostemata that happen from the twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Head of the Lamb
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As it happens with the artery and vein, so it happens with the nerves: that it happens by striking them, or by excessive labor, and similarly: and it happens most in the places of helpers, or the heel, and in every place where the joints are stretched, and it is a serious matter.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It resembles the color of the other parts of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is drawn with strength, it feels in it a weakness similar to that of amazement.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And there is no gathering of amazement in the deep parts of the body, indeed it is on the cheek, and it moves to all parts, and it does not go to the anterior part, neither before, nor after to the posterior part.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	What therefore comes from them in the joints, it does not need to be with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps it will happen to contract.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that however which comes from them in the head or in the face, find the skin with sand.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If then it is a small amazement, hold it with thorns and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is great, then suspend it with a razor and exfoliate it, then remove it, and gather the wound with a suture, and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	¶ About the section of the amazement that happens in the belly.
Caput LI.	Head of the Lamb.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Occasionally happen to some men multiplied in their bellies and in other parts of their bodies, the warts, which are called Fungali, by similarity with their mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is fine, and their head is thick, and their lips are turned over.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	It is one of them that is small and one that is magnified in appearance.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	Indeed, I have seen a man, and within his belly there were two thymele, which were greater than the others: there was no difference between them, white and small roots, and his lips would change color, and they would become moist. This was always present.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore, I cut it and found in the weight of one almost XVIII and VIII ounces and in the other almost VI ounces. The operation in the incision of these is, as you see now, if the patient is weak, and the color of the thymele is white, moist, and subtle root: then cut it with a flat spatula, and let your cauteries be present in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For many times blood is expelled at the section of this: therefore, if you do not cut blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a weak and timid man being cut with iron, then take a thread from the plumb, made in an appropriate manner, and string it with it: whose mode I have mentioned, and release it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the plumb's closure.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	You do not stop stringing the plumb, whenever it presses into the thymele, until it is released and falls without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	However, if the thymele root is large, then there is some fear and weakness in its cutting: especially in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless, it may be possible to cut it in half.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not remain.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful not to presume to cut the thymele that is of a red color, few senses, ugly appearance: for it is an aposteme cancerous: and I am alive with a reminder of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	The care of hernias.
Caput LII.	Chapter 21.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Hernias can occur due to many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from a tear in the abdominal wall, which is above the ventrum, and it exits through this ordeal, or the intestine, according to what happens in the others.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows out of the vein, or from the artery, according to what was mentioned earlier.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the congestion of the ventricle in this place.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however, it is due to a tear in the abdominal wall, and the exit is through this orifice, then the color of the strangulation is similar to that of the body: it is soft, without pain, and appears to have different positions.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the exit of the intestine, then the position of this part is as we have described, with a greater diversity of the stronger.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press on it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound at that time: and it is greatly admired among the entrance of the baths, and the labor of the weary.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If however, it is due to moisture, it is soft, and it does not hide when you press it with your hand, nor does it contract, nor is it added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If however, it is due to blood, then with these signs, the strangulation appears as black from the limb.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however, it is due to flesh that has been born, then the strangulation is dark, heavy, hard, and appears according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If however, it is due to congestion, then the touch of this part is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in this case is such that you should consider this now, if the hernia of the navel is due to blood from the artery or vein, or congestion: then it is necessary to forbid its treatment.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	In that there is fear and weakness, as I taught you in the chapter where I said apostemata for the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the eminence of the umbilicus is due to the intestine or zirbum, then it should be precipitated on the weak one, so that it may hold its thirst, and stand standing extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with incense around the entire umbilicus.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to rise between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround it with a broad side of soap around the place where you marked with incense.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the apostemata mediately to the upper parts, with a large uncino.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him around the strong part with thread, or with a firm cord of silk ligation: and let the node of the ligation be elongated.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the extended apostemata mediately above the ligation.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If then you find it already caught by the ligation: then extract the elongated one, and insert your thumb indicated, and push the intestine into the interior of the vein: and if you find the zirbum, then take it with a uncino and cut overabundance of it.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however the opposite is to you artery or vein: then surround it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert them in them two strong lines: and insert two needles around the apostemata in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then string the apostemata in four places over the needles: and if you will, remove the needles, and let the place be empty, until putrid flesh extended: and it will fall by itself: or cut it when subtle and putrid.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it yourself with him, as is necessary from the ointments, until he is cured.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the prominence of the umbilicus is from flesh in that part, or from moisture: then it is necessary to make an incision of the abscess, as I have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And blood or moisture, which I find in it, will be drawn out.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of it yourself with him, as to make the place solid.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	¶ Regarding the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Head 33.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	I have already said about the division of the species of cancer, and how it is necessary to take care of it with medicines: and it is necessary to be careful of it when taking care of it with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and I have said that cancer generated in the womb, and precaution for its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that when cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible, such as cancer which is in the breast or in the thigh, and similar parts, from the fixed members to take it out entirely: especially when it is beginning male.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When however it becomes old and large, it does not need to approach him.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I could not cure anyone from it: nor have I seen anyone before me who has been healed of this.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is placed as I have said, is like the preceding, and you dissolve the weakness from black vomit repeatedly.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find a phlebotomy with clear fullness,
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	then prepare the weak preparation, in which it will be placed with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then take out the hairs that are around it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then make an incision of it from all sides according to the cut, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood run, and do not cut it rashly, rather express the blood from the place, and wipe up the blood with your hand, or with whatever is available there with the instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, the flow of blood from a large incision in an artery is contrary to you, or inflamed: then cauterize the wound, until the blood is abscised.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it yourself with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	¶ Regarding the treatment of dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Head LVIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we have spoken of the division of the kinds of dropsy, and how aggregation of water occurs, and the signs of each kind, and the treatment with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those that are treated with iron are not excepted but only the asphylactics alone: and they do not approach with iron to the phthiatic kind: nor does the asphylactick kind approacheth to the hydropic kind: for that is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When thou hast already treated this kind of dropsy with iron and it does not yield to thy medicine: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient be already weak from the dropsy, or if there be another infirmity besides this, such as a cough, or expectoration of phlegm, and such like: then fear lest thou give him iron, for he is afraid.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If however thou seeest an one of excessive strength, and there is no other disease besides this, save dropsy alone: and he be neither a child nor an old man: then the mode of operation in him is, that thou remove the weakness standing by thy hand, and make him minister to it after him, holding water in his hand, pressing it down towards the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spongium with spikes, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let it be of two parts, sharp on both sides, long, and sharp at the extremities, like sponge.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Indeed, there is some subtlety regarding brevity in it, so do not rush through the operation until the intestine, and you may harm it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of Hydrometra is from the intestines, then it is necessary to extend it with the section at the umbilicus, three digits in length, downwards in a straight line above the navel.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If indeed, the generation of Hydrometra is due to the lameness of the thigh: then your section should be on the left from the umbilicus, three digits in length.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of this is due to the spleen: then the section should be on the right side: and it is not necessary for the section to be on the right side beyond where you wish the weak part to lie, so that superfluities do not flow to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then make a hole with the instrument and cut through the entire skin.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert the section into it and spread your hand with Siptilum between the skin and the fingernail, and rub as if you are scraping off the nail itself: and the quantity to be scraped off should be about the same as the quantity of the nail.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then scrape and rub until Siptilum reaches the empty place: and that is the water place.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then take it out and insert the instrument into the hole with the form of this instrument.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is similar to a cannula: it is made of silver, or air, or aurichalco, linen, and tersum: which has a small hole in the bottom of its part, and three holes on its sides, two from one side and one from the other: and the edge of its end is cut according to the size of the fingernail, as you see: the end of its upper part is an armillary sphere.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	When the instrument is wet with water, then it comes down immediately on the instrument, therefore it drains out of the water in half an hour's amount.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you drain out more than is proper, in an hour it may kill the weak one by the resolution of his animal spirit: or it may come to a syncope which approaches to death.
