And you know that the cutting tools and the saws for this bone are many, according to the position of the bone, and the preparation of them, and their grossness, and their subtlety, and their size, and their wholeness, and their durability, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary to prepare all the tools of this operation that are convenient for this operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And you know that these operations are significant to you with respect to the kind of tool you use, when you have a long will.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the modes of this art, is a witness of the modes of the diseases: for then you will find that which is convenient to it from the tools to all kinds of infirmities.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I assure you of the last of this chapter, the number of tools that you place examples on which you cut, and the experience you make over another.
Forma Serrae.	The form of the serra (or saw) is described in this section.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The form of another serra (or saw) is also described in this section.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of yet another serra (or saw) is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of the third serra (or saw) is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the serra (or saw) should be drawn with care and attention to detail.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	The arc of this serra (or saw) should be made higher, with the sharpness coming from the metal. The handle should be made from wood, and it should be made in a pyramidal shape appropriately.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the razor's blades is described in this section.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	The head of this razor should be shaped like the stars on its cap (handle), and the points should be like those of an elisechtfegi (a type of surgical instrument).
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit unless the heads are sharp when they are joined together and they cut, or if the mouth is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the larger razor is described in this section.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the medium-sized razor is described in this section.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the wide razor is described in this section.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the razor with which it is sharp is described in this section.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of the other, more subtle razor is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the razor with curved ends is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the large, subtle razor is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the razor with which bones are cut is mentioned, but not described in detail.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The form of the large razor is mentioned again.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles the radio (a surgical instrument), and its end is like that of a serra (or saw). It is shown in many locations from the bone.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the razor that is suitable for cutting the bone that has been perforated by the rasure (or saw) is described in this section.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The tip of this triangle is sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	This is from a medieval Latin translation of an Arabic textbook on surgery by Albucasis. The phrase "Fit ex Indi." translates to "It comes from India." in English.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it is fitting that all that we have mentioned be made from razors, and knives, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	¶ Regarding the cutting of the tip and the closure of the bone.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrefy, either from an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you are treating the decay with medicine and it does not improve: and you see the decay spreading to the member, which does not send out anything: then it is necessary to cut into that member until the decay has spread as far as where the member is weakened by death or by a greater defect in the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that happens to it is that the member is weakened, until it is thought that: that fire has consumed it, or that it has putrefied after being blackened: until the putrefaction spreads to the whole of the member, and grips it.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when cutting into it, and similarly if the cause of the decay is from the strike of some poisonous creatures, such as scorpions of the sea, and spiders, and wasps, and the like: then it is necessary to do so.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If then the decay or the strike is at the tip of the finger, then cut the finger, and do not leave any space for the decay to spread to the other hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root of the finger, and do not leave any space for the decay to spread to the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it spreads to the arm, then cut it at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however you observe corruption passing through it, and look at it about the hip: then in that place is the death of the weak.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer beyond that, is the quantity of strength.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly, do to the foot, when corruption reaches the finger, then cut it at one of the nodes: and if it reaches the heart of the foot, then cut the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it ascends to the knee, then cut the thigh at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That is if corruption has already passed above the knee, then there is no intelligence left except release and leaving the weak to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of cutting the limb, or rather binding it, is to draw the ligament in the lower part which you intend to cut, and draw another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend the other ligament downwards: and extend another ligament upwards to the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And then you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with the sole of your foot, until the whole flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is cut or bound.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary to put on bandages from all sides with linen cloth, and do not let the scarlet touch the healthy place: and the weak wound will heal up with a hot apostematic plaster.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If however the flow of blood internally happens while you are working, then cauterize the place slightly: or put on some children's abscessing above it to absorb the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine, until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a convenient ligament, and take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that something happens to the man in his foot, this is the same thing that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What is this, because it happens in his foot, with the ash that resembles the combustion of fire: and that corruption first occurs in his thumb, until it begins to affect the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the man arose from himself, after he saw the corruption spreading to his member, which he found from pain and ash: and it spread to the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, it happened to him that same corruption in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to recover that excess with the one I had put on his hand after the purification of his body with medicines: and it was not repercussed, and it began to move to another thumb: until it began to corrupt in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to apply it to his hand: and I did not do that, hoping for the cure of his excess from the repercussion of that one: and I feared even the death of him at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's virtue was above the accident.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had despairing of me, he returned to his earth: and came to me from it, because he had been healed, and the corruption spread to his entire hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not seek this narrative, unless it be an aid to that which falls from the generation of this disease: and so that it have a signification, and according to which it is spoken.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Regarding the care of Sinus, and the quality of clisterization with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 10.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a gangrene occurs in some of the fleshy parts, and it prolongs the space of the gangrene until the collection of pus: then it bursts, or perforates, and departs from what is in it, and leaves a watery place as if it were water: and the skin which is over it, like a piece of cloth that has been made fine: and it does not reach the end of his corruption, nor imprints in the mouth, nor in the tendons, nor in the ligaments: he deserves to be called Sinus: and it is not called Fistula: but if the space of its gangrene prolongs until it imprints corruption in something of these parts, then it is called Fistula, or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	The treatment for this is to incise the entire skin in the same direction as it unfolds: and especially when it has been made fine and like a cloth: and I am confident that it will not adhere to its place due to its own corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	However, if you hope that the skin will adhere and does not follow the last corruption: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh: then treat it with Clister as you consider for the Sea.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a fetid odor: then treat it with Clister as you receive the Egyptian medicine, which is a mixture of vinegar, oil, and zinc, and are received in equal parts, and are boiled over fire until the medicine turns red: and it comes to a thick consistency like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and Clisterize with the Sea: and tie the opening of it, and release the medicine into it for the amount of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with a smile: and do this for several days until the Sea is cleansed and the odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is Clisterized with ashes and water, when the medicine is not present to you: and it is, that when you take the ash of wood or the ash of oak: and throw it over it with water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then eat it, and Clisterize with it, until you are confident that the Sea has washed it.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient is not able to tolerate the Egyptian medicine, nor the ashes and water: then Clisterize it with water and honey, which has already been mixed with some of the ground zinc.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Whenever you wish to dress a wound with pitch and honey, it is proper to mix them together, because of the property of honey to cleanse and to wash: and honey makes wine adhere to the skin, especially when there are superfluities of stinching and drying properties in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this several times, and I am confident that the decay is already removed: then apply pitch and honey to the wound itself, which he causes to produce flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is that you take from the plaster, and dissolve it with olive oil, and warm wine: or apply pitch to the wound with some medicines and ointments, whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the wound is narrow, in which the cannula of the clister does not fit: then enlarge it with iron, or place in it an intact lock of hair in Egyptian ointment, or in basilic ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if it is also wide, then gather the lips of the wound with the suture: and let out of it the amount that enters the clister without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening of it from which pus runs is elevated to the upper parts: then dry it in a lower place within itself, so that the pus may run down from it into the lower part: for when the pus is contracted in depth, it prevents the production of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to dry the wound below it according to your wish: then try, as if you were preparing the member in preparation for the pus to run down from it according to how it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try not to hold anything of the pus entirely within it: and take the solidified remedies which are placed above the sign, agreeable to what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	Extend it over a layer of linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	The linen should be of such a size that it allows for the entire wound to be covered.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then make an incision with sutures along the direct opening of the sinus, almost up to the sinus opening.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then apply a gentle ointment over the linen, according to the size of the opening: and place it above the position, far from the sinus opening, so that the pus would come out from there: and you will not remove the large linen piece unless after some days one.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	However, the one who is above the sinus opening is the one that you remove at all times, so as to come out what is gathered in it from the pus: and so you will know if that which runs out of it is much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you again consider the place of the sinus of that one, whether the lord of it feels pain there, or not, or if there is pain there, or not, and if there is not an aposteme.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you extend your treatment in this way, and see what comes out from the sinus opening, then you know that the sinus is stuck, or is approaching stickiness: then you will loosen it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you loosen it, then change the linen piece, and apply the ointment again.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	However, if it comes out from the sinus after a long distance, then do not despair of its sticking, because the healing of it is approaching, for there are men who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act against it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	However, if it comes out from the sinus after many days of indigested pus, then you will know that the sinus does not stick.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If then the adhesion of the sinus is slow and prolonged, and then add to the drying of the physicians, let them be such that they are moist in their substance and dry in their virtue, as ointment dyafinicon, when superfluities of addition are added to it from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the latter part of which it is treated, take ointment dyafinicon and dissolve it with pink oil, and pour it over the old wine equal in substance to it.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then close it up with this and use it yourself.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does a similar action when there is no ointment dyafinicon near you, honey, when you extract it, until it thickens, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, frankincense, and olibanum, and bruise them all together, and while it is over the fire, make it smooth on the honey.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then lay a linen cloth over it, and bind it tightly over the sinus: and when you have extracted the honey that has been boiled until it thickens, and made it smooth on the honey, and place the linen cloth over it and bind it tightly.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when the long aristolochia is given in that, and the celestial lily roots, and the lily: and the herb flour, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them either simple or mixed, and bruise them, and make the cribella itself: and make it smooth on the honey that I will tell you to use, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the sinus is prolonged and not cured by this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depth: or already makes an impression on the bones, or in other hard members, or in the ligaments: then treat it according to the treatment of fistulas as I have previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	The treatment of Panaritis and the wearing down of the nail, together with the addition of a cut to the digit and a section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 11.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a blister that is born under the nail of the hand or foot, and perhaps it is born in other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When this affliction is prolonged and neglected, and the blister becomes hot: or it corrupts, and emits pus, until it corrodes the root of the nail: and perhaps it corrupts the whole of it, and perhaps the corruption spreads to the bone, until it has an offensive odor: and the tip of the digit becomes swollen, and its color becomes black.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you are treating it, when you have done what we said in the section about division, and the treatment does not agree with it: then it is necessary to cut with iron all the remaining excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Cauterization is a remedy for ulcers.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the additions of the nail are already compressing the flesh towards the interior, and beginning to prick it, and hurt it: then it is necessary to put on a thin layer of plum under the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and press it upwards: and cut it with ease, and place on top of what remains of the flesh from medicines that are burning and corrupting, until the whole of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If the corruption has already pricked the bone: then it is necessary to cut the bone, and take it out: for it is never healed while the corrupted bone remains in the place.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption about to enter the finger, then cut it off at one of its nodes, according to what has been remembered about it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it itself, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	However, if there is an erosion or a blow to the nail, and pain arises in it, then it is necessary to first make an incision in the weakest part.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then scrape off the nail with a sharp salt section, from above towards the mouth.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard against it being cut into the flesh beneath the nail, for you are causing this by the weakest pain, and it will be a cause for adding tissue to the place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then take care of the place with that which soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the finger that is added to some human hands may be entirely fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and some of them are born from the root of the joint, or it is a birth of its kind in some nodes of the fingers.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, that which is born in some nodes of the fingers does not move: and that which is born at the joint of the fingers may move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, of those which are from them, the cutting is easy for the fleshy ones.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That which is, that you cut it off at its own root with a sharp salt on both sides.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	However, the care of that which has a birth in the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, do not make an incision in it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	However, in that which is born at the end of the fingers, then it is necessary to make an incision in its first flesh round up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of the bones of the same kind that is suitable for this.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it itself, until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the consolidation that happens to the fingers is often due to the man's nature, that is, born with him, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from combustion of fire, and such things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it must leave that consolidation until the fingers return according to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place a thread or softly infused linen in rose oil: so that they do not quickly consolidate, and separate them: or place a thin platinum sheet between them, until the place consolidates according to what is appropriate.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if a consolidation happens to some fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation according to what is prepared and becomes the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Of the incision.
Caput XCII.	Head 12.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	The veins are wrapped up, thick, full of superfluous melancholic swellings that happen in many parts of the body: and the most frequent of them is in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and labor, and carry.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it must apply a massage to the body from black bile with a strong exhaustion.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then make a phlebitomy on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these is according to two methods with iron.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	They are uncouth, so they will be cut, and black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is to make the vein hollow and draw out all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of this is according to this mode.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Scrub the crus with hot water first, until the coarse, feces-like blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the weak crus from its superior part of the thigh, down to the inferior part of the knee with thread.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then draw out, that is, extract blood in your hand from the lower part of the thigh, up to the top, and the weak one must be drawn out first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut off the nail until it goes out of the amount of blood you see is sufficient, and that the weak one can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it: and tell him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and do not harm the weak one.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	However, this is the way of his leeching.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the weak crus if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce it into the bath: or rub it on the thigh of the crus with hot water, until it reddens and the veins swell, or exercise it strongly if there is no bath nearby, until the member becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut off the skin in a direct vena section along its length, or at the end of it at the knee, or at the lower part of it at the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hairs, and scrub the vein from all parts until it becomes visible to the touch: and it is at the appearance of this, which you see red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the skin, you will see it white as a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the radium under it, until when it is fully expanded and emerges from the skin: suspend it with a cat's eye, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry another section near that section of three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrub the skin from the upper part of the wound, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then expand it with the radium as you have done, and suspend it with another cat's eye, as you have done at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another section, or more sections, if you need those.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then expand it, and cut the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until it comes out from the section above it, or from all higher sections, until it entirely emerges: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you to extract and expand: then insert a needle with strong thread twice, and tie it, and pull it out: or insert the radium under it: and roll your hand over all parts until it emerges.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful that it does not cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it becomes difficult for you to expand it gently, and it emerges above the weakest part of it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have completely extracted it: then place a piece of damp lint under the wound, submerged in wine and rose oil, or rose oil: and care for it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vine is contracted, having a winding which it is to be folded to the parts, and not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary to cover over on it to all parts of its winding, and the place of involution of its own.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with threads, until it expands completely: and be careful not to cut the wound or the scars at your own section above it, for it will be difficult for you to expand or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Take heed of your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the incident on which grapes are cured.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the blind man.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	The form of the blind man is not like the others, nor is it sharp at the extremities, so it will not wound the eye: and it is heavy with folds, soft: for if it were subtle, it would catch the eye with its subtility: moreover, it is superfluous in its heaviness, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Of the extraction of the thigh vein.
Caput XCIII.	Head 13.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in hot terrestrial lands, such as Algiers, and in the Arab lands, and in hot, dry lands, few arid lands, that is, in which there is no growth of herbs or trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Indeed, its generation is from putrefaction which happens under the skin, just as happens inside the bodies of snakes and ascaris worms, and the worms that are generated between the skin and the flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of this vein is that which happens in the thigh inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then it becomes a wound.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to issue from the place of that wound, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore you see the extremity of that vein, then it is necessary to suspend a lead weight on the same fragment of lead, whose weight is from one drachm to two drachms and a half, and release the suspended lead from the thigh.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	When therefore something issues from that vein towards the outside, suspend it in the lead, and release the lead with the node.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged for a long time, then cut out a part of it and bandage the remaining part.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it deeply before it has completely grown out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and goes into the flesh: it causes an abscess, putridity in its place, and a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it carefully and remove it gradually until it comes out completely from the end of its own body, and there should be nothing left in the body: and from this very vein, which is in some men five fingerbreadths long and ten, it comes out into certain people.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has already yielded to me because it expelled a man from twenty fingers.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it is cut on your day of medication: then insert the root into its opening, and make a long hole through the body with it, until all that is in it from the matter is expelled: and administer putridity to the place with medicines for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of the abscess itself by the cure of the abscess.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this very vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings happen to it, and it comes out from all the openings of the branch.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore take care of it as I said in the division, and with what has been said before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ About the cutting of the worms generated under the skin, and it is called bunion.
Caput XCIIII.	Caput XCIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This affliction is called in our land the Aegritudo bouina: because it happens often to the bougs, and it is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	When it moves throughout the whole body, ascending and descending: and is shown to the sense during walking, from one member to another, until it reaches wherever it may tear, and then it goes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from putrefaction of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	So do vermin and snakes, that is, slugs, and worms, in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it fears from its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	For when it itself moves through the body, and ascends to the head, and goes around to the place: then perhaps it opens in it, and goes out, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and to take it out, then this is not done except during walking, and by the sense of its own being.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary to tie what is above it, and what is under it with a strong constriction bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and take it out from above.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it pierces into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place over the place a cauterization with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than what you fear, is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see it already ascended to the head near the eye: then tie under it a good tightened brow bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and take it out from above.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that he use a weak cleansing of his body, when the physicians are curing putrefying humors with bad drugs.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of food generating putrefaction for himself.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	¶ About the cutting on the sickness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called Nakir in our land: it is a pain that occurs in some parts of the body, and then shifts from one part to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have already seen it, according to what I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I am called to a weak woman in some cases of labor.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she pushes out her arm, and I see a slight swelling in the new flesh of her arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour has passed, I see one swelling to rise with the flesh, as the embryo rises to the shoulder, ascending to a higher place than it can be: so that it is like silver when it runs from one place to another.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore, the pain departed from that place and fixed itself in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and she ran to the rest of her body until it became saturated in the arm with something else.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that she was rolling over in her whole body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	Therefore, I was amazed at the swiftness of its shifting from one part to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had not seen this disease in that way before.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Nevertheless, I have seen many who found the pain to shift from one part to another: and I did not see it with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is so, unless it is because the woman was of those who are detected by the dry parts of the body for their wetness: therefore, it appears to the senses that the vapor has shifted.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and in the bodies of the moist, of the hidden vapors.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you wish to treat it and the patient feels the pain of it: then, if the eye is visible to you, as we said, then draw a line above it, and quickly below it: and dry the area around it, until the entangled vapor escapes: and cauterize the spot.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with the movement of the body, and with that which expels the vapors, and causes them to be carinated with rancid pills, and pills of serapine, and such like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	¶ About the Extraction of the Arrow.
Caput XCVI.	Head 46.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are diversified according to their kinds and the places where they strike from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is that: for among them there are some which have large points, and small ones: and sharp-pointed, and rough-pointed.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them there are some which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them there are some which have a tongue.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them there are some which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to the parts where they strike, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or if the parts be from the principal members, as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lungs, and kidneys, and intestines, and uterus, and such like.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When then the arrow strikes into one of these parts, and you see signs of death which I will tell you later, it is necessary to make an extraction of that arrow from thence, for death follows it in many ways.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see those signs of evil, and the arrow is not hidden deep in the member, then take it out, and heal the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When an arrow falls on the brain, and pierces the mouth, and exits through the eye, it is because such a wound causes soda to flow, dizziness, vertigo, redness in the eyes, swelling of the tongue, spasm of the muscles, mixture of intellect, and vomiting of choler.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may flow from the ears, or out of the nostrils.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And white fluid may flow from the wound site.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And similar water-like flesh exits from there.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs seem to you, then stop the treatment, and remove the arrow if it does not exit.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls on the heart are: that it is near the left breast: and it feels as if it is fixed in hard things, not in soft things.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a similar motion to that of the pulse: and it runs from the elbow black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And it follows this cold at the extremities, and cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore, you know that death has descended far from doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the arrow when it wounds the lung is the exit of foaming blood from the elbow: and the wound that follows the neck, becomes red, and the weak color changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great breath is expelled high: and it seeks the cold air's attraction.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	And if the arrow falls on the vein, which is in the breast: then it is near the costal muscles: and there is a great thirst with painful dullness, with sighing: and all the humeral muscles move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If an arrow falls into the stomach, perhaps it will then exit through the thigh, carrying with it something undigested from the food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If an arrow falls into the belly, and sticks in it, something of the kind of dung comes out through the thigh, or a piece of excrement, or a part of the intestine that is already torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope in the treatment of this, nor in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and exits with urine, and something comes out from it to the outside, and the pain is greater on the weakest part: then you know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining parts, such as the face, neck, throat, larynx, trapezius, shoulder blades, hip, leg, and foot, are healed according to several dispositions: when the arrow does not hit an artery or a nerve, and it is not a poisoned arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen the nature of these arrows, so that you understand through this about your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore, I drew it out from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was cured, and there was no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	I also drew out another arrow from a Jew, which fell into the fat of his eye below the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I only caught hold of its end with the tip of my finger, when it adhered to the wood of his bow: and it was a large arrow from the bows of the Turks, with soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew is therefore cured, and there is no harmful accident to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the mouth of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabian arrow, and those are its ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore held it above the same two girdles: and it had already been swallowed by his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was thus diligent with them, until I extracted it: and the Christian is cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed, and nothing had changed in his circumstances, I held it above the arrow: and I touched it, and extracted it: and he is cured, and there is no harmful accident to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man who had fallen into his back, and the rib was healed over on it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, the arrow was extracted from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman who had fallen into her belly with the arrow, and the rib was healed over on it, and the arrow remained inside of it, and nothing had changed in her circumstances, and the woman did not find any harm from any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man who had fallen into his face with the arrow, and the rib was healed over on it, and it remained, not finding him much pain, and such like many things.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the King's principals, who had fallen into his middle of his nose, and it had already leaned towards the right side: and the arrow was hidden completely.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I am called to care for him after the arrow wound, up to three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I then cut the pointed arrow tightly with a knife.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I then questioned it with gentle trials, and did not find it: and he himself found the point and the pain under his own gold on his right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I then hoped that it was the point of the arrow from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I then applied the plaster to the place with the plaster where the virtue attracted and digested, confident among me that it would be the spot where the arrow would be hit, and a sign of the arrow would appear to me so that I could cut on it: but it did not happen in the place meaning that the arrow had reached the spot.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I then applied the plaster to it day after day: and nothing happened, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime: but it remained weak for the extraction of that space of days, until he felt the arrow in his own nose one day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I then applied sharp medicine to it for many days until it was open: and when I tried to try it, and felt the point of the thin arrow that adhered to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until the point of the arrow was visible to us: and it passed by me within about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the wound was enlarged, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey the exit: I did not stop to refine, and to invent ways with the hands, until I once extracted it on a day with forceps made according to their form, according to which they want the end of the fingers, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I will restore the flap.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed, the physician says that the nasal cartilage cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restore it myself, and the flap is consolidated, and the patient is cured of his weakness in good health, without causing him any harm at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of several arrows: so place that rule and meaning over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended with narration: nor does that book comprehend it, and the wise artificer compares a little with much: and when he sees what is present, he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descending things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, that arrows do not issue from the limbs in which they are fixed, unless by two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite side of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those which issue from where it entered, are an arrow proceeding into the flesh, and is attracted and issues forth.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not submit to the exit from the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary to release it for a few days, until the putrefying flesh around it releases its attraction and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is formed in the bone, and does not submit to your exit: then release it for a few days: and then try it again with its attraction and motion every day until it issues forth.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	And if it does not submit to your exit after a day: then it is necessary to open the bone around the arrow in the same bone from all sides with a fine chisel, until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then pull it out and extract the same one.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	However, if the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already passed into one of the brain lobes, and it appears that some of the aforementioned symptoms are present: then stop pulling on the arrow and release it, until it is equal in size the next day.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow pierces the skull, then death will not be prolonged to him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed only in the bones, but does not penetrate up to the skull, and remains weak for a few days, and no such symptoms occur from them: then the intelligence in the removal of the arrow and its extraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	However, if the arrow is fixed firmly and does not obey your pull: then apply a blister around the arrow, as I will describe to you: then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	However, if the arrow is already hidden in the body, and hidden and concealed from sensation: then search for it with caution.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	However, if you feel it: then pull it out with some instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	However, if you cannot reach it due to the constriction of the wound, and due to the length of the arrow in the deep part: and there is no bone, nerve, or vein above it: then find something above it until the wound is amplified and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If the ears to which it is tied are present: then free the flesh that is fixed in them from all sides, by any means you can think of, and intelligence, if not possible through the fracture of the ear and its twist, until it comes loose.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the extraction of the arrow, in whatever part it is, then use a twist of your hand with the needles to all parts, until you make it come loose: and with a subtle final subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and it be difficult for you to attract its attraction and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot operate on it at once, delay the operation for a few days until the putrid matter around it has putrefied.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the operation: for if it makes a contrary current of blood, then administer what I said in the chapter on treatment: and preserve your health from wounds, or nerves, or strings.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And apply all methods of archery you can think of for release: and let it be with ease, calmness, slowness, or firmness, as I have described to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it must be that when you draw the arrow, it is weak according to its figure, as was at the case of the arrow in itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more difficult.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If, however, you cannot do that, then apply what is possible to you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow that is going out from the opposite side of another part, or already going out from it something to the outside: or it makes a bulging at the end of the arrow through the sense of the skin of the nearest part, and you see it prominent: then cut over it, and let the section be according to the amount that is caught in the screws.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it back: for it itself makes it easy to go out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrow prints itself in the bone, and enlarges itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: delay the operation for a few days, then repeat it until it goes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the wood of the arrow is in it, then push it with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the wood of the arrow has fallen, and you wish to give it impulse: then insert with an instrument a concave one, so that its concavity reaches the end of the arrow: then push it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If, however, the wound is closed, then push it with the instrument as it is being inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	Indeed, the wound is closed by this.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If, however, the wound is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out the entire flesh in which the pox is, if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with that which comes to that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If, however, the wound is falling into the chest, or in the belly, or in the side, or on the back: and it is near to that which you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut it, and be careful not to cut into the pox, or a nerve, and take it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then if you see your gouernor, and take care of that, until it be healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the Forciptum, by which they take out the wound.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities should be like a face, with teeth, which are made like iron: when they take hold of the wound above the Sagita, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And they are many kinds of them, great and small, and medium, according to the magnitude of the wound, and the thinness of the wound, and the breadth of the wound, and the constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the pusher is a conga.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the pusher is deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the deaf end like a radius, so that the introduction of its enter may be closed with the Sagita, and it is pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The end of the pusher's conga is a conga like a beak: so that the introduction of the Sagita into it and its push may be closed.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	¶ About Bloodletting of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XCVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty types of venepuncture, which is a customary practice in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	There are sixteen types of veins in the head: two pulsating veins called the Azymes, and two arteries that appear in two temples: two veins in the two lacrimal bags of the two eyes, known as the Aspicientes: a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead: and a vein in the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi veins in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins in the upper lip of the mouth.
