Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins in the lower lip of the mouth.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are the veins known as Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, veins that are punctured in the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it is on the side of the forehead: and it is called the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Black vein.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the Middle vein is composed of the Basilic and Cephalic branches: and it is called the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilic vein is placed on the side of the domestic arm: and it is also called the Titillating vein.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is called the vein of the breathing.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the funiculus of the arm is placed on the focus: and it is that through which puncturing occurs, and it is that which appears above the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Salute vein: and it is a vein that is between the annulus and the minimum: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the groin and foot, there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is beneath the curved part of the thumb, from the side of the nail.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second one is the Saphenous vein: its location is beneath the heel, from the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The third one is the Nerve of the Great Toe: its location is beneath the heel, from the opposite side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the groin, there are three more veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding phlebitis of two veins after the Auerus.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	However, the phlebitis of two veins that are after the Auerus is a treatment for old cataracts, and the hemigathes, and the saffron, and the bad old ulcer of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebitis is according to what I am saying.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the weak is stretched: and the scalp of it is rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth good rubbing.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak stretches his neck with his tongue, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are after the Auerus in two depressions of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, seek them with your thumb, and where you feel the pulse of these under your thumb, there make signs with a candle.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the phlebotomy tool, and that is the one that is said to be Incidental.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomy goes to the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin over it, and cut the vein with the skin incidental incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision is the quantity of two fingers joined, or about this: and make it to come out of the blood as much as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tighten it with threads, and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And it has already been preceded at the beginning of the book, and its own cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	¶ About the sucking of two arteries in times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	However, the two arteries that are in the two times of phlebotomy are the old one for the hemigeneia: and it is sodded with prauam, and obtalmied with assiduousness: and the course of the excessive acute effusions is made to flow to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the sucking is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak one should tightly tie his neck much, until the two veins become visible by their own manifest appearance: and it will be shown under your thumb the pulse of them.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs will be with the cauterization.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then tear the skin of the vein upwards with your thumb, and insert the sucking under the incidence, and tear the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And incise it, as you did in the other two veins: and let it run through the blood according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then dissolve the weak coartation, and put your thumb on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place it on the same belly and pulsi, and tighten it from the strong constriction: and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And it has already been preceded in the rememoration of them, and their own incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	¶ About the sucking of the vein of the front after the sucking of the cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	However, the sucking of the vein of the front is after the sucking of the cephalic vein, to the old diseases of the face: and to the hemigeneia, and the redness: and the grievous ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of his phlebotomy is, according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	His feeble neck is coapted with his throat until the beast appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called the Fossorial one.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is the form of it.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent acumen which is on the head of the Fossorial one above the beast and thrust it through with your thumb or with another tool in the same way: and let the blood run according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then dissolve the weak perforation, and tie it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it opens with the phlebotomist's side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it should not be a sharp-pointed phlebotomist like the others, but rather a wide-ended one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy of it according to transfusion: for the mouth is near: and perhaps in it the phlebotomist breaks when it is fine.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	¶ About the phlebitis of the Veins in two Lachrymal ones.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	However, the humor of the two veins which are in the two Lachrymal ones of the two eyes is to the eye from scabs and redness: and it is in the eye, and it causes afflictions of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is such that it coaptes his feeble neck with his throat.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then do the phlebotomy of it: and you will be standing over its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebitis be according to the transfusion to a short length when the phlebotomist is small, wide, because there is no flesh: for it is not in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is sharp-pointed at the end, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make the blood circulate as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a bandage over them, and tie it tightly at night, and unbind it in the morning.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	¶ About Bloodletting of the Nostrils.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	However, bloodletting of the nostrils is done for acute fever, severe thirst, and facial ailments such as migraine or redness that occurs on the face, especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of this bloodletting is that it tightens the weak neck of its own.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold the nostril of this one with your left hand, and take a fine bloodletting, long: and thrust it in the middle of the nose of this one, between that which distinguishes the nostril according to its uprightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the nostril does not appear to the senses there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary to let go of your hand with the bloodletting as soon as possible: and make the blood circulate according to your necessity.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then tie it tightly at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it restores quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	¶ About Bloodletting of the Nostrils, by Guidegi:
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	However, the bloodletting of two Guidegi is for constriction of thirst, and the onset of leprosy, and melancholic ailments, and impetigo and ulcers bad, and corrosive, that is, herpes is said to be.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of this bloodletting is that it tightens the weak neck with both on each side with a tie: and let the artificer stand over the head of the weak, and the weak is sitting over its own seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then make the bloodletting of the nostril as wide as possible.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then remove an equal amount of tempered blood from outside. Or according to what you see, there is a need for this.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with another kind of urine.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards loosen the ligament, and tie two urethral strictures in the middle: so that the weak will not be affected.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And release it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the arm will be cured.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	¶ About the phlebitis of the veins of Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	However, the veins of Algeberich are subject to phlebitis because they are prone to alcohol in the mouth, corruption of the gums, bad ulcers, and openings in the lips, as well as ulcers that are even in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebitis is such that you should make them sit weak before you, and tie the neck of it with a cord.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then roll the lip of it, and look at the two urethras: one is from the right side of the lip, and the other from the left side, and the demonstration of both is by blackening of the gums.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true because there are small and black veins around it.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore make an incision in both incisions that are approaching.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	However, if you doubt about me, and do not know what it is: then consider to the greater incision of its, and the most visible one of them.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do to the two urethras that are on the upper lip: and most of all is the custom with it: and make two incisions in the two urethras that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	¶ About the phlebitis of the vein under the tongue after the cephalic vein phlebitis.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Two of the veins that are under the phlebitic swelling are: that the cephalic vein is for the preforation which are in the throat, and the weakness of the eye, and the weaknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that it should be weak between your hands in front of the sun: and the language of its veins, and look under the tongue from one side of it, and from the other side of it: and the color of both of them should incline to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore, the phlebitic swelling on both sides: and guard, lest at the end of your hand in phlebotomy, you.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under these are arteries, and perhaps there may be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	¶ Of the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	However, the three veins that are phlebitic in the elbow, are those that have become customary in all men's phlebotomy.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by pressing with the myrtle phlebotomy wide: or by olive oil to the subtlety of it: or by drying with the phlebotomy of the cultivator, and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, which is convenient for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these are the flat and the subtle ones, and the largeness of the veins and their strictness of the form of the myrtle phlebotomy is flat, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is convenient for the opening of the eyelids, the full ones, the proceeding, the apparent, the heavy, and those which contain the thick blood, the turbid.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This small vein is of less width and more delicate at its extremity.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It can be applied to the veins of the subtle golden blood that is contained in them.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Regarding the phlebitis of the Basilican vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, the Basilican vein among the three veins of blood is the one that needs to be opened.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments that are under the throat and neck, from which it follows the chest, and the vein: and it can be opened by the surgeon with the phlebotomy tool on it, so as not to cause fear from it, for there is an artery under it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If then he errs, and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will incise that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore, it is necessary for the surgeon not to open the vein with a sharp phlebotomy tool, but rather to be gentle with it, and to be careful with Alne's silk.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the Basilican appearance does not seem clear, then it is necessary to remove it and change it to another, or ask someone about its branch: or use the phlebotomy site as the fun of the thigh.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is clear and you should dry it with Alne's silk, as I have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you want to open the vein of the same one, then it is necessary before tightening the thigh, to touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then make signs on the place with the encaustic, then the thigh, and dry the vein section with Alne's silk, as I have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And be careful not to fall the impact through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	When you see, when you tie the bandage, the inflammation in the place that you marked with the burn, then that inflammation is an arterial inflammation: therefore it is extinguished.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood flowing at a vein-cutting, like the urine of a child, and it is a thin, red blood: then you know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then accordingly, and place your thumb over the space for a long time, then take back your thumb.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then tie the arm, and let it go: and let the weak one be afraid of its motion: and let it be above his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And it will not move it for days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If the blood is not cut off, and does not stop you: and there is no one present in your moment of medicine, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its ends contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of leather, and find it: take a half of it, and tie it over the place of the vagina's tightening, with the bandage and the pulleys until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of it with the one whose remembrance precedes the flow of blood from the child's wound: and the cutting of his blood is not difficult in many positions, because of the small wound and the possibility of the bandage from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	¶ About the venous hemorrhage of Fuscus.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	However, the venous hemorrhage of Fuscus is the juice, which draws blood from the superior part of the head, and the inferior part of the body: for it is composed of the Basilic branch, and the Cephalic branch, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	The bloodletting surgeon finds it suitable for this purpose, as there is a nerve under it, so that it should be done with caution due to the risk of damaging the nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	Therefore, if he adds to the puncture of bloodletting and finds a nerve, there may be unconsciousness, and it becomes difficult to cure him, and perhaps he will not recover completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to the senses.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	However, if it is hidden in some people, and is subtle, and not shown: then you should perform your bloodletting on it, with a section like Alnesil, and cut the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If there is a vein between two nerves, then find the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Regarding the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	However, the bloodletting of the cephalic vein is a stimulant, because it attracts blood from the head and leads to eye diseases.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is appropriate in this vein, if you wish, to bloodlet it by puncturing it with an olive-oil phlebotomy needle, or with a myrtle-oil phlebotomy needle: because it is the easiest vein of all, because there is no subcutaneous artery, and no nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it suits you during bloodletting to use a knife with the phlebotomy needle, and to seek a gentler place: and it will not harm it if it is not found by first percussion, so that it may return above it with repeated bloodletting.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However, it may cry out in some people when not bloodletted by first percussion, but it will not hurt them that cry.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Regarding the utility of bloodletting and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality and accidents of phlebotomy, and those that occur with its correction, are things you should consider.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, it is necessary to know that phlebotomy is not administered except in the preservation of health, and with perseverance in it, and caution against the coming of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And it should be done in one arm of three, which are in the elbow, namely the cephalic, and the black, and the basilican.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And it should be done in the beginning of spring after fasting, in the truth, and in summer: and in autumn and winter after eating, when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And it should be done on the first day, or on the third day, after the three hours have passed since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, the phlebotomy that is administered in diseases does not have a determined hour: but when convenience and need for it are presented, it can be done at night or day, and in every hour, and in every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it should not be done on children until they are over fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be bled, unless from the fourth month to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old men be bled, who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	But when anyone wishes to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that he cleanses his intestines before the bleeding with a mild clyster, if there is much fecal matter retained in them: so that the veins do not attract the putrid superfluities of the intestines which are noxious to the principal membranes.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient be bled on the eve of the full moon, that is, from satiety, nausea: nor a drunkard, nor one who is drunken, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor is one weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let it be caused again by phlebotomy after the passing of a fit of passion, and vomiting, and flux of the humors, and multiplication of coitus, and labor, and exercise, and fasting, and all that dissolves strength from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if blood is coarse with food and drinks, and medicines: if possible, do this.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him take a bath, if nothing forbids it: or exercise in some exercise, to make the blood more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy of his heart in the breast, around the third day, as we said: and may it be that his breast pounds on that day from all the evil animal occurrences: such as narrowness, and anger, and fear: and from all the body occurrences, such as labor, and pain, and superfluity, and these like.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him seat himself and make these things to be present with which he used to run his course custom of men from aromaticity, and odor, and tribulation, and such like in quantity as possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist seat himself on a higher place than the place of phlebotomy, and then take his arm and rub it with his own hand twice, or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should tie the ligament with the corrections, and unfold it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the tie should be temperate, for when it is unequal or through superfluity in the tie, it prevents the course of the blood: or in the mollification, it also prevents the course of the blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tie, it is necessary that he rub his phlebotomy hand with both hands until the wetness comes and declares to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist will remove blood with a little oil, properly called for.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he will place his thumb on the left hand over the vein where he wants to draw blood, a little: so as not to cause pain, and press down gently.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For the vein is like a fleeing chord at surgery, and it is the one that is full of vitality: and when you place the blood over it, it contracts under the bloodletting, and deceives the bloodletter, and does not open the vein: and if it opens, it is tight: therefore, it is necessary for the bloodletter to be firm and attentive to all things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he will let go of the blood.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then, it opens the vein from the oil alone, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then try this oil elsewhere, or above it with haste: if it does not cause the place to bleed.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it causes the place to bleed, or weakens it, then let him give it one day, or two days: and do not tighten the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it will draw the hot burn.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he will repeat the bloodletting if he likes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If it is small, or runs blood thinly: and be careful not to let too much blood escape: then repeat the bloodletting through the same hole according to its direction, and add a little to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste, before the place bleeds, for the bleeding place is in many people at a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see it already bleeding, then do not repeat it completely, for it does not excuse anything in your eyes.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	Place something from the feces oil on top: for it helps in blood circulation.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	This is better in this place than the oil itself, and even better than the rest of the olive oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	Similarly, administer oil to all your phlebotomies wherever you restrict blood circulation: and they will become Tyrian brass, and sagger, when placed on one of them over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it happens in the site of a phlebotomy scar, which often happens, especially to those who are not phlebotomized except for the vein, or is an open small wound, then immediately and place on top of the water and salt, slightly heated, a sponge infused with blood, and string it for an hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary to do this after the end of blood from the same vein or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something black or blue remains in the place after several days, it will not harm you: and if you wish, place something on top of it, such as aloe or myrrh: or something from the juice of mint, that is, calamiter or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	Indeed, many occur at the site of the phlebotomy at the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore, place your hand on it, then if you find a soft spot under your compression on it, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, so that you can place something on top of it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of the artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for it with the one that has stipticity, so that the site becomes hard.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then he should attend to it himself with the rest of the treatment until he is cured.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that all men have the blood of their own strength removed in due proportion.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the color of the wine over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it be released to flow until it turns red: and so if you see it thick, then let it be released until it becomes thin: and so if it is sharp, then let it be released until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and requires a single extraction of blood to amplify the phlebotomy vein, and for the phlebotomus to be on the side: and in him who is weak, it should be opposite to that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary for him to draw it out in the veins, and for the foramen to be strict: and it is better that what is given in phlebotomy vein is a transuersa section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy by extension and breadth.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And whom it is customary to fast before phlebotomy syncopis, it is necessary that he eat a little bread soaked in wine before the phlebotomy: or if it is cold, let it be heated: and let him release it from the blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is frozen, then let him take before the phlebotomy a bread soaked in wine infusion, or in a syrup made from honey with spices, or in an aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If a syncopal episode occurs during phlebotomy and the cause of its blood exit is many, then it is necessary to take a hand of fresh flesh, a subtle odorous syrup, and use aromaticity with algae, and line the chest with this, and use the remaining ones that I mentioned in the division in the chapter of syncope from emesis.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	If someone wishes to achieve the release of his arm and the solution of his blood secondly, it is necessary for him whose phlebitis is due to emesis and his strength is weak, so that he releases blood gradually according to the amount of his strength over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	If however he wishes to achieve the release of his arm and the solution of his blood secondly, and his body is strong, then he should do this after seven hours or a new from his first phlebitis.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	If however he wishes to attract his blood from his body to the opposite part on which it leans, it is necessary for him to achieve release in the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	If however in his body there is already much heated blood, and sharpens, and causes fever to occur: it is necessary for him to withdraw much blood from the vein in one vinegar, and extract a large quantity from it: and extend the opening until a syncope occurs: after which you will preserve all conditions of phlebotomy: and how you will place your hand on the pulse of his course of blood, so that a death does not occur at the place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For this often happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant, and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when you wish to release the arm and release the blood secondly, when the orifice of the vein is already closed, and there is a difficult exit of blood, so that it be done with great force and the vein is extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	This is indeed an unpleasant wound, yet let it be released until the phlebotomist treats it a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	If you remove it with the sharpness of the phlebotomist when that which has been coagulated by blood from the opening of the vein is removed, and place something salted in water over it, it will be healed.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something from Tyrian tar over it, or pitch, and place a gentle compression on it until blood is drawn out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein has become hardened, let it be released and do not press it until it settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If something necessitates the second removal of blood and there is no excuse, then either the phlebotomy itself over that place or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	However, the band of the arm is phlebotomized at the place of the Fuscus and Basilicus veins, when they are not found, and they are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of that phlebotomy is such that she inserts her weak hand into hot water until it reddens and the vein is clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then she will gently compress over it with a medium degree of constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the second phlebotomy is made gradually, not laterally, nor according to length: and it should be widely open, and your phlebotomy that you have made over the joint of the hand almost.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the exit of the blood is forbidden, then she will repeat the hand in hot water, and let the blood run into water until she satisfies her need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	However, if you are in the days of summer, then you will excuse yourself from repeating the hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	The course of blood is particularly noted to flow in hot water at the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	The bloodletting of this kind is softer than in all other veins, because it is not subject to pressure, nor is the nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The bloodletting of the right hand of the salutary art is beneficial for the pains of the back.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	The quality of the bloodletting is such that you will tighten the big toe of your hand with the bandage, or with your own hand, after you have introduced it into hot water, until the vein becomes full, and it will be felt by the senses.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the bloodletting is transferred through the transfusion.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you apply it entirely, it will not harm that to any part of it.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And keep it, so as not to end with your hand when bloodletting.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For there are bare nerves of the fingers under it.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat your hand to hot water, and let the blood run through it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in hot water, the blood will coagulate in the opening of the vein, and it will be forbidden to run.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you withdraw the necessary quantity of blood from the blood, then put oil and salt on top of the vein, so that it does not stick together hastily.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And it is also necessary to do this when you tighten all the branches.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The juice of this bloodletting is: for it is beneficial for the pains of the spleen: and do the same in the bloodletting as you did in the second equal.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The juice of the saphenous bloodletting is for the pains that are in the lower part of the body, such as the pain of the womb, and retention of menstruation, and weakness of the liver, and old ulcers and sores of the thighs and knees, and such like from these diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	The quality of the phlebotomy procedure is such that it inserts the weakened foot of its own into hot water: and makes over it friction, until the waters become bloody: and ties above the joint of the foot with the correction.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	Indeed, the place of the blood is at the heel, appearing reversed thumb: and many branches of the legs are ramified from it on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, the phlebotomy is done in a wider branch of it, or at the heel in its gathering: for it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If however, phlebotomy is done on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves which are under it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy in such a way that it is done from the transuded blood, as if you were going to incite it: and let the phlebotomy be of Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	However, if the exit of the blood is forbidden, then you should insert the foot of its own into hot water: and let the blood run into it, until it becomes clear.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If however, the phlebotomist errs in the first drop of blood, then he will go with the phlebotomy to the higher parts, for it is safe and you do not fear any harm from it when you cause nerves as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly when the Saphena of the other foot is equal to it.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	However, the location of the Sciatic vein as we have said, is at the heel on the side of the leg.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the treatment of its phlebotomy is, to the pain of Anchaea, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is such that it enters the weakened bath and becomes firm: and he should tie the crus of his weak leg from the side of Anchaea to the heel above four fingers, with a thin long string: for it does not appear except for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When then you see it, then perform the phlebotomy according to your ability, either by suction or by transfusion: and it is better, or to cut it by incision, or to cut it by section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is more profitable, and it itself is hidden in the private parts of many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it, and it does not appear to the senses at all: then perform a phlebotomy on some branch of it, and that is the one that appears in the sole of the foot, and the ear-like one: and be careful of the nerves, and make the blood flow according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then dissolve the stricture, and place the corium over the site of the phlebitis, and tie the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it cures quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	¶ About the use of Ventilation and its quality.
Caput XCVIII.	Head 48.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventiles are made from the corners, and from air, and from earth.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventilation indeed happens in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarification, and the extraction of blood: and another is ventilation without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventilation which is without scarification, is in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Either it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilations which are given with scarification and the extraction of blood, are fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is Ventosation Alnocrati, and is the last of the head: and Alkehel, and is in the neck: and Ventosations Alhagdahim, and are two layers of the collar from two parts at once: and Ventosations of the mentum, and is under the mandible in the lower jaw: and Ventosations of two spatulas: and Ventosations of Alachosos on the end of the tail: and Ventosations of two focils, and are in the middle of two brachii: and Ventosations of two cuffs: and Ventosations of two cuanillae.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And Ventosation indeed does not draw blood from you of the finest particles scattered in the flesh, and for that reason it does not fail strength from them, just as is the case with its effect from phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not necessary to administer ventosation either with fire, or without fire, in certain diseases that arise from repletion, until the whole body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If the necessity for ventosation is provoked by the disease, or from custom, we administer it at all times at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and whenever the time may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is, because of men who when the blood increases in it, until they require an extraction from it by ventosation, find in their head a grauedinem, and a sodahan.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from them are those who find repletion and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from them are those who find pruritus in their face, and on their forehead, and a darkness, and a dullness in their eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from them are those who experience pain in the place of their own ventosation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from them are those whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from them are those who find a taste of blood in their mouth: or they spue out blood, and expel it.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from them are those whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from them are those who see in their sleep blood, and redness, and wounds, and similar things to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something of these, and especially if it is in the middle of the third month: we advise that ventosation be made to be performed, after the two hours have passed, or three.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The neck of the windpipe, is because it carries the old age to the head, and that which is poured out to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It should be, that this should be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And indeed, this is in the place of the cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it should not be used by one who has a cold complexion, or in which there is a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it does not bring large harm to him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And therefore, it should not be used by the old, and in whose head there are cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But if he is persistent on it, a forgetfulness is generated for him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And therefore, it should be that you precede the windpipe surgeon, so that he lowers his hand when it is almost wet to the lower parts, fearing the generation of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alkehel is in the place of the cephalic phlebotomy and the basilic phlebotomy, and for that reason it brings asmati, constriction, anhelitus, instrumental fissure anhelitus, tussis, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be that Alkehel ventosation is pressed upwards, because if it is laid down lower, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Alhagdahim ventosation brings painful accidents in the head, obtalmia, hemiglossal, perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in the place of the basilic phlebotomy.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it should be that you precede the windpipe surgeon, so that he does not lower his hand when shaving: so as not to rupture the artery, and to cause the flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventilation under the chin, wine is poured into the mouth, and corruption of the tongue, and similar to these from diseases that are in the mouth: and it is in place of phlebotomy, which are in two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventilation of the spatula, it is poured on the wine, which is made by reflection, and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventilation of the interior parts of the two spatulas, it is poured on the three veins of the thighs, basilic, and fuscus, and cephalic: for it draws blood from all these small veins that are in the flesh: and these small veins are drawn from other large veins until the attraction becomes attached to the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you be the first to ventilate, so that the process does not proceed too much in the scarification: for the place is bare of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	Ventilation however that becomes saturated on the wine, pours over the anus, and over the lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you be the first to ventilate so that it is large and comes from the air: for the place needs strong suction, and perhaps the small vents are broken, and the scarification is large.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Ventilation however reduces the bed diminutively: for it draws blood from the whole body, and conveys old pains to the renals, and matriculas, and uesica: it provokes menstruation, and conveys bothor and ademenul: and stand in the place of phlebotomy of two saphenous veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Indeed they weaken the body greatly, and cause syncope in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The proximity of the winds of Ventus is similar to the proximity of the winds of two cups.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the winds of Ventus is, that you place a wet vapor first, and then a gentle suction: and do not prolong the position of the winds, but place them lightly, and remove them lightly, so that the humors may come to the place in equal measure: and do not cease to repeat this until you see the place already reddened and inflamed, and the redness of the blood appears: then shave it, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For whoever is of soft flesh and rare bones, it is necessary that you shave it only once, not more: so as not to ulcerate the place.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And advise the Ventosator to enlarge the shaving, and make it deep, and temper the suction in ease, and lightness, and motion of its own.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickness in the blood, then it is necessary that you shave it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In water indeed the first opening is made for the subtilization of the blood and its aqueousness: and in the second, the pursuit of the sharp extraction of the thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is fecal and valley, then let the shaving of water be the third: so as to get the last.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And at last, when we want to draw the blood slightly, or rather, almost, a single shaving is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If indeed we want the extraction of the blood to be many, we shave it by multiple shavings.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary that it be shaved by deep shaving: and the terminal equal in the shaving, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which must be administered from oils at the position of the Winds, and what must be avoided in inhaling.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In the one where the skin is rough, hard, dark, and the pores of whose skin are narrow, it must be made to anoint the winds with oils that are open, soft, and dissolved, such as the oil of alkali, or the ointment of violets, or the ointment of the seeds of sweet almonds, or the ointment of the cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in the winter season, then the oil of narcissus, or the oil of lilies, or the oil of camomile, or saffron, and similar oils.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If there is superfluousness that is rough and cold, then the oil should be amaracin, or the oil of balsam, or the white oil, or the oil of anetum: and similar oils.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If inhaling is necessary through large pores of soft flesh, it must be prohibited from oil, and it must be made to wash the winds of those places with water that is rosy, or cold, or cold, or water of cucumbers, or water of celery: and similar oils.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of many moistures, washes the winds with vinegar, or with water of myrtle, and sumach: and similar oils.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whose superfluities are rough, he washes his own winds with old wine, or with cold water, or with the decoction of anetum, or with camomile: and similar oils.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it must be avoided that in the bath or in the bathroom, but it is necessary that after leaving the bath, either for an hour, or for two hours, it is administered.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	It is not necessary for someone to sleep after ventilation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is to be done in order to ventilate, or before phlebotomy?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And then it is necessary, if the ventilation or phlebotomy is choleric, and there is sharpness and inflammation above the blood of the patient: then it is necessary that he receive cold, such as pomegranate rind: and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and dry iubeba, and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And then place the meat of his chicks, and lean meats, and cooked foods with coarse flour: and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if the complexion is cold, he should take in a pot of syrup made from honey or almonds, or ulecaniabin made from sesame seeds: and he should take a slightly scented wine, which is between old and new: and he should be advised to use it in small amounts.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And then place the meat of his chicks, and cooked foods with hops: and pigeons, that is, young doves: and the young of columbaissadebat.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink of the day and ventilation and phlebotomy be more than the food: and it is necessary that a drink be given in a pot in which some men in Tyrian alfaroch or muscat wine, or alesethe before ventilation: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal limbs are strengthened, and the blood becomes thin.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	It is not necessary for them to take it in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	About ventilation without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	However, ventilation without scarification are those that are placed on the back, and spleen, and podagram, and above the ventrum, umbilicus, and the region of the liver, and the navel: for these parts do not bear scarification over them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	It is not sought through these, unless there is attachment from a blood vessel to a limb, as we place the vent on the breasts in the case of a bloody discharge from the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we employ them to dissolve the cold moisture injected into a member from another member: as we place the vapor over the ventricle and the navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	Indeed, it dries the member and heats it up, and relieves the pain because it dissolves that cold moisture.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed over the kidneys when there is poverty or a stone in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	Indeed, the strength of its attachment may open up poverty, or it may remove the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And it also does so when placed over the spleen, and the liver to be heated up at the same time in both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these vapors are given with the cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And they are sometimes given with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And they are sometimes given with full hot water in the cases of pleurisy: and this is, that the vapor is filled with hot water, or with water in which the herbs that agree with it have been decocted.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of the vapor given with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	The size of its opening should be two fingers wide, according to the form we have made: and its quantity should be half a palm deep in the hollow: and there should be a small hole in the side, in the place which is about the middle of it, according to the amount that enters the needle: it should be made of air at the same time, or of brass, with golden edges, equal to the size of the hole: so as not to hurt the member in its position over it: and there should be a hole in the middle of it, through which the candle is passed when it is lit with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	This already has been made soft and wet, greater than what we have mentioned, and lesser than that, according to the severity of its ailment and age of the one who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	Winds are different for children, and those that lessen pain, than those that are for men and large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	The quality of applying this wet with fire to the body is, as if you were setting a linen comb with fire from linen, or a small candle from a wick: and place it on the middle of a woman who has passed through menstruation, which is in the lower part of the wet: so that the fire may be set to the lower part of the wet, so that it does not burn the weak body.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then it is placed on the body: and a finger is placed over the hole which I said, until when we hold the wet: while we require, we remove the finger, and the vapour comes out above that hole, and the wet is immediately dissolved.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then set fire to the linen according to its kind, and then if you need that,
