In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the wet which is administered in inflammation of pleurisy with water, there is no woman who has passed through menstruation, nor hole: and it is not given unless it is filled with water, and is placed only on the body.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this wet, the more it is great, so that it can hold much water, the better it is.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	¶ About the suspension of Sanguisugarum.
Caput XCIX.	Caput XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Sanguisugae are not given in many, except in which there is no position for the wet, because of their smallness, such as the lip, and gum, and those like them.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in a member stripped of flesh, such as the finger, and nose, and those like them.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	The quality of these instruments is such that they are made from blood-letting plants that are found in sweet waters, free from putrefaction.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they are allowed to remain in sweet water for a day and night until they become hungry, and nothing remains in their bellies.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body will be emptied at first with bloodletting, and with vomiting.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then cleanse the weak member until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterward, they will be placed on top of it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are filled, and fall down, and there is a possibility of drawing out the water from the place with vinegar, then it is the last in the operation: and if not, then cleanse the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then when much water comes out, and it frizzes, and is expressed.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood is prolonged after the blood-letting, and it is still residing, then pour linen flax into cold water, and place it on top, until the abscess is separated.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood is multiplied, then poultice it with ground barley or galls, and similar substances from stinx: until the blood is separated.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or they may be placed on top of the place in halves of flax seeds: and they are allowed to remain until the flax sticks to the place, because the blood is separated.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if a blood-letting is required again, when it is possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	But if they are forbidden from being hung up, then cleanse the place with the recent blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or hang up a sponge in the places until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they are placed on top, because when they feel something from the blood, they stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you wish for them to fall, apply something ground or salted or ashed over them, and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	Part II End.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book III of the Surgical Book by Albucasis.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	Discourse on the restoration, dislocation, and treatment of twists and similar conditions.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is often necessary in the art of medicine, and it is the restoration of broken bones and accidents of the bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, O sons of mine, that you are stupid doctors and fools who do not understand this chapter of the ancient book, nor have read from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason, this method is isolated from our earthly sciences.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never seen any good in this, and I have not obtained it from this, unless I have obtained it only through the long reading of ancient books and a desire for their understanding, until I extracted the science of this from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I applied the experiment and study of the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And I have described to you all the science of this chapter: and then my experiment surpassed what was contained in that knowledge: and after I had freed it from the occupation of elongation, and from the end of abbreviation, and from the end of declination, and I showed the end of declination: and I formed many forms in it from the shapes of the instruments given in it, when it is from the addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	Summaries and collections of cases from broken bones, from those whose release is necessary before we begin the recall of the fractured members, and divers, if any.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary that we say in the preface of this chapter, that it contains the highest sermons, and the headings, to which the understanding of the artificer is directed first, namely, whether you or those who are quick, know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say that when it happens to anyone a fracture, or dislocation, or torsion, or case: then it is necessary that we immediately attend to the sanguination and the dissolution of it, and also of the latter: if nothing prevents it, as weakness of vigor: or it is he who has something from them, a child, or an old man decayed: or it is time of excessive heat, or excessive cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then he should be content with his food, cold vegetables, and flesh of animals, and seeds: and forbid wine, and fat meat, and repel from the food and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Then when you are secure from the heat of the aposteme, and do not fear the effusion of the material to the member: then the weak one returns to the regimen of the first with whom it was customary for his habit.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the weak one be fed with nutritious food, much and coarse, in which there is weakness: such as food made from boiled flour with water, and rice, and barley, and feet, and intestines of vinegar, and egg, and fresh fish, and wine, and such like.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	When this regimen is made for the coagulation of the fracture more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	When broken bones are in the eyes of those who are in the first stage of old age and decay, it is not possible for them to continue and to heal according to their nature, due to the dryness of their limbs: and they consolidate and continue those which come from them in the end, as the bones of young boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue on the broken bone from all sides, where there is thickening, which holds and strengthens it until they are glued together, and they bind themselves together until the end of strength and firmness, as was in the beginning, until it does not prevent anything from its operations: and for this reason it is necessary to give weak foods, in which there is thickness, viscosity, and thickening, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	You know that the appearance of fractures is diverse, according to the diversity of the limbs: for the fracture of the thigh is different from the fracture of the bone of the head: and the fracture of the bone of the breast is different from the fracture of the bone of the back: and all other parts of the body are also diverse in their nature: and I come with remembrance of all kinds of fractures, each one distinct from the other.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the appearance of the fracture of bones is also diverse within itself.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	For it happens that the fracture of this arc is made, except for the stars that happen to it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes it happens that the fracture of this arc is made according to the length of the bone: and these fractures are called saturation points, that is, stars, and the additions that follow, as they do in a quill when the pen is used for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding: and is a fracture with the ulna and disruption at the head: and is a fracture of the small fissure.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And of all kinds is genius, or the proper instrument for its restoration, according to which rememberance of it is to be recollected, distinct in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from that by which the fracture of bones is known, is the tortuosity of it, and its eminence: and its appearance to the senses, and its sound when you comprise it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When therefore there is not apparent tortuosity in the place, nor sound when you touch the bone with your hand when you move it, nor great weakness of a large pain: then there is not fracture there, but it is possible that there is tortuosity or a small fissure: therefore it is not necessary to move it with your hand and completely with compression, much less to put above it from medicines, which comes to memory, after the moment that conuenit loco: then it is drawn tight by a subtle string.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you know that the place when it is arched, and is divided into two, besides what happens to satiety, yet all parts are removed from their comparison: then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour to the rectification of it, equaling it before it happens to him a hot apostema.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	If however a hot apostema happens to it, then let it be given days, until the apostema rests.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equal it according to whatever mode can be from lenity and ingenuity.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And you know that the restoration of it, and its equalization, is easier than bones, in which satiety happens.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then draw it tight according to what comes to memory to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If indeed the bones are affected by caries, then it is necessary to extend this member, broken into two parts, either the hand or foot: or if your hand, then if the member is small: or if with two thongs, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And your position when you place the member on a corresponding place according to its natural figure, until the parts of the broken member are extended: then try to make those additions with all ingenuity, and according to whatever method you can in those places: and be careful not to cause any pain or injury to the weak part by your operation, nor any wound: and try to apply one of the two bones alongside its companion bone, according to the better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	It is necessary at that time to test and touch it with your own hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If then you see something different here, correct it yourself, and make it equal according to the quantity of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And be careful of a violent extension, and a strong compression, as some foolish men do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For they often make their own hot aphorism or contraction in the member through that operation, as we have already seen this from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then annex after the equation, and a fitting operation, and a strictly closed member, and quietness, and tranquility: and warn the weak about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make it hesitate, lest it move in the hour of its vigilance, and in its dreams at its revolution, and its agitation, and at its evacuation, and all its movements with the last strength of itself.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And so that it may not be in the position of the member with the position that follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when it feels pain or injury in the position of the member's disposition, then it should change it to another position from that with which it does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	When setting that bone, make its position equal and straight, so as not to cause twisting in the member when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the fracture of the member is according to what I say.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	You know that fractured members are diversified according to their soundness, and their magnitude, and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Those which are small like the arm, the finger, and the toe, and such like, then it is fitting that a soft and fine cloth bandage be used.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But if they are large, such as the thigh and the leg, it is fitting that there be a wide bandage in them, hard.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	For a wide bandage connects the large member, and tightens it from all sides equal, so that it does not enter the mark.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then after your purge, begin to put on a suitable liniment to this, in a soft cloth over the place of the fracture of that member.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to bandage the member with three or four folds, according to what is fitting for the member: and tighten your hand a little with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go up with it to the upper part of the place of the fracture, and tighten less than was your stretch, which you bound at the place of the fracture.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then stretch you with the bandage a little, and soften the tight one gradually, until you catch from the healthy place a great thing.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another one carefully, and bandage it again over the place of the fracture with folds.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go down with the bandage after the fold.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And may your operation be in the bandaging and softening of the fold, according to what I said in the first bandaging above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the incisions made from the plaster or cloth, as is used for the same degree of twisting in the fracture, if there is a twist in it; and if not, do not put anything into it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then place another incision on the same spot.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Afterwards, place needles at the same spots immediately, if there is no inflammation and no hot applications.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If however there is inflammation or heat: then place above it the thing that is lying on the heat, and it will remove the inflammation: and let it be for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tie up the needles above it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the needles be made from the middle of a cane, sawn in two, and cut into a fine point: or they may be made from wood, from which broom is made, or from palm branches, or from calamus: and the width of all the needles should be according to this form and shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, it should be the needle that is placed on the same piece of flesh that is the largest and most slender, than the others; and the length of the needle should be according to what can be allowed for the member, according to its size and thickness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tie up the needles above the other incision, according to the first tightening.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then tie up below with threads according to the first tightening, as we have said about the binding; and it should be that your binding is higher on the spot of the fracture than the previous one, and the more it extends from the fracture, the smaller the binding.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it should be that the middle thread is of medium thickness and soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, as is seen in the operation of the stupid ones, their threads from twisted linen fall away because of it: for the binding falls off because of it.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	The fine threads do not come together again: for you do not achieve that which you wish through the stricture with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	It is not necessary for it to be between a star and a star smaller than a finger.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If it is affected by the weak through the extremities of the stars after the stricture in the healthy places: then place under them from the woolen ointment gently, or the caramelized wool, until nothing is harmed from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When however there is a fracture with the elbow, and it happens to be disrupted in the skin, I recall it according to its individuality in the chapter.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And you know that not every limb fractured should be tied with stars from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	That is because when the limb is large, it is not necessary to put stars above it unless after five days, seven days, or more, according to your security from the event of your apostleship, hot wax.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the way of ointments which were made by the ancients, which are placed over the fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	Common method of ointment, restoring the fracture, suitable for more complexions, especially women and children: for it is from that which does not kindle heat, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is that you take from the dust of the mill, and it is the brain of the flour which hangs in the walls of the mill at the time of the grinding of the mill: and you place it thus, except that you do not crumble it with the thumb: and you place the confection of it neither thick nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	Another method of ointment for restoring the fracture and dislocation and torsion.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Remedy for strengthening the voice, praised by all, acacia, unguent, and mucilage, and myrrh, and aloes of Comoros, and alethium 20 parts, and all other spices are mixed together with water of alchemy: or with albume oui, if the complexion is weak, it is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this ointment.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is a good composition, it restores broken bones quickly, and it benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	Another method of ointment, which also cures fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Recipe for mucilage, and myrrh, and white aloe, all ʒ X myrrhae, and aloes of Comoros ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX parts are mixed together with great grief, and they are shorn, and they are made into ointment with water or albume oui: and they are given.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	Another method of ointment for joining, and bones separated from their place: and it soothes the pain of accidents to them, and it heals the fractures and separations.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	The wax is allowed to stick, and it is dipped in vinegar, and the decocted oil: and it is placed on the spot.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this ointment there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good for the sedation of hot applications: and it expels the pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Another method of ointment that restores the broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Gather the leaves of the fig tree and the white leaves of the aspen: and beat them all together and make an ointment from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	Another method of ointment for shortening the time of restoration of the broken bone: and when you want to give the remaining hot applications.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Recipe of the root of the old plant, and chamomile, and flowers of the herbs, and all parts of a bunch in equal part: they will be made for all, and bound with wine, if there is no heated member.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If the member is heated, then bind it with a damp coriander, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	A method of plastering another stronger in resolution than this first, when hard aposteme happens during the restoration of the member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Recipe of the root of the old plant, and linseed, and balsam, and yarrow, and savory, and chamomile, and all flowers in equal part, they will be made for all, and bound with salt water, or with sweet water, or with wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	The whole of this according to the heat of the member, and quietness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates said in his book that it should be placed on the broken member during its restoration, unless carbuncle is made from the stone, and oil: nothing else: and he said that it should be between the grossness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen says that it is good to place on the broken member during its restoration, in which there is heat exudation, such as myrrh, and aloes, and olibanum, and similar ones from them of which we have spoken.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	A method of plastering that is used for the wound and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Recipe of mug and chickpeas, and the sharp teeth of human hair, or the feather, and old plants, and all parts in equal amounts: they will be made for, and sheared, and bound, and a plaster will be made from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The quantity, according to what should be, that remains the suture, then it is loosened, is such that you consider then, if not the patient suffers pain, nor itches, nor moves the fractured bone from its place: then you do not resolve it days many.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If however it happens to him in the place pruritus, or pain, or inflammation: then immediately, and loosen it in its own hour, and take off the plaster from it: and receive a soft bandage, or a wet sea sponge, moist: and submerge it in warm water, and wash away with it the place, until the pruritus is quiet, and sits down the pain.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place over it a linen cloth on it, submerged in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night for one night, until you are secure from the hot pinch, and the pain in the member is quiet, and sits down.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the member to the fine bandage and the thin plaster: and do not tie it with your first constriction, and the fine with it, until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the pinch, and redness, and pain, and inflammation, and all other things removed completely, and you need plaster and bandage, then repeat this as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If something of what I said does not happen to the limb, then do not loosen it unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it has been for twenty days, the whole of this, according to what appears to you from the loosening of the limb, as I said, until the fracture adheres, and the coagulation of the flesh is applied over it: and also at that time in the bandage more than in your first bandage entirely: and also in the increase of weak food, according to what precedes the remembrance of this.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see a place where the wound has already dried out and been scraped, and has been rubbed beyond what is necessary: then you know that nourishment is forbidden to be applied to it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore, let the wound be embrocated with warm water at all times where it is possible to apply it, and let it be done for three days, and let it be tightly closed.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Therefore, food is given to the member for this operation, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	However, what they do with stupid restorers is to give nourishment to the member from the fracture of the limb, when it does not heal at first, according to what is appropriate, and heals according to the tortuosity, it is an error in their operation, and a great fear: and if it were right, they would have said that in their books, and they had operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I do not see any of their traces in that at all, and it is better that it is not done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	Regarding the accident that occurred in the head.
Caput III.	3rd head.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of the fracture are diverse, and the figures of it are many: and the causes of it are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For from the fracture is that which happens by a blow with a hammer: and the blow removes the whole bone until it has been moistened to the siphon, which is under the bone, as does the axle in the wood, therefore this species of fracture is called the Axial one.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Sometimes the hammer strikes some bones, and it strikes the face of it, and does not penetrate the cut to the end of it, and this species of fracture is called the Kalan one, that is, Absolute Luxation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is a joint of two fractures, or great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And from the fracture that is abrasion or abrasion, and its cause is a strike with a stone, or a chance on the stone, or such like.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also or perforating, which is approaching the pannicle, which is under the bone: or it is in the face of the bones: and it is a fracture of these two small or large fragments.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And from the fracture that is hidden in the bone in the subtlety of the hair: and it is a small fissure, and for this reason this species of the fracture is called Capillaris.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And from these is a fracture that is made by chance or by a strike with a stone, and such like, which make it go into the slice of the bone to the interior, and it becomes a concussion: just as happens when hot air is struck by them, and it goes into parts of them to the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And this is done most of all in the heads of moist bones, such as are the heads of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these kinds of fractures are separated and become distinct, and I return to this memory of the whole in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we know all these kinds of fractures by detection on it, and by the investigation of them when we touch them, and by the removal of the corrupt flesh which is on them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	However, the species of Capillaris is known by this, that it is detected on the bone, and removed, and covered over with wax on it: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	However, in the treatment of the fracture, consider first the accidents of the weak: then if you see from the accidents that signify a manifest danger with fear, such as diarrhea, and extension, and loss of intelligence, and glottis, and abscess, and acute fever, and exit of eyes, and redness of them, and such like from many accidents, it is not likely to be cured: and if you see accidents that do not frighten you and hope for health, then begin the care of it.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	When it comes to a wound that has first been inflicted, it is necessary to study the removal of bones before the fourthteen day of the month, according to all arrangements.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the months of summer, then it is necessary to remove the bone before the seventh day, before the flesh under the bone becomes rotten, and those things that we have mentioned will occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the fracture of the bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and it is with small pieces, and with attraction, then it is necessary to remove the part that is comminuted and attrited, according to what I will tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is like the removal of the head of a wounded head: remove the skull above the bone according to whatever possible way is for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is weakest above the weakest.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it happens to you during the detection of the bone, the flow of blood or hot apostema, then place it with what is necessary next to it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is like filling the place with injected membranes in the wine, and rose oil: and make the elbow rest, until the apostema is settled, and be careful about the flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin in the care of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And it is done according to one of two modes.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One mode is to remove the bone with a scalpel in a straight line: and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then administer another scalpel after the first one is wide: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then also administer another scalpel that is wider than the previous one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second mode is to have a number of scalpels of different sizes: some of which are wider than others, and some of which are narrower than others: and they should be at the end of the last cutting edge, and they should be made of iron or steel: and use ease in percussion on the scalpel, so that it does not hurt the head, and harms it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If however the bone is strong and hard: then it is necessary to make an incision around its circumference, before you administer the forceps, as the terebras, which are called terebins, do not pierce but cut, and are not called so because they do not reach the end of the cartilage to that which is after it, because the terebra is the rounded extremity above that which is the sharp edge under the head of the bone, similar to a margin, and a smaller ring prevents it from being submerged and passing through the density of the bones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it suits you, that you take from these terebras a great number, of which one concurs with the quantity of density of the bones, until the present head of the terebra is before you: whose sharp end in length and breadth is according to the quantity of density of that cranium.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of the three kinds of terebras, or trephines.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	However, the quality of perforating around the fractured bone is: that you place the terebra on the bone and turn it with your fingers, until you know that the bone has been almost perforated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then change the terebra to another place, and place that which is between all the holes of the radius in quantity of breadth, or about this.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with the forceps that is between all the holes of the bone: and make it finer than you can on the end of the fractured part, as we said, until you remove the bone with your hand, or with any other instrument which you have prepared for this, such as tenails, and thin forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary that you take all precaution to see that the terebra does not touch the forceps, or any part of the syringe.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you have surrounded the bone with the drill and separated it from the siphon, if it is continuous with it, and take it out, it is necessary that you sharpen the edges, and make them equal at both ends which remains in the bone with another similar instrument such as an incisor.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that it be thinner and more delicate with others of the same type.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If something remains in the bones, and it is hard: then take it with ease, with that which is at your disposal from the instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then take care of the wound after that with the ointments that I have mentioned, and the liniments.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another method of operation is easy, indeed far from fear: which Galen said and highly praised it, and this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	First of all, it is necessary for you to begin to expose a part of the bone from the place where the fracture is more severe and manifest: until when you have detached that part and placed its end under the extremity of this lenticular Incisor, whose this is the form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the part of the lenticular one is not sharp, and the sharp part of it is on both sides of it, going in length as you see: so that the lenticular part be attached to the siphon, its sharp face incident on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike it with the hammer from the one side with a small mallet, until you detach the whole bone with ease, as it turns: and you will be secure from the blanket, which does not happen in that which you fear infinitely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the physician were not more foolish than man, and more ignorant of it, and was not sleeping, then if something remained attached to the bone from the blanket in some places, it would detach it from the extremity of the lenticular Incisor of its own, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	This book is released by him without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	If the fracture does not penetrate up to the fascia, and the part that is separated from the bone is the appearance of it, and the roughness and subtlety of the hair remain in the same: then it is necessary to remove this roughness and the subtle hairs with thin rasps, as you have prepared a number of different quantities of them, so that it is possible for you to apply some of them in every convenient place and righter ones of them, according to what leads to the operation you are performing, and the broken bone and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary for you to apply them in proportion to your own, which is first the rasps of the bone.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease doing this according to continuity, until you become more skilled in applying it more gently and subtly of all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	However, in each of the remaining small fissures and subtle fractures, it is necessary to apply attention according to what leads to the correction of its figure.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And there is a thing which is not hidden over everything, which in this art is the desire of everyone, and it stands over what we have written and shown in great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	However, if the fascia is detected and retains the membrane, when you remove the bone: then it is necessary to take a linen bandage according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another linen bandage, either doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first bandage: and do this as easily as you can, so that it does not become greasy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer it over the wide ligament: and do not strain it, unless by the quantity that holds the thigh only: and release it with this care once a day, or for two days, until you are secure from the hot nail.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it, and administer after that the medicine with which there is superfluous dryness, such as the roots of lilies, and flour of herbs, and powder of thurible, and aristolochia, and such like; and it is as if you were making a child who would be dried on the thigh as those are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer to it all medicine of which the property is to ablate, and not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And take care according to your virtue, that the thigh be clean in your curing: neither let there be sores on it, nor dregs of ointments, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Nor release the urine to gather in it altogether, because when urine gathers on the brain pan, it corrupts it, and putsrefies it, and happens to the weak after that great malice: and it has already happened in the infected skull, when the mouth of it is being cleaned from it, especially when care is neglected, a blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider now, if such accidents happen to the weak, you know that it is incurable probably.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not happen, unless from the medicine which is put over it, and it is in the virtue of that medicine to make it black: then you must take one part of honey, three parts of rose oil, and linen with them a piece of cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it over the infected skull: then care for it with the specimens of the curing which come together, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	The restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	You know that the nose is not broken except when two of its upper parts are broken at the same time, or one of them: for they are two bones: therefore, because they are two bones, it does not break the lower part, which is cartilage, and it does not happen to it except abrasion, tortuosity, and similarity.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of its upper parts is broken, then it is necessary to insert a small digit into the nostril, and indicate the fracture with your thumb, and with a deformed finger, until the nose returns to its natural figure: and it should be done artfully, with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware that it does not happen by your operation on the weak pain.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not go to that digit: then it is necessary to make equal to the end of the radius, in which there is a small thickness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If the fracture is in two parts, then make it like that: and as soon as the restoration is made on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at quiet at night, apply hot sticks.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then insert into the end of the nose a linen bandage, if the fracture is in one part: or insert two linen bands if the fracture is in two parts: and let the thickness of the linen be so much as to fill the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some ancient restorers have said that the linen should be wetted with butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	This does not seem to me, but rather it is necessary that the linen be wetted with honey and completely mixed with flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then release the linen, until the bone is firm and the cartilage is hardened.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And when it is introduced into the nose at the place of a goose feather, after being covered with soft linen: and it becomes, that it holds the fracture of the nose more firmly, and prevents weakness from inhaling.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do this: and if you wish, make the linen.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If the nose is burned again while you are working, apply a plaster to the nose with hot oil, or with oil soaked in rose-colored oil, or a small amount of ointment made from alum.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If the nose is not burned hot, then it is necessary to apply a plaster with flour and powdered turmeric with white gum.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place over the plaster a soft linen bandage, and do not bind the nose tightly with anything.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If the bones of the nose are broken or crushed, then it is necessary to cut under them and take them out with the tools that are suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then care for the cut with what becomes inflamed and condensed, and make it strong with suitable plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If the nostril is injured, then it is necessary to treat it with linen and give a lead tube until it recovers.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	¶ Regarding the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken:
Caput V.	5. Head.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken and the fracture is not with the cheek: then consider if the fracture of it is only deformed, and not broken into two, and whether it is curved towards the inside: then recognition of it is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	If the fracture is in the right part of the bone, you must insert your left thumb into the weakened left jaw: similarly, if the fracture is in the left mandible, then insert your right hand: and press with it the exhaustion of the fracture, with ease, from the inside to the outside with your other hand, and make it equal to the same.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the mandible fracture has already been separated into two parts, then it is necessary to give extension from two parts according to straightness, until it is possible to make it equal.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If however, already there is an excitement or disruption in the teeth, then tighten those from which you hope that the remaining ones will remain with gold wire, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a cradle over the broken mandible.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place a double band over it, and place a large magnifying glass or a equal frustum of the sole skin on it, in the length of the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then tie it up from below according to what is prepared for the ligature of this, and it fits its application until it is not destroyed, and order the patient to be calm and quiet, and place a soft food of his hunger.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If however, you think that something has already changed in any figure of any mode: then immediately and loosen it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has changed from it, and apply the plaster to the dough with alabaster or with flour sieve, after you have removed the cradle: and place a soft wool over the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While this plaster is still attached to it and does not change the position of the bones, release it, so as not to loosen it, until it heals: or tighten the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	This fracture is held together by many strings for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If an acute burn occurs meantime, then administer that which we called many strings for its sedatation, until the burn is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with the thigh, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	Then separate the piece from the bone, or from the splinter: then use your fingers to remove that splinter with what suits you for the removal of those from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If however the wound opening is tight, then enlarge it with the phlebotomy according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed that splinter, and there is nothing left of it, then if the wound opening is wide, then enlarge it; and if not, put on top of it with ointments that suit you for this, and let them marinate until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	¶ Restoration of the Wing: When it breaks.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	Indeed the wing is broken from the front part of the shoulder, and the fracture of it is made according to one third of the mode.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or if it is broken and separated into two, except for what happens in the splinter, it is easier to restore it.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or that which happens in the bone splinter: and it is more difficult to restore it.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or that which is a fracture with the thigh: and it is more difficult to restore it.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation on it when the fracture is without the thigh is, that you make present two ministers, so that one of them holds the aid that follows the broken wing, and the other extends the neck towards the part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then make an equal fracture with your fingers, until it has the form that it should have, and there should not be any prominence or concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you require further extension, then it is necessary to place under a thin, weak sphere made of cloth or wool, and its size should be according to the quantity required by you: extend it, take the goose wing, and with your hand pull out the sphere, until the even fracture is made according to what is necessary.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot pull the end of the goose wing to its outer edge: because it is too deep: then it is necessary to have the weak one over the gauze of it: and place under the shoulder of it a medium-sized pulley, and put the shoulder of it at the lower part, until the bone of the goose wing that is in the deep end rises up to the upper part: and then rectify the fracture and make it equal with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If however you feel saturation from the goose wing, and it moves: then it is necessary to take the saturated one away from that, and pull it out with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If however it is held in the bone, then use your ingenuity in the incision of that one tooth which you have prepared for it, after you have placed under the goose wing the instrument that suits the sifach: and this instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It should be similar to the cochlea without connection.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to the size of the bone and its proportions.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	However, its length should also be according to what is possible for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it should have two ends as you see: and one end should be wide and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If however the wound that you cut when you took out the saturated bone is wide and secure from the hot aposteme: then gather the two lips of the wound with the suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	If disruption is small, or you fear hot aftercut: then fill the wound with bandages, and stitches according to the extent of the cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot aftercut occurs, then pour bandages in rose oil, vinegar, wine, and place on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	When the stricture of the bone is without a wound and without a section, it is, as you place on top of the bone an ointment made from flour with almond oil.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft splint on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under the soft one, if you need that.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a hammer, that is, the round wheel that the Saracens hold, which is long and of about the same width as a palm of one hand, or about this.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a doubled bandage on top of the splint and ointment.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a star from a fine table, whose width is three fingers, and lengthwise similarly.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then cover it in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then cover the bandage with the star in the place where the hammer falls on the fracture and the wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the hammer on the fracture as it revolves, and cover it over the neck of it, and under the soft and hard shoulder, and under the soft and hard wrist: and bring it back over all parts, and how you see that the stricture holds the fracture stricture decently, and is this, which is not hidden over you, and whole, so that the star does not fall off from the broken bone above.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And therefore it is necessary to look at the weak one every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever you see the star already falling out, then straighten it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place a pillow under the weak part of its back, and place a small pillow under the pillow of its neck at night, so that when it turns to its side, it can support itself with its own side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	It then heals the fracture of the shoulder by elevation.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or tie its arm to the collar of its own neck: and do not untie the ligament, unless it does not happen in the place where it should be, or due to pruritus, up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then reapply the plaster, if you see the face of its head towards that.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add to the closure, and release it, until it is restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	And the fracture of the shoulder is indeed tightened and strengthened according to the most in twenty days: and sometimes it happens in some people in a smaller one.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	¶ About the restoration of the fracture of the spatula.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
