Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of some joint from its place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore, movement is prohibited and the appearance of the limb is deformed.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes pain to be felt on the infirm part, and severe injuries.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When then a dislocation happens to someone, it is necessary to hurry towards its restoration: nor does it delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	If it delays, the place will be postponed, and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, it is not necessary to delay, nor to extend in the hour of his postponement.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it often causes a spasm, and painful wounds.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	Indeed, when that happens, it is necessary to hurry towards phlebotomy of the weak one.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then he will be released, until the postponement becomes quiet.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the member will be rubbed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it will be reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And all the member is to be cared for with that of which the memory will not be in its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I myself have already ordered the chapter of dislocation, even according to which the fracture precedes in the body from the upper part to the lower one of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	¶ About the care of the dislocation of the inferior mandible.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	Few dislocations happen to the two mandibles unless rarely.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of the inferior one is made according to one or two modes.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or rather they are removed from their places by a slight removal and are softened somewhat.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated completely and integrally, until they are softened to the chest, until the weak pulse is flowing, and it cannot hold it, nor can it close its mouth, and the tongue of it is uncovered with the speech of it.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When however the dislocation of it is slight, then it returns to several positions by itself with a few number.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If indeed the dislocation is complete and entire, then it must be that a hasty reduction is to be made of its head, and it should not be delayed long: and it is fitting that the physician hold the weak head of the patient: and he inserts his thumb of one hand into the root of the dislocated mandible between the cheeks thereof, if the dislocation is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he inserts both of his hands simultaneously, if the dislocation is from two sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the rest of his hand should be outside, by which it ought to be equalized.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And he commands the patient to clean his jaws and to free them for chewing to all parts.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician should equalize the jaw, and he drives the jaw until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If however the reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are at once, then a hasty reduction is to be made of its other side, and he administers ointment with warm water and oil until a easy reduction of the other is made, and it should not be delayed long in reducing the other as we said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they are reduced and equalized, and the weak jaw is closed and not softened, then place above them some flax cloths soaked in rose oil, with which a certain thing has been made from wax: and let it be applied.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then he is to be gently bound with soft bands.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the weak one be laid on his back, and his head stand between two flax cloths so that it does not move to the right and left: nor is he compelled or forced to chew anything: indeed, a soft drink of what he desires is placed under his jaw until the pains subside and the jaw nods, then he eats what he wishes and the drink is given with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not labor over the operation of his mouth at eating and drinking and nodding until the jaw is subsided and he is cured.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	When two mandibles are difficult to reduce after being dislocated in a certain hour and do not return to their original position, many fevers and frequent diarrhea often occur, and perhaps the cold stomach is relieved, and perhaps the sour choler is vomited.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see that, then you know that it is a loss, and that person often dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	¶ About the reduction of shoulder joint dislocation and its extremity.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	Indeed, the shoulder joint is not dislocated from the inner side due to its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it is sometimes dislocated to the outside: and this is felt by touch.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And the restoration of it is, that it lie on his weak side on his back, and extend his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then, place it in the right position with the palm of your hand, for it will return.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then place the bandage over it, and the plasters, and bind it.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	But the extremities of these, which follow the elbow, and are continuous with it, are not dislocated, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	When it is dislocated on a certain day: then it must be reduced and made equal according to what I have said, and prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place the bandage over it, and the plasters, and the bound one.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And advise the patient to remain in tranquility and quiet until he recovers.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when the same treatment is applied to the extremity of the shoulder, it also separates from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	¶ About the reduction of shoulder joint dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the humerus does not dislocate unless it is done in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of them is, that it is dislocated to the part that is titillated towards the lower parts.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second way is, that it is dislocated to the part of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated to the upper part of the humerus: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated to the back, because of the spatula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated to the front, because of the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it is most commonly dislocated and goes towards the lower parts, opposed to the titillated part: especially in those, where the flesh is few.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	For they go into them easily, and they go in easily.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those where the flesh is many, it is opposite to that, because it goes with difficulty, and it goes with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some men by hitting, or accident, and the humerus is struck hot, and it is thought because of that, that it is already dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, you should try this, until you are certain of it, and then proceed to the treatment of it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is known that dislocation occurs when it is to the lower parts, opposed to the titillated part: and you can distinguish between the dislocated humerus and the sound humerus.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a manifest difference between them, and you will find in the head of the humerus a congestion, and under the titillated part at the touch of the head of the humerus as if it were one thing: and it cannot weakly return the hand to its own ear, nor move it with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated to the front, or upwards: then you will find a manifest touch, and it will not be hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	This particular dislocation makes the reduction of this type easier when it is recent or the child is weak.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	The reduction of this is that he should raise his helper's hand to the higher parts.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your hands under the flap of it, and raise the joint with strength to the top to its own place: and the helper should raise his hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then he should place it lower, for he returns unsteadily himself.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	However, if he does not return as we said, and the days that have passed since the dislocation began are many: then it is necessary to let the weak one bathe in hot water, and apply an embrocation that softens and soothes, just as if decoctions of high roots, such as ginger, and fenugreek, and mallow, were applied in water.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the weak one should rise on his back: and a sphere and wool that is equal between softness and tightness should be placed under the flap of it.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the physician should place his heel on the sphere, and raise the head of the arm with strength, and draw the weak hand downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another should hold the weak head, so that it does not move towards the lower parts: for he returns immediately himself.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce it according to this manner: and it is that the longer and weaker man should be present, and stand on the side, and insert his arm under the flap of the weaker one: and he should raise the flap of it to the higher parts, until it is weak hanging in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another should draw the weak hand downwards towards his vent.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	However, if the weak one is large: then it is necessary to hang something else with him, so that it makes it larger, for the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	It is reduced or cut according to another mode: and it is as if a long wooden beam, whose head is round-shaped like the handle of a mortar, were laid on the ground. It should not be thick nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then soft cloths are placed upon the wooden beam after the other materials have been laid on top of it: and the standing cloth should be as long as the wooden beam.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then the hand of that person is extended to the lower part of the other side, and the body of that person is extended with strength from that side: for the joint returns to its place with ease.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If it is difficult to reduce the joint through all that I have said, then use this caution: and it should be as if you take a beam whose length is the sum of two forearms, whose width is the sum of four fingers, and whose thickness is the sum of two fingers: and its head should be round like an opening, so that the passage of its head into the deep end can be made according to this form.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then soft cloths are tied around the round head: so that it does not hurt the weak standing cloth.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then the weak standing cloth is placed under the opening, so that the hand or forearm can be extended up to the lower part of the beam: and the beam is laid on the aid, and the hand and forearm.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then the forearm is placed on the step of the ladder across its breadth, and the hand is extended downwards, and the rest of the body is suspended from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	For the joint immediately enters.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When the passage of the joint is completed according to any possible mode: then it is necessary to place a round ball of equal quantity from wool under the opening.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then place the prepared plaster made from flour with oil and almond, and spread it all over the shoulder as it rotates.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten the knot under the thin strip in a neat manner: and roll up the ligament over the plaster: and attach her hand to the neck of its own collar, and let it go, and do not make her hand move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it is necessary that a weak food be placed on him, until he recovers, because it is more beneficial for his cure.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then a larger one will be placed on him after seven days, or five, and it will be moved with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If then he holds firm and is not softened, he is already cured.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If however the joint is dislocated many times, due to the moisture that happens to him, or due to another cause: then it is necessary that this cauterization be given to him with three holes, according to what was said in the chapter on cauterization.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If however this is done all, and the ligament is unwound after seven days, and the joint is not confirmed, and the plaster and the knot are reapplied on it several times, and it does not hold firm, and falls away, and cannot be raised up to the upper part: then you know that the nerves of his arm which are towards the head of the shoulder are already cut, or extended, or softened: and you know that the joint is never set in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	However, dislocations of the chest and breast, or to a posterior reduction, are made with a push and extension with the hands: until it returns, and the remaining stricture and care are given with the cauterization, until it is cured.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If however it happens after his cure, old age in the member, and slowness in its movement, then a weak bath is used many times, until that old age is eased, and it returns to its original nature.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	Translation: "On the Treatment of the Dislocation of the Knee-joint.
Caput XXVIII.	Translation: "Chapter 28.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Translation: "You know that a dislocation of the knee-joint is difficult to reduce and also returns with difficulty, and it itself is reduced to all parts, especially to the anterior and posterior.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	Translation: "And its dislocation is not hidden from you: for it is a falling under the touch, and under the touch, according to whichever figure it is dislocated.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	Translation: "And when you join a dislocated knee-joint with its proper bone, this is clearly shown to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	Translation: "The joint is contracted, and it cannot double the arm, nor touch its own shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	Translation: "And it is necessary to straighten it as soon as possible, and to reduce the dislocation before a hot application causes it.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	Translation: "For if a hot application is given, it becomes difficult to reduce the knee-joint: and perhaps it cannot be cured at all, especially when it is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	Translation: "For it is the worst of all kinds of dislocations, and the most severe pain that comes with them: and often it ends with death.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	Translation: "And the restoration of it is, when it can be reduced, to extend the hand of the patient with two hands, and the arm of the patient be expanded, and the hand of the physician to be above the knee and under it, and he himself presses the joint with his thumbs of both hands at once, or with the root of his finger, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Translation: "Or if the dislocation is to the front, then it returns thus, that the hand doubles with its own hand, until it strikes with the root of the finger's palm of the dislocated knee-joint.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	Translation: "But if the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a violent extension, with strong support: and it is that the two assistants extend the arm, and hold it even, so that it does not remove from the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is rotated around until it has been fully unfolded over the palm of the same hand, either the wide spread or the wide ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the physician touches it with his own hand, he should grease it with oil: so that this may be one of those which aid in the lubrication of the joint with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he will drive the joint with a strong push, until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after the reduction, it should be placed on the same plaster, where the stipes and excoriation are, with the gouge: and it should be tied in a proper manner.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And the arm is hung from the weak neck: and let it hang for some days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it is loosened.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If the joint is firm in its place, then loosen the ligament from it and let it go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see the joint not well tied, then repeat the plaster, and the ligament, and let it go for some days until it is tied.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then let it go.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	But if, however, stiffness occurs after the reduction of the joint, and the position is in motion: then administer hydration in the bath, and subtle friction, and compression, until it becomes soft, or place it on the joint itself, that is, the pale heel of the mare.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is tied, and let it go on it for a day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take it away, and introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When it is wet, then friction the joint with subtle friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then repeat on it, with one drop of ointment once, and twice, and thrice with the introduction of the bath, until it becomes soft.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	If you wish, place a damp cloth soaked in warm butter over the excrement and then tightly wrap it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do this several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	Indeed, it becomes soft again and returns to its original position.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	The treatment of the dislocated Almahassem:
Caput XXIX.	Head 29.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The Almahassem hand is often dislocated, that is, the joint between the shoulder and the wrist.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of this dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	And the opposite joints are reduced.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it is necessary that the ease of reduction is in the reduction of this dislocation at the time it is dislocated, before the wound is closed, or else a hot apostemetic will occur.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of the dislocation is such that you place the Almahassem hand of the patient on a board, and extend the other hand of his: and the physician places his palm on the prominence of the joint, and pushes it, until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, it is necessary that it be considered if the palm has already retreated to the vent of the hand: then the physician places the weak back of his hand on the board at the extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding to the back of the hand, then the position of his hand intrinsically on the board is such that the hand of the physician falls on the same prominence of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, that is good: and if not, then tightly wrap it with a sedative wound dressing: and release it, do not insist on this.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it does not bear, nor can you stand upon the reduction of it after three days have passed, yet the joint remains according to its twist: and nothing will hurt the weak one, unless the hand has been softened and cannot be tightened around anything: then you know that the nerves are cut or torn.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	It is not genius in her, unless it resonates with the cauterization near the site of her wound.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps she will not yield to this.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When Almahassem does not return, then place the ointment over it, which we have mentioned.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is bound, and it is released five days later: then it is dissolved and it is released, and the hand is exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however, the movement of her is hindered, and something of age happens to it: then soothe it with warm water and repeated rubbing, until it is soothed.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	¶ Regarding the treatment of the dislocation of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated from one of them to all parts, or from one of them to the back of the palm, or to its ventrum: then extend the finger, and press the dislocation with your thumbs, until it returns.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, and suspend the opposite part to which it is dislocated, and release it after two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it until it is straight in that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When it is night, tie it according to the description: and do not cease to untie it in the day: and exercise it with motion: and tie it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do this for a few days until it is bound.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same with that, if it is dislocated to the ventrum of the hand: and tie it to the same part, and do the first operation of your hand until it is cured.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And do the same with that when it is dislocated to other parts:
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	¶ Regarding the treatment of the dislocation of the vertebrae of the back.
Caput XXXI.	Head 31.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When a spondylalgia occurs on the back or a complete dislocation of the neck, or when many vertebrae are moved from their places: then there is no cure for it, because death comes to the weak one.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the weak ones leave it without will, and cannot hold it: and often some limbs of him are made soft by it, or two thighs of him, or two arms of him, or one of them: or a vertebra is removed from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	For it is often removed, because it is often removed to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	And that which is removed to the back, is called gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	But the cure of it is, that you consider now, if gibbosity happens from childhood: then there is no cure for it, nor any healing at all from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	But in those which happen by chance, or by blow, or by such like things, the ancients have already spoken of the ways of curing them with a long discourse.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Whose most does not return with profit.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have already abbreviated from that, whose little excuses from much of its nearness to my proximity: and from my own explanation, in which I explained it, and shaped the instrument of it in a different way from that which they showed it, and they also explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore, that in gibbosity which happens from the front part, there is no genius, nor healing from it.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And also in those which are made to two sides, even so.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And it is not cured from them, unless those which happen in the back properly, when I say: and it is, that the weak one extends over his face over the podium equal to the wall, and is extended under it with a wet string, so that his heart is not harmed.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight log is placed on the fire on the ground, at the tip of its foot, roughly at its head: and another log, roughly at its other foot: and it is held by a servant, and it should not be fixed in the fire.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And the other holds the other.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then it is wrapped over the weak head, and the rope of its titillum is gently made firm, and extended from the end of the rope to the log that is at its head: and it is tied in it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then string another rope above its belly, and above its own knees, and at its knee joints.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the ropes together and tie them in the log that is at its foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then the servant extends all of the ropes to a part of the log, and the two logs are not removed from their places where they were fixed: but they should not be made firm as I said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the physician will place his hands over the spine with strength, until he returns: or he may place them over the table.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he will tie the table to his feet, until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If he does not return through this treatment, then take the table whose length is roughly three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And make an opening in the wall near where we said it was weak, in the place where it enters the end of the table.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the table over the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And the physician will place his feet over the opposite end.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And tie it well, until the spine is bent, and return to its own place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	And if you wish, operate with the turn that was wrapped with your hand: and it is as if you were drawing two logs on the ground at the weak head of the other foot's last toe, and at its head two logs with the length of an arm.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	The length of the one palm tree between all timber is and already made in all places a hole, through which the turmoil runs: and the whole wood is firmly fixed on earth much, so that it does not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	The round wood is inserted and there is turmoil in which the ligament rotates in two holes of two timber.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	At the end of it there is a hole, in which the wood is fixed, whose length is palm with that of which it rotates: and in two other timber is similar to this.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then strengthen the ligaments that you have tied in the weak timber which is at the head of it: and the ligaments that you have tied in the thighs of it in the timber which is at the foot of it.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand at all timber which rotates the hand of him with his sinew, with which it rotates the turmoil: and the physician should adjust the spine, according to what we said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the timber which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then after the spine has returned and adjusted the place, then it is necessary to put the plaster of egg white with almond on it.
Deinde stuppam.	Then the stupe.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then put above the plaster a star from the tablet, whose width is three digits, or about them.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And the length of it has quantity which occupies the place of Gibbositatis, and over a part of the healthy spine.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is placed with the ligament that we said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And it uses weak nutrition of fine, until it becomes healthy.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	What if there remains some prominence in the place at the end of the cure: then it is necessary to give medicines which soften and relax, with the administration of the tablet which we said for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	The lead sheet is now being applied in that place.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	When an exuberance occurs at the posterior spine of the vertebra, it is supposed to be a dislocation, and that is the bone that is now protruding.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore, it does not suit to make a presumption of that in this medicine, perhaps it will cause death to happen.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ About the treatment of Anchaea's dislocated bone.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You know that in the joints of Anchaea and the shoulder, a dislocation only occurs, and it does not happen to them that happens in other joints due to removal of a small part and union.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the joint of Anchaea is indeed dislocated according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is dislocated towards the front and back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And it is indeed most dislocated towards the inside, and little dislocated towards the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment of the dislocation towards the inside is: because when you join the weak thigh bone with a sound one with a weak one, it is longer: and the knee of his is more prominent than the sound one, and the weak one cannot extend its foot at the groin: and it is the place that follows the groin, which is burned after being struck by the post, therefore, because the head of the hip has already become wet there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign that happens to the outside is what are its opposite symptoms, which are the opposite symptoms of these.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign that happens to the front is because the sound thigh expands according to the complement, verily it does not extend itself without pain in the knee: and if it attempts to walk, it cannot go over that to the front: and it retains its urine, and it is struck at the groin of its, and there is a callosity of its foot under the heel during walking.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of this which is subject to dislocation is towards the posterior end, so that it does not extend the knee, nor can it double itself before doubling the thigh: and the leg of its other side is shorter: and the thigh is softened, and the head of the hip is at the place of that one.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	However, reduction of this dislocation is as follows, so consider this now if the dislocation is old and has been long in place.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you perform a reduction of this, and it remains according to its position: then there is no cure at all in it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, it does not follow that it should be presumed to be completely healed.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	However, in the one where the dislocation is recent and it is of one of the four kinds of dislocations: then you should hurry to this, so that you want to join it, and extend it both towards the interior and towards the exterior, and move it to the right and left: perhaps it will return, and there will be no need for further treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	However, if it does not return in this way, then it is necessary to prepare a strong attendant and extend the leg of its other side: or with his hands, or with the ligature that is placed on the leg of its above the knee: and another attendant extends his hand over the tendon of its, so that he inserts his hands under the tendon of its.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then he should tie it with a soft ligature over the root of the hip, and hold the other end of the ligature.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And it should be extension either from the front part of the thigh to the shoulder, or from the back to the back.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And it should be extension of all of them in one way, until the weak one hangs down with its body from the earth, and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this is the sign of the species of extension, which is common to the four kinds of dislocations.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If then the dislocation returns with that which I said, it is good: and if not, then necessary is all kind of that which I say about the cure proper.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reduction of this proper when the dislocation is to the inside, it is necessary that the weak be raised above its own sound side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then he will put a ligament over the head of the hip, in which is the head of the hip and the place which is under the thigh.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament from the part of the thigh up to the higher part of the body, to the knee.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then he will take another helper to the strong arm of his, and he will make the weak place of the poor hip less, and he will extend it with a strong extension.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	Now then it returns to its own place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this species is easier than the others in the cure of this member.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If however he is excused from you, and does not obey to the coming with this kind of cure altogether: then it is necessary that two weak feet be tied together with a strong and soft ligament over two heels, and over two knees: and the length of each should be according to the quantity of four digits of his own: and the weak knee should be extended more than the other quantity of two digits.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then he will hang the weak over the head of the wooden beam which is in the house: and the length of it should be according to the quantity of two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then let the strong ivy cover the head of the hip: and he will hang with the weak in another place: and he will press the strong one to cover the hip with strength, for the dislocation returns to its own place with feebleness.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	In the reduction of this proper when the dislocation is to the outside, it is necessary that the weak lie on the foot according to what we have said about the hunchback.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	The ligament is tied above his thigh, the weakest part properly, and above his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two beams are placed, one at his foot, and another at the head of the same.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a beam is placed in the middle of his foot, fixed well: above which the wet bands are wrapped, so as not to harm the weak one; and it should be a beam between his thighs, so as not to attract the lower parts during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all the assistants extend to their own part, and the physician makes the reduction with his own hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If then he obeys for reunion, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place over the same tablet, and press it down evenly, as we said in the swelling.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Nevertheless, it is necessary that the weak one lie on his sound side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is to the front, then it is necessary that the weak leg be extended quickly: and this is according to the same narration over the foot: and the physician places his right hand palm on the weak thigh.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he bends it with one hand and places the extended leg down to the lower part of the knee.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is to the back: then it is not necessary that the weak leg be extended downwards and be raised on the ground, but it should be placed on a hard surface, as it is necessary that it also be placed if the dislocation is far away from his exterior, according to what we said about his pillow over two anchas: and it should be on his face and the extended ligaments: according to what we said earlier.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary that compression be given with the table also over the place where he is going to be united, when the reduction is complete according to what is appropriate.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	When the sign of its ransom is revealed to you, and it is that you extend two weak legs: and when you see them equal, and the weak one tightens its own thigh, and expands it without exception: then you know that the limb has returned, according to what is appropriate: then join the two buttocks, and put on plaster, and tie with a rope, as if it were a wheel: so that it does not swell to any part: and it will hold firmly by quiet for three or four days.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then solve the ligament, and the plaster, and compare the thigh with the other: then if you see them equal in state, then you know that the dislocation is already fixed: therefore, loosen the weak one for walking.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see something of softening: then return, and that plaster, and tie it according to your first stricture: and release it also for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then solve that and make it slow in walking over both for a few days, until it is well strengthened.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	¶ Regarding the dislocation of the knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee is dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	The knee is dislocated to the outside, to the inside, and to the lower part, that is, to the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it is not dislocated to the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	The sign of its dislocation is that it extends the weak leg, so that it applies its thigh to its own buttock.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	However, if it does not hold with the buttock: then you know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	And the restoration of all modes of its dislocation is that you make the weak leg sit straight, so that it can extend its thigh if possible over there, and hold your back to its face: and place its foot between your feet.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then hold on with your thumbs to its knee, and make straight lines over its knee with your fingers.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Then apply with your hand's side two sides of its knee with strength.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another one extends its foot, until it returns its knee to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	And the sign of return is that it holds on with the knee to the thigh without labor.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then apply the plaster itself, and hold on the knee with the thigh.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind it together for three or four days.
Deinde solue ea.	Then release it.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And do not use it for weak walking for a few days until it heals.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	However, if it refuses your return, then administer a strong extension with the bands that precede the report in the care of Anchaea, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	¶ Treatment of Calcaneal Dislocation.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The heel sometimes comes off by gentle removal and sometimes it is dislocated according to the complement.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation is made, either to the inside or outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you see the heel inflated, going to the part where it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	However, the treatment of its removal is a easy return: and it is that it extends with ease with the hands and becomes equal until it returns.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the treatment of it when it is dislocated according to the complement, it is necessary that you make the weak sit upright: and hold it with a strong hand from the back part of its back, in the middle of it.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold on with your right hand's foot of its part from the top of it and with your left hand's foot from the bottom part of its foot's place.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then pull your foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left hand, make two incisions.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with your left hand, and push the chest of the foot with your right leg without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice, as we have described.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the chest of the foot towards the third thigh, and you will pull out the catheter.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If then it returns to the third thigh, or to two in this manner, and you see the foot equalized, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation on this one, because it returns itself.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If however, it is forbidden for you to return it with what we have described: then make the weak side lie on its back over the ground, and fasten a bandage on the firm ground, so that it falls between its thighs: and you will have already covered it with the cloth, so that it does not hurt the weak one.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then let the attendant take the thigh of his patient: then extend the other foot, either with his hands, or with the bandage that lies on the neck of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then let the attendant extend all against the comparison of his extension: and let the bandage stand between the two weak thighs, holding it, so that it does not attract the body of its towards the lower parts in the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the physician should straighten the dislocation with his hands, and the other attendant should hold the sound thigh down to the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with weakness.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When then the dislocation returns, and it declares to you the health of its return: then put on the plaster and ointment, and tie it firmly with the strong bandages, and tie the foot with the bandage to the thigh.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you should be careful or fear that the nerves which are above the heel posterior may not be hurt by the bandage, and it does not become a burden to them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then release it for two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, tighten it again: then dissolve it on the third day, or the fourth: and forbid the weak one from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If however he dares to walk before that time, there is no security that it will not be dissolved by the displacement over it, and it will rot, and will not receive after that treatment.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If however a hot aposteme occurs on him: then it is necessary to administer to him in the sedative of his this, which precedes our narrative in another place from our cure, and embrocation, until it be removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	¶ About the displacement of the toes of the foot, and the cure.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It is necessary that it be equal to what is dislocated from them with a small extension without labor: and this in fact is not difficult, but rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If however the displacement is in some of the nodes of the back of the foot: then it is necessary that he make sit the weak leg of his on a place equal to the earth, or on a table: and stand as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then you stand, and place your foot on that which is described from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then shoe it with your foot with virtue, until it returns, and you will see that it is equal, and will not appear in the place of eminence.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under the belly of his foot a table which can hold the whole foot, with two handles.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then tighten it for three days according to the curve.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then dissolve it, and make him rest from walking for many days, until it be tightened and secured from the reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	¶ About the kinds of displacement with a sinew or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Head 36.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something happens from this, and the care of it and its restoration follows, death often follows: and therefore it is not fitting that they assume responsibility for the care of this kind of thing without being very experienced in the art, merciful, kind, slow, not bold, nor presumptuous: and to use in medicine when it stands still, apostemata hot only: and let go the weak for a long time.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you see, or hope for health from the destruction with the ease of the disease, and in which something seems to be hoped for.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, let them immediately perform the reduction of this, before the hot apostemata occur.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If then the member returns according to our will, at that time we should administer the regimen which soothes the hot apostemata: and care for the opposite side with it that agrees with him from desiccated ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If then dislocation is with fracture, and happen in the separated bones of the saturation, at that time let them dare to remove it, and make in that what I said in simple diseases from that which precedes in those places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And take care according to your virtue, and guard yourself from the fear within until it comes to my prediction for you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For this is better for you before your Creator, and more lasting to your glory, and more safe for your body among them in your time.
